reviews.review: Pristine high-end fashion hub. Ginza was where we stayed the second time we visited Tokyo. In terms of location I can't fault it. You'll find it to be very central, and most locations in Tokyo are only one train away (rather than having to change lines).The area itself is very clean, and is home to all the major fashion labels from around the world. If you have the money I'm sure this would be a fantastic place to shop. I found that nearly every store in Ginza is fashion and/or makeup. You won't find any arcades or electronics stores.On the weekends they block off some roads to traffic and set up tables and chairs in the middle of the streets. That's how busy this area gets when people aren't working. It's actually amazing to see and feel the contrast between a weekday and the weekend.You'll also find a great many restaurants in and around Ginza. They range from very fancy and expensive (in the heart of Ginza) to fairly cheap, so it's worth having a look around for a decent place that fits your budget. A nice bowl of ramen can certainly hit the spot without hitting your wallet, and the portions are generous.Personally, I believe that had I stayed in Ginza on my first trip to Tokyo I would have been disappointed. It's really not the Tokyo you see in the movies. For a second visit however, the location is fantastic for getting around.

One of the unique parts of Tokyo. If you're into shopping (or just window shopping) this is a must visit area of Tokyo. Very central and with some truly interesting architecture, it goes for several blocks and makes for an interesting stroll. Only downside is that the stores are predominantly the same brands you see in every major city, even though I'm advised that some of the clothes are different.
Bright lights, and shopping. We are not big shoppers, but if you are this is probably a five star attraction. There are a lot of restaurants to see here, and the scene is worth a stroll.

Hustle & Bustle in the Heart of Tokyo. This area has a good mix of attractions for serious shoppers and history buffs. High-end stores, unique shops and long streets/rows of endless shopping will satisfy the curious browser. Make sure you bring plenty of money and set aside time for some amazing food throughout the area.
Good place to observe the crowd. Take a seat in one of cafe's on a main junction of Ginza (close to Giza metro station) buy some expensive coffee and enjoy looking at people passing by.
A happening shopping district . Shop at muji and uniqlo til you drop. Take your original passport for 8% tax free discount. Also great restaurants and street lights

Ginza has all the shopping and restaurants of all levels.. The main street Ginza Chuo has the expensive stuff. But, just a couple blocks away on the side streets are more reasonable shops and restaurant. Yurakucho is also a few blocks away.

Great nightlife. When visiting Tokyo there are two places that are must visits for me; Ginza shopping district and Roppongi night life District. Both neighborhoods vibrant energy and interesting exploring. Very safe to walk at night.

Nice, but expected something a bit more. Have been hearing about Ginza since I was a kid so had to pay a visit when in Tokyo. Went with Hubby and our 9 year old son so I couldn't do much real shopping. I am sure there are plenty of department stores and brand name shops in the area if you are into shopping. It was nice walking around the streets and seeing some unusual shops, e.g. the 6 or 7 storey Uniqlo shop in Ginza with pretty impressive window display. Also went to the Apple store in Ginza but was a bit disappointed. Not as a grand as I expected.

Ginza the luxury shopping temple. I saw Champs-Elysées and the 5th avenue and they are both in their league high end luxury shopping avenues but Ginza is another level. The area is vast and the luxury brands are coming one after the other. I enjoyed the building design while my wife was inside Shiseido buying some creams. You can buy at Uniqlo even if you cannot afford upper scale brands.

Lovely Ginza in Tokyo. Ginza is one of the best place in Tokyo . My family enjoyed strolling in Ginza . Our hotel was situated in Ginza just opposite the Mitsukosi Ginza , Mitsukoshi Ginza is a Mall selling beautiful items . I bought a handmade japanese souvenir cup there .We also enjoyed dining in the restaurants in Mitsukooshi . During our stay in Tokyo we mostly ate our dinner at the Tempura , The Asian Cuisine ,The Italian Restaurant and The Okonomiyaki in Mitsukoshi Ginza ,Ginza is shopping district . You will enjoy the place . We also bought Mochi and the Himekuri Monaka at Ginza Akebono,Ginza is such a lovely place. The Japanese are kind and warm hearted people .We went also to Tokyo Tower , Akihabara , Tokyo Disney , Shibuya , Shinjuku , Pokemon Center , J World and Mt, Fuji . We really enjoyed our travel to Tokyo , Japan .My children enjoyed the One Piece in Tokyo Tower .We will be travelling again around Japan

Ultimate shopping district. This is one of the biggest and most luxurious shopping districts in the world with all high end brands represented. I recommend to go here on a Saturday because they close the major roads and turn them into walkways. You should also not only go on the major streets, take the small ones as well, where you will find the concept stores of major brands

Lovely area . Ginza is great area to be staying in if one is having a short stay in Tokyo... a wide variety of Japanese and world cuisine restaurants available at all price points... array of high end stores and lovely broad walkways modelled on London's oxford street perhaps... although it was my first Tokyo visit the location was perfect and no doubt I'll choose the same next time around too...

Glitzy glittering Ginza. One of the planet's most shiny temples to conspicuous consumption. Great to wander about in. And when you feel the burn step into one of the numerous coffee and other bars for a restorative.
excellent!. so safety in Ginza nights,hanging around.Many department stores,restaurants,enjoyable city...little bit complicated with communication with the Japanese...though.
Ginza - The New York of the East. Ginza is a high end shopping & eating place.Wide roads, wider pavements, busy crossings.Best time to visit is between 6PM to 9PM.
Upscale Japan. Brand Names and luxury shopping galore is here in Ginza. Very busy on weekend nights. Nice place for a 1 day visit if you just want to soak in the city.

It's just another grouping of stores, some high end and some not so high end, found this in downtown Tokyo as well.. I would not consider this a must-see, there are some big high end stores, but the same high end stores are in many of the Tokyo prefectures too. We walked around for about an hour, but I didn't see the draw or point of coming here, we could have stayed in Shinjuku and seen much of the same.

Start your evening early at Ginza . This is a very long and complicated stretched of road with lots of eateries ( under the major bridge ) or Restuarants within the shopping areas. It get confusing even when you use Google map to try to walk from the subway to other large department stores like Muji and Tokyo Hands. I have fun searching for my dinner place. Firstly within the submay station. Saw a beef/ steak store and when I sat down and they handed me the English menu, I realised it is a specialty store that sell every beef tongue dishes. I walked out apologetically and asked if there are any other eating area. The Young waiter directed me and accompanied me to the main road and with his Japanese pointed me to the streets parallel saying there are more sushi and beer drinking places. It was very nice and gracious of him to help me. I do ended up having a very pleasant sushi set dinner under the green metal bridge for dinner. After venturing through the alley that sell beer and local Japanese food in the open space, I decided to give it a miss since I am eating alone. Will come back with colleagues and friends next time. After dinner to walk around and trying to get to Muji store. But it was too late, the store closed at 9 pm and I turned back to The station to go back hotel. I will come back again.

Precioso. Es la zona cara de tokyo! Muy glamurosa y von muchas tiendas! Sobre todo de animales donde puedes entrar y ver unas preciosidades que se pueden adoptar! It is the face area of ​​tokyo! Very glamorous and with many shops! Especially animals where you can come and see some treasures that can be taken!

Very nice and modern area. It's similar to midtown Manhattan - many high-priced retail stores and many tourists strolling down the streets. One big difference - there are almost no souvenir shops! Most of the area is western-like - not many Japanese features.

The best place for shopping!. As far shopping goes, it's pretty hard to beat Ginza. It has everything, from upscale designer brands to mass market (but quality) Japanese ones. One day is not enough; 2-3 days of walking around Ginza is probably best, especially if you are visiting Japan with the intention to shop.

Lovely Area. Ginza is a lovely area of Tokyo with all the highend stores and some great restaurants. We wander around and it is all very clean and feels very safe. Easy to get to using the metro which is a fabulous system.

Most expensive street in Japan. Ginza is long known as the most expensive spot in Japan. The first Starbucks started here and many other brands would open their first Japan outlet here.
The road is a pedestrian heaven on weekends where they block off the roads and allow people to walk on the roads between the buildings.
A must visit for anyone coming to Japan.

Love The Ginza Area!. The Ginza area is similar to Times Square and Las Vegas with the bright lights, upscale shopping, and many many restaurants. There are many side streets off the main Ginza street and you can spend several days going strolling through the streets. The metro is accessible with stations every so many blocks. The Ginza area appears to be very safe and no worries walking the streets in the evening.
Have to say you were there. It's Ginza. The most unique thing is Sunday they close down the main street and it becomes a place with pop up cafes, bars, and music venues. Very contemporary.

Bring the Bling$$. Ginza is an upscale shopping district in Tokyo! It's worth a walk around. It's is also known for its restaurants but most are really upscale and expensive. Might be worth dinner for a special occasion.
Not to be missed!. Amazing fifth avenue Japanese style! A lot of modern japanese life. Sony building with hundreds of latest technology stuff!
Japan's 5th Avenue. All of the high-end stores are here. Be sure to walk the street at night for the lights and keep going to the south area which looks like a classier version of Times Square.

Had expected something more than it was!. As a world famous area, I had expected it was going to be something more than I found it to be. There are lots of big departmentstores and big streets and a metro station just NeXT door,but not that exciting!

Waste of Time. We are not big shoppers and may never have owned something with a prestige label (unless you include a $25 "Rolex" watch that I once had). And so we were not tempted to enter any of the stores in this famous quarter. For those of you out there like us, save the subway fare and go somewhere interesting instead.

Something for everyone . Amazing sights. The mix of high end brand outlets, flash cars and spectacular lighting, make for a great place to stroll in the early evening. Plenty of bars and restaurants to suit any taste. Needless to say, this is not the place to grab a bargain.
Large crowds, ritzy stores. At least one street was closed to traffic. Many high-end stores like Harry Winston, Tiffanies, Louis Vuitton, Chanel and Gucci.

just another place to drop your money. Maybe when I first visited 12 years ago, it was awesome because you're still in college and all the glamour and glitter were eye candy and uplifting to the soul. Now, it's just another neighborhood that's mostly catered to well off tourists or those who have saved up to spend on a limited edition item. I'm not against any of those, but shopping for designer goods isn't cheapest in Japan so I don't understand why anyone would want to go crazy here. However, Japan is known for issuing certain colors or crossover items you can't get elsewhere so that would be a good reason then. I thought I would see more architecture design wonders but that wasn't the case. Skip...I'd rather visit a neighborhood with more character and grit that really serves the locals instead.
Typical high end shopping street. Very busy, but also typical shopping street with all the big names. Didn't feel all that different from other major cities to be honest.

Elegant and upmarket Ginza. A lot of people prefer Shinjuku or Shibuya to Ginza. The noise and neon and crush is exciting. I get it. But give Ginza a go. Yes it's top end - like New York's 5th Ave - but there is a elegance and style here, especially at night. Wandering the main road after dark is the best time. The Chanel building becomes a giant video screen showing a black and white montage. The Cartier building next door subtly changes colour. The window displays in Tiffanys and major labels are like art. Go a street or two off the main strip and you uncover more restaurants than you'll have time to try. And the bars! The streets are less busy, the people more stylish. A visit here gives you another side to Tokyo.

Designer street.... I went during the weekend where all the motors were prohibited from entering the Main Street. If you have a bottomless wallet then you will like all the labels in one place..if not like me then it's good to have a stroll to say you've been...beware of high souvernier prices!

Running on their reputation ! . Basicaly a shopping district with high end names. Very expensive of course. Since the financial crisis a certain number of shops with less weight have opened. There is also the fact that more and more japanese people can't afford it anymore as the income gap has widened. It is now a nice light show at night. The likes of time square. For those who want to go for a bit of fun.
Enjoy the lights. Just enjoy all the lights, the busy people and the clean streets of Ginza. You see the same luxury brands like everywhere in the world, but never in this manner.

Visit Ginza even if you don't shop for name brand goods. Even though I'm not interesting in, or can afford to purchase, name brand items, the liveliness of the atmosphere and preponderance of eateries in Ginza makes it worth the visit. There are great snacks, interesting shops, and lots to look at in this area. Enjoy!

Light, Camera, Fashion. Its nice to take a stroll on the street which is closed off to traffic during weekend.
Basically all high end shops around here (Apple, Bvlgari, Loius Vutton....etc.)
Even if you are not into shopping or on a tight shopping budget, its worth a visit.
Nice atmosphere with cool/fancy looking buildings (everyone trying to outshine one another)

Best place to shop and eat. No matter the ages in your group, the Ginza is a world class area akin to Chicago and Nee Your shopping districts. Lost of hustle and bustle and fashion and prices for everyone,

5 star town. when u go to japan and u want to visit Ginza town and see what this town has to offer I highly recommend that u don't take ur girlfriend or wife the if u traveling on budget coz u will send all of ur money on shopping there are many things to see and do in Ginza even if u are in budget in my opinion wonderful town that u must see

A Must See If In Tokyo. Ginza is what people expect about Tokyo with its bright lights and glitzy shops and restaurants. Walk Ginza Dori to get the feel for the place and then go down the many side streets with the myriad of restaurants and shops and office buildings .

Second visit. It was a rainy day after the typhoon swept through the South China Sea and Japan areaThey have enclosed the street to become the pedestrian walk so there are no trafficLots of people were walking on the streets with umbrellas,especially tourists from China There are certainly exclusive expensive boutiques stores along the stripOur tour guide bring us into a tax free shopYou have to pay more than 5000 yens before you are qualified for the tax exemptionI was disappointed when I go to the camera sectionIt seems they only carry predominantly Sony products with a few canon cameras,not much camera heads,and there may be one or two Lumix and nikons on siteThere are lots of cosmetics from Korea which is worth checking outThe Purses from name brands,watches are more expensive than North AmericaThere are interesting toy shops with electronic Gage's e.g.there is a dog which is interactive,can play rollover and play dead,acts of peeing etc which the kids love to playThere are food stores and eateries along the street which is pricey,but this is GINZAAll the stores will talk to you in Mandarin and Chinese,what a difference in six years......the Japanese do know about to adapt to tourist industriesThere is not much to buy unless there are specialty items that you cannot buy from home..It is an interesting street to visit,the rainy day did dampen the spirit somewhat

Ginza is really the real Tokyo. Ginza is really the shopping heart of Tokyo, you have all the famous brands to dress up for tourists. People are free to walk along the road on a Sunday. A lot of tourists are taking great photos. The restaurants and cafes are really nice here in this area.

Shopper's paradise. Ginza is indeed a shopper's paradise where you can shop till you drop. You can basically find all the established branded retails with their flagship stores here. Ginza also has the biggest Uniqlo store in Tokyo.

Awesome if You're a Serious Shopper. The Ginza shopping district has every high-end store that you can think of. It was fun to walk down the middle of the street as they close it Noon 5 on Saturday, Sunday, and Holidays. It is also a good place for people watching.
wonderful. Branded shopping paradise, nice building and clean city. Worth visiting if you like to shop for expensive goodies.

the lights of ginza are a must to see. No trip to Tokyo is complete with at least a walk around Ginza - come at night and see the lights or come during the day and go shopping at the high end shops located there

Don't miss the big department stores!. There is lots of shopping, but I think the big department stores are the most interesting. The bottom levels have the most amazing food vendors. It is fun to just walk through and see all the interesting and beautiful food. Don't miss Mitsukoshi.

An Upscale Organized Area for Shopping, Dinning, Clubbing and More. Ginza is the Oxford Street of England, Las Vegas Blvd Forum Shops of USA (no Casino though), or Robson Street of Vancouver (for Dinning). This is an area nearer from Tokyo Station or Imperial Palace Hotel, always well lit in the night, very safe and one can find almost any high end shopping item from Electronics to Cosmetics to Stationary to Clothing. Ginza is a very enjoyable atmosphere. Very organized, wide sidewalks (pavements), and you will also find Office goers reminding you of San Francisco Union Square. It is worth a visit if you are in Tokyo.

Shopping paradise. The Oxford Street of Tokyo. You think of any high end brand and the chances are they'd have their flagship store here. Great for window shopping and for serious shoppers. Great to while away your time soaking in what Tokyo has to offer.

Excellent for shopping. Ginza is one of the most expensive shopping places in the world. Mitsukoshi is the landmark department store in this area though I spent more time in the Uniqlo. Ginza is a must do in Tokyo.

Dream come true at SanrioWorld Ginza. It was a dream come true to find a lot of My Melody and Little Twin stars items. Ginza is a good place for shopping. We also visited Uniqlo. There are smoking and non smoking designated times for some restaurants.

Super Modern Shopping District. Love it here. Maybe it was because it was super convenient to get here from my hostel but I kept on finding myself coming back to explore the huge malls, boutique shops or chilling in a cafe.

A place you must see, but not to eat or drink.. The place is very cool, very nice to see all the bright lights, all the shops and restaurants. However, I found it to be an expensive area for food, drink and shopping. Therefore, if you're budged conscious, don't go to this area to do any of the above.

A Bit Pricier. We found most shopping to be a bit more on the high end scale. Still a good place to see and shop. Just don't go here with the intention of buying unless you are ready to spend for the higher end goods.
Ginza!. Shopping Shopping Shopping! Went on a Saturday and it was car-free day! Awesome to be walking and mingling withe crowd! Plenty of shops for you to go into and find the perfect gifts!

Shopping district for big brands. Prices here are slightly on the high side. This is especially true with the restaurants and drug stores. The central Chuo Dori street is close to automobiles and become a large pedestrian zone on weekends. The road closure takes place from 12:00 to 17:00 (until 18:00 from April - September).

Must stay place in Tokyo. If you want to experience gourmet food, high end shopping, Ginza is the place you must stay when visiting Tokyo. Everything is within a walking distance and you can save lots of travelling time. Moreover, the distant between Tsjiku Market is within 15 minutes or one subway station.
Clean District. Ginza houses top end branded shopping belts. The road is closed for traffic during Sunday for shoppers to walk freely.
Great shopping experience!. What a great shopping experience! There are lots of high-end shops and boutiques. There is a variety of shops to please a lot of different tastes.

Ginza... the colorful shopping paradise. Ginza is the Tokyo's colorful chicissime shopping area... Large boulevards, enormous buildings, heavy traffic and some more than interesting and intriguing examples of contemporary architecture used for the designed brand palaces... with the good old clock tower and the new, yet traditionally looking Kabuki theatre house. It's incredibly lively 24-7. Not to be missed... The new Ginza METOA artistic and high/tech space with the lovely cafes nearby seem to be quite a nice surprise, attractive, attiring and perfectly functional space designed by the famous Jamapnese architect Shigeru Kubota.
Fashion, architecture and good wibe . Good area if you have a taste for high end brands and amazing architecture . Try out the food court in the basement of mitsuya department store

Upscale shopping. Great place to walk around and see Tokyo by night. Loads of office people walking to go home or bars and restaurants in the area. Shopping is open till late at night and they have all upscale brands here.
good shopping place. nice place to shop.. you will get enough of variety over here . its a good shopping place for women's wear

High end, great hotel Millenium Mitsui Garden, Tokyo Japan. Ginza in Tokyo is very high end. There are no food courts and minimal basement department store eateries. Unlike Shibuya, Shinjuku and Harajuku, Ginza is home to the young female shopper with a wallet full of credit cards. Tokyo is a very clean city. There are minimal garbage/trash bins around, yet no rubbish on the streets. There are limited seating availability in most places, and super markets are few and far between in Ginza. The Tokyo Metro train network is amazing and second to none in the world, Hong Kong would come a close second. There is no real city centre, with many 'centres' around the city. If I return to Tokyo I will be staying in Shibuya, Shinjuku or Harajuku. These places are more affordable middle of the road shopping and restaurants and take out. Restaurant consist of eels, Octopus, tofu, cold udon noodels, miso soup and of course sushi.Japanese people are very polite and courteous. Manners is something that Japanese people have embraced and it reflects in their culture and way of life. You always feel welcome and accommodated for here in Japan. Our hotel is fantasic and right next to Higashi-Ginza station. An elevator ride to the street and you are only steps away from the hotel entrance. Staff made us feel very welcome and have accommodated us with directions, suggestions for food and shopping. The hotel itself is only a few blocks away from the main highend shopping area, yet far enough away not to be caught up in the hustle and bustle of the crowded streets. I would highly recommend this hotel if you are wanting to stay in Ginza. Bring your credit cards though...you'll need them!
Fun place. Interesting area of Tokyo lots of shops and places to eat. Great range of everything that you could be looking for.
avoidable. Nothing of interesting to see. Just fashion's stores, skyscrapers and nothing else. I didn't come to Tokyo to see some things that I can found in any western city.

Japan's Ginza District is so much more than just great shopping. When we decided to stay in Ginza, my wife's wanted to go shopping, but as we explored the shopping areas, we found so much more. We found many quiet neighborhoods with fabulous local food, and beautiful corporate buildings such as the Sony Building. We even saw a local parade walking down a main road.But the local food was not what I expected, it was a wonderful surprise. We had two days of eating local food for both lunch and dinner since we enjoyed the flavors of these small restaurants. We had delicious grilled beef and vegetables, flavorful soups (much different taste than just ramen), but our favorite was local fish grilled to perfection and the meat peeled right off the bones....sooo good! So when you go to Ginza, either ask your hotel concierge for directions to local food areas, or just go exploring!!

Ginza on Sundays. The traffic is closed for cars on Sundays. I think that is the best time to visit Ginza. I was on a mission to find two places - Cartier to get my watch battery replaced and a Geox shoe store. Both I found via Google map easily. Get off at Ginza station and you will come up to the busy cross "dori". Use certain stores as landmark on your Google map or any map to get your bearings. It is a good idea to plan ahead of time what places you want to stop while you are here. But if you don't have anything specific, don't forget to branch off into the side streets. Although Ginza is known for international high end brands, there are many unique stores and boutiques to browse and shop as well. The famous stationery store Itoya has a nice spot where you can sit and people watch from above. You can find fancy restaurants but there are still set meals for reasonable prices. Tea shops with tastings, Japanese sweets, fine department stores, Sony building, Shiseido flagship store, kabuki theatre, etc. Lots to see and do.You can easily spend the whole day here. Plan it well so you can save extra walking!

Ginza. Tokyo is a monstrous city and the shopping district of Ginza reflects it. It is vast, but it is also very expensive with designer clothing shops everywhere. The main attraction for me was the aesthetic. Good for loads if photographs, especially at night.
Expensive goods. If you are looking for luxurious goods, this is the place to go. All the big brands have their flagship stores in this area.

Great place to shop. The Ginza is a busy mega of designer shops which caters for everyone. Experience the Ginza on a Saturday afternoon as the roads are blocked off and the shopping experience becomes one big mall with no traffic for about 5-6 blocks. And if your tired feet just want to sit and people watch there are tables and chairs set out down the middle of the road to rest. My favourite place to shop when I'm in Tokyo.

Not really for us. If you want to go shopping and are into designer labels then this is most likely your idea of a good day out. For our part all I could see was inflated prices probably to pay for the expensive facades of the shop units etc. Similar to any other main retail area in the world with little to no Xfactor that we saw.
Expensive Area. A nice but rather expensive area of Tokyo. You'll find premium brands like Louis Vuitton and the works here.
The area for rich people (;. It was an experience to see streets with all the most expensive brands (; there is a nice department shop with umbrellas starting from 50e in sale (;

ฺBusiness area with a convenience.. A lot of shopping area with the hi-end brand. Business or luxury hotels around here. Easy to transportation by Metro, JR and limousine bus to airport. Please spend around 1 day to visit here.
Impressive . The sequence of buildings is quite impressive.. Luxury brands one after the other, buildings very nice in terms of architecture, there is something..
Awesome place. Great shopping, great restaurants, wish we had more time to explore. Wonderful aquariums at the Sony building. And a pedestrian crossing going diagonally.

The place to be!. A buzzing Tokyo district ideal for dining, shopping and going out (everything is walking distance here). Great vibe - I always stay there when I come to visit. Very accessible & well connected to local transportation and other areas of the city. Accommodation tip: be sure to check the size of your hotel room before you book - most tend to be really tiny.
wide avenues and luxury shops. Unfortunately it all adds up to become one of the most boring areas of Tokyo- unless you have plenty of money to spent at the big brands.
Fabulous shopping district in the heart of Tokyo. Wonderful place not only to shop but to "people watch" as well! Found great venues here for restaurants and wine bars!

Just a normal shopping district. Nothing special. If you want to spend a lot of money on clothes and other stuff its nice. But overall its just a normal shopping area like in other big cities and NOT worth the visit if you dont want to go into a shopping spree. As someone that travels by himself and isnt going to Japan to buy a lot of clothes it was definetly not worth it. I can buy exactly the same in Germany, so why in Japan??

This. Is. Ginza!. Fashionable people, in a fashionable part of town. All the modern sophistication you can ask for.Did not go to shop, so can tell you nothing about that, save that all the name brands are here.|Food-wise, there are restaurants galore. Check out all the side streets and those parallel to the main strip. There is food of every price range, and the basement food halls of the big department stores are a must.

Lively place. We walked around for one hour or so, between upscale shops, eventually stopping at a Chinese restaurant. It's a vivid place, not as crowded as other parts as Tokyo, but definitely not to be missed, if to capture the soul of this city.It's also close to the Central Station and to the Imperial Palace.

Excellent food, shopping and street food in B2. My family loved the traditional Japanese food. And my daughter loved their Italian restaurant on the 12th floor. B2 level is filled with traditional street food of Japan and you can eat anything from octopus to honey comb ice cream. My family enjoyed the ice-cream with honey comb in it. For shopping this is the place to be. You get all brands and they have shopping assistants to help you with your shopping expedition. Overall, wonderful experience.
The Famous Ginza. This is the same famous Ginza Street which is a trademark icon of Tokyo city. Quite an experience. You can roam around and surf through top brands here.
Japanse version of Regents Street. Nice shops but very much international chains. Wander to the back streets for great places to eat. Nice toy shop

Great for shopping! especially for food.. My mum and I went in to shop for japanese food, it was cheap and incredibly delicous. obviously they had places to shop clothes and cosmetics, my sister and her friend bought a lot of stuffs.
The clock tower was amazing and it was soooo amazing! loving it!

Busy like London's Oxford Street. Loads of shops to keep you busy all day! If you love shopping, you'll love Ginza! There are many shops which are also above ground level so be sure to look up as well as forwards! Lots of people around too so beware of bumping into other tourists!
Great place for shopping.. Loved the Ginza area, it's a great place for shopping.......if you have the money, definitely recommend the Lion Beer Hall, great atmosphere.

Nice Shopping area. Ginza is a nice shopping area. If there is something you are looking for that you can't get at home,ry looking for it in the Ginza neighborhood. There are also some nice food places if you get hungry while shopping. The worlds largest Uniqlo is in Ginza. Twelve floors of Uniqlo fashions. If you like cutting edge desinger fashions straight off the runway, try the Dover Street Market right behind Uniqlo. A Sanria store is located in one of the nearby malls.

Extraordinary buildings, luxury shopping. Ginza feels like another planet. It is filled with buildings designed by famous architectures like Tod's building, Dior building, and many, many more The area is overwhelming in terms of luxury and modern.

Luxury Shops, many restaurants and good bars. On the weekend afternoons it is pedestrian kingdoms !Many luxury shops, from old Europe or more modern, tea & coffee shops, some even with their own factory.At night, may local are wall dress to go to restaurant or just to a music bar.Very nice place to hang around and enjoy a night in Tokyo.

My favourite area in Tokyo. Amazing area for shopping, food etc, and ultra convenient. Loved all the department stores and the huge variety of options available when it comes to choosing a restaurant for dinner etc. Reasonably high end so things are quite expensive, but great for browsing and generally relaxing without the chaos of places like Shinjuku.
Excellent shopping. Ginza has a lot of shopping and it's easy to walk around. Just about anything you want will be there. A lot of famous stores.

Shopping heaven.. If you have been thinking about some shopping when you are in Tokyo, don't miss this place. Ginza is like 5th avenue in N.Y, but is so much better. They have everything here as they have in N.Y, plus more. Ginza is not the only shopping district in Tokyo, but they have all and then I mean ALL highend brandstores.

Glittering shops & lights. Apart from the department store, many of the shops were out of our price market. However, they are great to see. At night the lights are amazing as all the store fronts, up several stories, are lit with creative signs. On Sunday evening they close the street off.

Laid-back Ginza ( Tokyo) tour. After an overnight stay at Hilton Tokyo Bay Hotel to spend a day in DisneySea, we transferred to ROYAL PARK, SHIODOME so we could explore and experience GINZA District and neighboring points of interests. We started with the Tsukiji market, then to Tokyo Tower; Meiji Temple with the many century old varieties of wine displayed at the temple entrance ground; the Sky Tree, and the palace (at a distance). We stopped at a place where we witnessed the famous " scramble crossing" and queued at the side of a busy street to have a taste of the the Ichiban Ramen. We also visited Diver City with the giant Gandam on display in Odaiba and to see tulips in full bloom. The day was capped by a visit to a very reputable store where preloved bags, watches and jewelries were sold at reduced prices.
Alive & Buzzling Energy. a must see to expereince the Mega Shopping Every Friday evening the roads are closed to the Public as to create a stress feel atmosphere - High end Shopping

Modern Ginza. Ginza is a very modern and busy area with many offices and shopping. I wouldn't spend a lot of time there but well worth a "walk through". I found some of the surrounding areas much more worthwhile. If you're touring Tokyo, exit at the Ginza station and start exploring --you'll pass through relatively quickly on to your next discovery in the surrounding areas!

Shopping, eating district. Much to do in a up-scale part of Tokyo. Some world class camera stores here. High end clothes shopping. Food galore. This is an inviting and upscale part of Tokyo that was very enjoyable overall. I liked that many of the side streets were closed to traffic over the weekend making a nice pedestrian friendly environment.

A nice place to wandering around. Ginza has a lot of shops and department stores, from street brands to the luxury ones. The footpath is wide and nice for walking. The area is usually not as crowded as other area such as Shibuya or Shinjuku, so I think it is quite a nice place for wandering around especially for family. Many nice restaurants around too.

Must go! . Ginza is just like New York's 5th avenue. The streets are filled with shopping malls & luxury name brand stores. There are also tons of restaurants & cafes around the area. Shopping in Japan is super expensive but sight seeing & soaking up the energy are complimentary! So definitely take a few hours to roam around Ginza, get some lunch & coffee& just get lost. The shops don't open till around 10.30am.
I love this neighborhood. Best area in Tokyo where you can go shopping and you can find the finest restaurants and the best patisseries in the city!

Rather overwhelming shopping experience.. Again, another place you have heard about all your life and there it is. There are almost endless high end shops, boutiques, restaurants and department stores to name just a few. We were told that Japan was in a recession but there was no sign of it here. Clerks in the shops were very friendly and helpful, and most spoke English which was very helpful, especially if you were looking for specific items. While we were there a sound truck, resplendent with the Imperial Japanese flag from days gone by, went by. We were told this was operated by a right wing group who want to re militarize Japan. Scary.
Trendy and fun. Probably one of the busiest neighbourhoods you'll ever find yourself in. Even without splurging in the expensive shops it is still fun to just poke around and take in all the action.

Shopping . If your looking for high end shopping this is the place to go. There are lots of restaurants to eat and places to shop. I didn't do too much shopping because my Yen was starting to run out, but I enjoyed the area.

Nice business centre. We watched the picture of Ginza busy intersection cross on TV very often whenever mentioning Japan economy. It is nice to visit in the evening time to enjoy watching the buildings and retail stores all lighted up but only few people on the road. You can have a leisure walk on the pedestrian road without interruptions. Metro station is nearby and you can access easily back to your hotel after relaxation. Ginza is a beautiful city.

Beautiful. Very nice place to admire buildings and architecture... And if you're planning to spend lots of money as well once there are only the most expensive brands there... This is also nice for a walking late at night as the place isn't so full of people and stores are closed, with lots of lightening everywhere... The only issue is with the constructions and maintenance processes that happens during the night and may be kind of noisy in some areas...
Very well-maintained. Clean, well-maintained, and neat. Tons of things to buy as there are so many stores. Since I'm not into shopping, I'm going to give this place four stars.

So many department stores. We went on the weekend when the streets were closed off. It was pretty fun to walk down the streets where cars should have been but instead there were people.The department stores are really fancy and upper class not really what we were after.Another user recommended finding Itoya. They suggested it is in the Mitsukoshi department store. It is actually a store on its own further down the street from the department store but we went in and asked and the staff helped us with its location.Itoya is worth finding for the 8 floors of stationary.
Nice high end shopping district . If you are into luxury shopping, this is the place. You can find all luxury international and local brands here. They have very nice options of dining as well.
Excellent area . Ginza is an area that full of branded fashion. Modern and nice building. If you love shopping with expensive staff and trends, better visit here.

Expensive and Beautiful. I got to Ginza and simply started roaming around. Everything is extravagant and beautiful and the price is befitting.I read in a review that you can find some good deals here but couldn't find anything myself, I bought nothing.
Shoppinh. Great "posh" shops, quite expensive of course, but fun to browse, soak up and enjoy the Japanese-Eurobrand-phile spirit!!

Small area with the best brands in the world. Ginza area consists basically of a big avenue or street where you can see the most famous brands show off. Gucci, Chanel, Rolex, Mikimoto... The best brands are located in about 10 blocks that you can walk around easily. Even affordable brands like Uniqlo have beautiful 10 story buildings to show off their brand.

Something for everyone. Ginza was our base whilst visiting Tokyo and it was a fantastic choice. It has everything close to hand, good shopping where you can just browse or shop tIll you drop, various styles of bars that cater for all times of the day and every conceivable style of restaurant all within easy walking distance. Walking around is simple and easy as it's very flat and there are easily accessable transportation links across the rest of Tokyo. Easy to navigate as it's roads are mainly in a grid layout system so little chance of getting lost. We just loved it and would not hesitate to base ourselves there again should we ever return.

just another high end street.... If you want to shop or have the spare time then take a walk down Ginza. It is like most high end streets around the world. Nothing really special. Great for luxury shopping that is for sure. In the evening the walk is better. Classy part of Tokyo.

Worth a visit if you have time. We strolled this area of Tokyo during a recent visit. It gives a perspective on the upscale nature of the city, but the stores (or many of them are Western) and if you have come to Japan to experience something other than Western stores, you can probably skip this. That said, walking around here gives an interesting perspective.
Ginza the right place for shopping. Ginza, is, one area of Tokyo with lots of good restaurants, good shops, and shopping malls like Mitsukoshi, very nice area to take an evening walk.

Lux and classy place. Try to visit twice during day time and night time. Highlight for me is the yokan and matcha tea house nearby excelsior cafe. If you like socialite place to hangout then go no further to shiseido cafe

High class luxurious places to go. It was a high class area with good looking and expensive look of shopping centre buildings. The area was accessible for a baby stroller and the pedestrian walkways were clean and convenient to walk through. The area was safe although there were many people walking to and fro.

everything yo want to see and shop is here !!. Yes !! Everything you want to see and shop is here !! Provided you can afford it !! Tokyo is undoubtedly an expensive city , and its standards show in Ginza !! for us here in India , shopping there is very expensive ....but one can get a few bargains from shops that have things put on a discount .........Every big name - Armani , Prada , Cartier , Tiffany , Apple ...........is there ...............for me all of it was window shopping , but absolutely enjoyable ........I did not realize how long i had been walking just looking around ..........you see people playing musical instruments and even painting ....chairs arranged on the street , closed for vehicles -where one can sit with a cup of coffee and just relax .......Subways in Japan are easy to travel via ..............Ginza Station is one of the very popular ones there ...........

Window shopping. High end brands have their main stores here. You will not be disappointed. Expenxive, yes. But there is good shopping if you know where to go. Lots of good places to eat also. Ginza train station is also central to most places in Tokyo. There are
Great shopping centre. Very easy to get to by subway. Street has all the shopping you can imagine. Very good to see even if you're not a shopper.
Amazing! . Vibrant, full of energy and high end. Great stores for shopping for brand names. A great neighborhood to visit while in Tokyo.
Lot's of shopping!. If you like branded goods, this is the place to be! There are also nice coffee places to check out such as Brooks.

Visit the Ginza subway station! A must !. We stumbled upon the ginza subway station and it was amazing! The underground station is the finest Tokyo has to offer in terms of ambiance , buildout , decor ! The food court is superb, champagne , caviar !

Great place for shopping. This is a very good place for shopping and cafe hopping! Do drop by the different animation cafes that are available here.Examples are the gundam cafe, honey cafe, maid cafe,etc. The night scene is different from day and is worth another visit.
High Class Shopping Area. All the world high end brands are here. Prada, Dior, etc, etc, just name it. It is nice to stroll around, and will be even nicer if you have much to spend here.
Wide streets with nice shops-easy stroll. Shops are the same glam international brands in any big city in the world, so did not shop, but the stroll was nice and it was good woman (fashion) watching.
Ginza is at heart of tokyo. the best place to walk if you want to know the trend in tokyo, lot of food, shopping, brands options
Have a walk around the lights of Ginza!. Great experience! To just walk and have fun, because shopping in this area is quite imposible for low budget traveler :P :P :P

Hi class neighbourhood . Hi class shops - any brand that you are looking for it are located in this area. Nice restaurant and reasonable prices.
It a must see area in Tokyo.

I love ginza. One of my favorite places in Tokyo. I always stay here when I travel on business. Walking at night is definitely more enjoyable than in the day. The lights are amazing and I think competes right up there with Akihabara. The Chanel building has this amazing light show. There is definitely a high energy vibe when you walk around. But be prepared to spend a lot of money. The shops are mostly high end and very expensive. If you get off the Main Street there are lots of little shops that are fun to walk and look around in. If you aren't staying here it's easy to get to. It's one stop from Tokyo station.

Good for a walk after a heavy dinner. If you intend to stretch your money, don't shop here unless you are going for a premium luxury items. However, is still an interesting place to go for a walk and look at all the window display. We visited on a weekday and the was not crowded. If you are looking for Tokyo street crowd crossing, go to Shibuya.
For shopping funs. Nice place to go if you love shopping and the most known fashion brands of the world. A lot of shops, boutiques and restaurants.

What A Sight!. Every high end (or MEGA-high end) designer or luggage company or jeweler you could imagine has their own building in the Ginza. And they have all tried to outdo each other architecturally. The result is an incredible series of buildings that is well worth a walk. Plus the area has amazing departments stores (hit the basements for food!), traditional shops and some fantastic restaurants - at all price ranges. And at night it is spectacular!

Upscale Shopping. Great area to window shop! Most of the shops are very high end designers where you must be buzzed in through the door. They are too expensive for my taste, but I did find several wonderful little art galleries.

It's the Regent Street of Ginza!. Bustling wide street with end to end classy shops with all the best known brands. One not to miss is the downstairs food hall at Matsuya where the food displays are more art than food and would leave Fortnum and Mason standing still!

Shopping Mecca. Bustling area that is a shoppers paradise. It has all the brand names you could possibly want all in one place. On a Saturday afternoon, they shut down the main street through the area to traffic - becoming a pedestrian only avenue for shoppers which has a great vibe.

Beautiful area to embrace Tokyo life. Beautiful area to walk around. Tremendous number of shops and food options. You can get a cup of coffee and simply enjoy the people watching, or you can simply flow with the crowd.

Nothing special. A must do when in Tokyo. It is just a crossing and there are many big ones in Tokyo so do not expect too much. However, it is rather fun to view. The Hachiko statue is located right by the crossing so go have a look at it too if you are here.
loved it. Great, lively area, amazing shopping. we really liked almost everywhere we visited, as each place has so much to offer and diversity.

The place to shop in Tokyo. Ginza is known for shopping but it clearly has much more. There are plenty of places to eat as well. The very large department stores are all present. Many department stores have a food hall one floor below the the main floor. It's a great place to get cookies, candy and virtually anything else you might want. Ginza is the place to shop
Not much for shopping but its fun to walk about.... For shoppers this is probably heaven but I just enjoyed walking around watching other people spend their money :)

Restaurant paradise.... My hotel was 2 minutes walk from Ginza, so I had the opportunity of coming here atleast 4 times during my stay in Tokyo. To my mind, this happens to be the restaurant as well as shopping district of Tokyo. Totally posh, Totally upscale. And if you are a foodie, you will be in food heaven..if there is such a thing. All kinds of cuisines can be explored. And if you are an Indian craving for home food, I spotted at least 10 Indian restaurants. I am sure there will be more. Great place.

fanatic silver place. super experience of drinking colorful levels with Karoke .3 hours times spent in a minutes but many more things left to taste in this traditional cum freak street of this silver place.

Streets are closed to cars on the weekend . Great shopping coffee and to sit and people watch . On weekends it's a sight to be seen . No cars are allowed in . Umbrellas and chairs are put out on the road to sit on and watch people go by or watch people sell there goods . There are lots of high end shops . I bought my new iPad there . Great service . Very busy shop . We went to a cute coffee shop wow coffee and service was great

Chic, sleek, trendy!. Ginza means silver place. Its name comes from a silver mint that was built in 1612. It has many shops selling traditional crafts mix with galleries, high-end department stores and the ultra-modern Sony showroom. It is very clean, elegant, polite and very safe downtown. It is just a pleasure to walk around it. It is mainly visited by wealthy and elegant Japanese people. The service is impeccable. Of course, it is expensive. There are several places to see: the San"ai building which is made of glass, the Mitsukoshi department store which is glamorous and sells beautiful kimonos, Wako, Mikimoto, and Printemps. Walking through Sotobori-Dori was quite relaxing and on this street we found a nice café where we had a delicious ice cream. My favourite site is the entrance of Hankyu and Seibu store with its magnificent clock that sounds at the hour! From there, we walked to the Imperial palace.It is easy to reach. Just take the subway to Ginza.

The place to be. You can get a little of so many of the things that make Tokyo special and a lot of others (like shopping). We wandered up and down side streets and main streets, people watched from an upstairs cafe, took in the beautiful window displays and snapped many photos of the neon and lights. Don't miss the food halls in the basements of department stores - many local specialties and more pastry and sweets than you could try in a year.
Shopping paradise. I love Ginza, A lot of good restaurants. Good place for shopping. You can find all well known brand here.

Lives up to its reputation. We went to the Ginza by subway and walked all around the shopping precinct. It was busy and some of the stores are to be seen to be believed. One of the subway stops entrances comes out directly under one of the large department stores. People queue for it to open. The food section in the basement is massive and the rest of the store is impressive also. The bowing of all the staff as you pass them is also impressive.Lots of other shops to see (all the big names), but leave your credit cards behind at the hotel if you want to pay for the rest of your holiday.

No sign of recession in Ginza. Japan may be in recession but there is not sign of it in Ginza. The designer shops and department stores are amazing and the architecture and interior designs of the buildings are worth the visit alone.

The Exclusive side of Tokyo. The walk from the Imperial Palace is a beautiful walk, very scenic. One can sense that a lot of money is centered in Ginza.  We saw the beautiful Imperial Hotel, partly designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. This was a personal highlight for me. The shopping area is a hotbed of luxury, with many high-end department stores and boutiques. Not many tourists around, maybe just the serious shoppers. Don't expect street food or vending machines here either, I imagine Ginza shoppers would sit for their wine.
Shopping . If you want to go shopping then this is a good place to do it. Your usual international metropolitan brands can be found here.

Vibrant shopping district. Ginza is a very busy area of the Metropolitan Tokyo. Fashion chains, fast food chains and all kinds of shopping is available on the main street. An Apple store also has become a key attraction. The smaller alleyways between houses have numerous small restaurants and pubs which serve authentic Japanese dishes and whiskeys. But comparatively you pay more for what you get there.

Lovely Area. Great district for shopping and restaurants. Stayed in a local hotel and spent quite a bit of time just walking around Ginza - the St Germaine des Pres of Tokyo. If you like Muji - don't miss a visit to their flagship store. The cafe/restaurant in store is worth a stop too. Mitsukoshi's food dept (in the basement) is a must visit! We bought some delicious salads and had a picnic on the roof of the building!

World's cleanest, safest downtown.. Reviewing Ginza is like reviewing Manhattan. It is a large central area of Tokyo and includes hundreds of large and small stores with all of the world's best brand names, scores of galleries, and countless restaurants offering everything from fast food to ultra expensive dishes. It is like Manhattan except that it is totally safe and always clean, and nobody will ever be rude, just not done. Great part of the world and not cheap.

Lovely part of Tokyo. Very nice shopping streets, department stores and boutiques. Everything is clean and safe. Make sure to take a moment and enjoy the big pedestrian crossings where everyone croesses the streets at the same moment. Not quite like Shibuya Crossing, but the same feeling.
Top brands. Plenty of staff to shop. More than enough to buy. Top brand in the world and Japan. Each building individual brand, the buiding itself is also the nice n unique attraction.

Ginza is a high end shoppers paradise. Very upscale with retailers from all over the world. The stores and the people watching are off the charts amazing. I spent the whole day in the Ginza. Next time I will stay near here. Its a great neighborhood.

Upscale shopping destination. If you are into an upscale shopping experience, then Ginza is the place to go. Luxury boutiques and amazing collections at every corner. Need a break to rest your legs and arms, you will have a lot of restaurants to choose from. However, with tax-free shopping, the prices of designer goods are considerably more expensive than other cities especially in Europe. Still, shopping there is a lot of fun!!!

Worth a visit for sure - the Knightsbridge of Tokyo. We visited Ginza a couple of times in the evening. Lots of great restaurants across the price spectrum but also just amazing to walk through, with all the window shopping available.

Ginza at night. Went to the Ginza at night after a day tour. Wow it was an experience seeing more than three hundred or more people crossing the street at one time. Lots of stores and shops and priced at the higher end with the usual luxury stores. Subway station located nearby and so convenient

Ginza is a must. Mind you, many of the shops you see in Ginza are exactly the same on display in New York, Milan, Hong Kong, and yet there's something to it. Maybe, it is the small restaurants, the coffee shop you can spot between one luxury stop and the next or the proximity of the lively Ginza Corridor, or the prestigious Imperial Hotel or the gorgeous Hibiya Park... I love walking through this place!

Lively shopping belt. Stayed at a hotel on this stretch and there was so much to see even at night. Used to like staying at Shinjuku, but that area has become too touristy so I'm now more inclined toward Ginza.
Lovely visit. There were many posh designer shops and it houses the most expensive real estate in Japan. We didn't stop at any shops but none the less it was a nice walk through.
The shopping mecca!. A must for great shopping. All the top designers are here. The prices are no cheaper but buying is more fun.

Nice clean shopping area. Having 0 interest in shopping not to mention first class brands, I just went for a short walk around. It's a really nice and developing are with beautiful modern buildings, so it's worth even without spending a yen.

Go if you are rich. I did not spend enough time in Ginza to give the neighborhood a fair review. I had one day left in Tokyo and wanted to see as much of the city as possible. However, when visiting Ginza, I truly felt out of place. The area is clearly built and designed for the very wealthy. Once I was there, I knew that I did not belong in the neighborhood. I did a little window shopping before quietly moving onto my next location. If you have the money, I would suggest visiting Ginza. It was unlike any other location I have seen in Asia with the high quantity of luxury shops there. If you do not have the money, it is best to visit other locations. Japan and Asia overall have many luxury shops, so it won't be hard to find many of the same items in a different and possibly cheaper location.

Your wife will love it. We stayed at the Mitsui Garden Ginza Premier hotel with a Fine View of Ginza. The Japanese have such an appreciation of art and architecture walking the streets of this upscale district is all the entertainment you need. Besides the night time photo opportunities the main street is also closed on Friday and Saturday afternoons for pedestrians a great time to people watch.I also recommend going up to Tokyu Plaza where you have a great view from the 10th floor of the intersection below and best of all it's free. Fine dining on floors six and nine.
Modern. Impressive modern city. Can be very congested during morning rush hour, lunch break and after office hours. Best to visit on weekends.

Nice during the day. . Ginza is definitely great to go to during the day when all the shops and cafes are open.. But stay far far away from this place at night. It is still incredibly safe, you can walk around at 2/3am with no worries! It's just simply too deserted at night owing to the fact that it is a business area, so once the workers have left.. You are alone!I would give it a higher rating if only it were more lively during the night.
The hustle and bustle of Tokyo. Flashing neon, international brands, amazing window shopping. If you're into shopping this is for you.

Classy area. We stayed in this area for 12 nights and enjoyed each night immensely. The area is quiet and in a large city that is amazing.The highlight was the food hall of the Matsuya Ginza Dept store....oh could have spent days sampling bits here and there.Great location with 2 main train lines: Ginza and Yamanote. 'Mercure Ginza' was a great place to stay.

All the shopping you can get. Ginza is the place to be for shopping. They have big name brands and luxury brands, as well as local Japanese shops for souvenirs. Also there are two major department stores with food markets on the bottom floors. The streets close on Saturdays and Sundays for easy shopping. There are also various restaurants nearby.

Shopping and Architecture street. Branded products are all here, and if you dont have money for shopping you can spend your time enjoying the great architecture here. The street is closed for car and motorcycle until 6 or 7 pm.
Walking. Just a shopping street.... very clean even with no trash canns but that is normal i thing in Tokyo. Went to the Yamaha music store but was not very impressive.

Ginza... high end brands of the world are ALL HERE!. High end brands from Loui Vitton, Hermes, Prada, Gucci, its all here in Ginza. A strip full of shopping and dining, its a must visit for people who are brand concious. There are also famous brands that are not that expensive like Uni Qlo and H&M available here.
Shopping Strip. The shopping strip in Ginza has all the big brands of the fashion world and lots of places to eat and bars to down a drink or two. Gracery Hotel is a good stay option.

Shopping heaven. Not as crowded as some other more popular attractions like Shibuya & Omotesando, we came to Ginza purely for shopping & so we had everything we look for in here. The flagship store of Uniqlo, which satisfied everyone in our group (bring kids to 12th floor, they can spend hours with signature characters displays like Mickey, Captain America, Iron Man etc.). Nearby GU (a local brand, lower range than Uniqlo though come from same company), Zara, Shiseido, Adidas, LV, you name them & you can find here. Misukoshi itself has every cosmetics brands & many local clothes & groceries brands. Money exchange at Customer service counter of Misukoshi shopping mall.
Great Shopping. An excellent selection of shops from boutiques to major department stores. Not much English and research sizes before you go.

An amazing area and street!. Spend a week in the Ginza area and loved every minute of it! Great shops but definitely high end. If you don't want to spend $1500 on a purse I would recommend Uniqlo store....some good prices there. Go there on a weekend day and they turn the street into an amazing walking mall, a lot of fun!!!
Ok, very luxurious. Ginza was mainly because wife wanted to look at the Burberry Blue Label shop but as people said before, there was pretty much nothing to do apart from looking at Nightlife.

Beautiful architecture. We did not plan to go to this arrea, since we're no luxury shopping addicts, but accidentally came here in the evening and really enjoyed the beautifull buildings from Hermes, Dior, etc

Typical shopping area. We were told that Ginza was an amazing shopping precinct however there was nothing out of the ordinary; just the same type of shops as in many other large cities. The main difference is that there is nothing particularly attractive about this area - it's just purely functional. Staff in the shops are very polite however I found prices to be higher than in many other countries.

city lights. The Ginza is one of the great shopping districts of the world. A short walk will take you past most, if not all of the high end international retail brands. Even the building facades are part of the show with elaborate lighting and projected videos. Whether or not you are in the market for something expensive, the Ginza is worth a look, preferably after dark.

Shopping exclusive. Ginza is known as a shopping district of Tokyo. Lots of department stores with luxurious shops. So, if you are looking for something different from European shopping centers, this place is not for you.

Jaw dropping!!. Iv'e visit quite alot of shopping places in the World, but nothing, nothing is as good as ginza! Polite Staff in every shop, so many brands restaurants and ppl! I could not Love this place more! And no its not cheap

Endless shopping!. I went on a solo trip and stayed at the shangri la hotel which was close by. There were so many shops! I found a Granny Smith place! Everything is close together and all the high end shops are easy to find. Everyone was helpful pointing me in the right direction if I got turned around. They spoke great English and were very helpful. I have to go back because it was too many places to see in only two days!

Great for shopping. This is the centre of up-market shopping in Tokyo. All the designers have at least one outlet in Ginza. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants and easy access to the subway and trains to get around both Tokyo and the rest ogfJapan.

GOOD PLACE FOR HOTEL STAY AND GOOD ACCESS FROM HANEDA AIRPORT. Ginza is a great place to base yourself in Tokyo. Our first week in Japan we stayed here and visited places mainly on the west side of the city. When we came back to Tokyo for the last few days WE stayed in Shinjuku and visited places on the East side.However, we were not tempted in revisiting Ginza, it was just a nice area to come back to the end of the day (our hotel was away from the main streets).All the designer stores are here and there are some impressive looking buildings if that interests you.

Shoppers Paradise. The Ginza area caters for all budgets and it's a must if only for window shopping. Well worth a visit but please be warned you will be tempted to shop as the selection on offer is Amazing

Not what it used to be. I visited Ginza last month and was disappointed at how much it has changed from when I was there 10 years ago.It is still a great shopping place if that is what you are after but the Sony building (which used to be filled with robotics and lots of fun gadgets) is now just a 6 floor retail building and all the innovation and amazement has generally gone from the area. Its a shame as it was a truly great palce to visit back in the day.

Interesting and lively area. There are some attractive side streets in addition to the wider ones with the big department stores and they all are interesting to look around.It was nice on a Sunday when some of the streets were closed to traffic and the atmosphere changed from quite the crowded bustle of weekdays. There are lots of restaurants to chose from and if you can grab an outside seat at one of the few cafes on the main drag, it is great for people watching.
shopping craze. if you like shopping, then Ginza is your place to be - many shops and department stores offer something for everyone

The luxurious shopping Destination in Japan. almost every International brand vying each other to draw your attention. There was a huge beautiful building on the top of which SEIKO clock shows the time.I think this belongs to the leading watch maker SEIKO. There is the famous local brand UNIQLO and all popular items. Tokyo, being one of the most expensive cities, it is good for viewing the shops than shopping here. Always crowded with local as well as foreignersbusy looking for branded items.
Glamorous. Ginza is the upscale neighborhood of Tokyo.It's interesting to walk on the streets, watch the people, shop.
Very busy but nice. Very busy during the day, but is a very nice walk after supper, where you can window shop, their display is so nice, and the lights on the buildings and windows are so pretty

Just another massive mordern shopping area, certainly not on the must-visit list. Just like champs-elysee or oxford street. I guess it is convenient if you want to get all the items on your shopping list from one place.
Great shopping. Wonderful department stores and all the top stores. The streets are closed to traffic from noon on Saturdays giving the area a festive feel.

Expensive, overrated but central. Ginza is the area of Tokyo that most people have heard of. Tokyo is like a doughnut with the centre being the Emporers gardens and therefore has no public access or transport through it. Ginza is on the inner ring around that centre and has superb access to the amazingly efficient metro to get anywhere quickly. However, it's is full of luxury shops, high class bars hosting business men after work and is expensive real estate driving prices for rooms up.if your idea of fun is expensive restaurants ( we found nearby Shimbasi cheaper and more fun) and luxury brand goods then it's fine. It's strong point is as a venue to access everywhere else.

Higher class neighborhood . This is a higher class neighborhood and it is not as crowded as the other neighborhoods. Our hotel was in Ginza which was very convenient to go to the other neighborhoods by subway. Make sure to get the subway pass (3 days for 1500 yen).

Weekend pedestrian street. Ginza is Tokyo's most renowned high-brand shopping district, full of places to dine, green tea places (especially nice but popular in spring), and various other entertainment places and cafes. The department stores in this area were lots of fun to browse and nab a few photos of, especially since there was a Frozen and Disney exhibit going on on the top floor of one of the bigger buildings.I loved going to the top floor of the Uniqlo to buy some Uniqlo shirts for 990 - 1500 yen plus tax each, many of which contained Disney characters and other popular icons, but my favorite were the shirts that were in Swedish, Dutch, and Japanese. There was an excellent travel shop on the fifth floor of Itoya where I found some collapsible water bottles for 1200 yen, a wonderful tool for any traveler!Ginza's shopping isn't necessarily any better than other high-brand districts of the world, but it's an experience to see in Tokyo along with the Japanese who shop here; it's fairly ritzy. I loved seeing it, and I had a great time here. I definitely recommend it when it becomes a walk solely for pedestrians over the weekend when the road is closed to cars!

High End Tokyo. Ginza is FABULOUS! And I use that word with all its loaded implications. The best of designer fashion, art, food and nightlife, but with a hefty price tag. If you're looking for bargains, this is not your neck of the woods. It's Tokyo's 5th Ave and Rodeo Drive. When you're looking to splurge, head over to Ginza! And make sure you go to Bar High Five. They'll make you your own original cocktail!

You'll find the best merchandise here.. Ginza is Ginza, sort of like 5th ave and Rodeo Drive. You will find the best pearls, the best handbags, outfits, shoes and whatever you are looking for, oh, yes, electronics also. Restaurants everywhere. But they do close earlier than our stores in the US.

World class shopping. Like any fine shopping street the world over, Ginza is represented with all the major brands and designer products and is heaving with both tourists and locals alike. Got off at Shiodome station and walked. Some of the shops are fitted out so beautifully- personally I loved the Uniqlo building. Side streets also lovely with the architecturally amazing De Beers building. Even if you're no shopper, you can still enjoy a few hours here. Can be very busy

Shopping paradise. The Ginza is famous for shopping and has all the name brands associated with luxury items. I merely strolled the main Ginza-Dori avenue. I suspect the prices for luxury goods are higher than in the west than in Japan. Locals mentioned that discount stores are coming up as the economy is cooling. There are many upscale restaurants to experience too. My budget was too low for me to experience but Ginza is a great window shopping event and crime is non-existent as in most of Japan. There is no necessity to worry about touts, scamsters, pick pockets as in other parts of the world. Petty crime seemed rare here and very secure.

Don't miss Ginza. We have visited Tokyo more than five times however had not been to Ginza. The suggestion of the business district did not lure us until now. The streets are lovely and wide and everything is so well presented. Even if the shops are out of your price range there is plenty to see just window shopping. Enjoy.
nice lights. Nice lights.Shops are like anywhere else. Pricey. There are good restaurants around, that were not too expensive.

A world class shopping for the high end.. This is just the place for a variety of brands with it's unique buildings, so attractive in both day and night. Staff are friendly and helpful for your shopping needs. A variety of restaurants available along the main streets as well as in malls.

Long shopping street . Main road is all about international branded goods. This is not what I like as it is the same in every cityBut I do enjoy walking into small alley where I could find some local product. There are some art gallery too!

Upscale department stores,boutiques,restaurants. Numerous stores,coffeehouses and eateries.timescale of visit is usually short unless one is keen on shopping.Historical Imperial palace is not far and is at an walkable distance.

Must visit in Tokyo. nice area for shopping and dinning. most people around here dress so nicely. even the coffee shops are excellent. the shop range is from the luxury brand to local boutique. really a must visit place if you are in Tokyo.

Visit during week-end pedestrian street. Tokyo's most famous upmarket shopping, dining and entertainment district, featuring numerous department stores, boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, night clubs and cafes.

Unique stores. Ginza is full of high end boutiques where you can find their exclusive Tokyo collections. If you are after an unique piece you will find it here. Moon phase is the must for men exclusive watches. There is also a toys shop for the little one at the end toward Shibashi. The services here will make you feel most welcome and pleasant.

Upscale shopping district. This is the place to be if you have cash to burn, all the international & Japanese luxury brands and stores you can find, and can shop till you drop literally. Very crowded during the weekends and some streets, don't know the names are car free for the weekend too.
For The Gardener At Heart. Ginza is not only for shoppers but for the garden lovers as well. The historical Imperial Palace and Hama Rikyu gardens are in this area.
Place for fancy fashion. It's a suitable place for shopping lover with high quality and high-end. It's still enjoyable for window-shopping.
Awesome shopping (for branded stuff esp). You can walk and walk and walk and not feel tired of shopping. All top brands are available. With sufficient credit in hand, shopping is like a rainbow

What I imagine the future looks like. We went to Ginza in the evening and feel in love with the neighborhood. It was so modern and clean with so many things to look at that it easy to interrupt the flow of traffic.

Ginza . If you love to shop high-end, this is the place to go. I did enjoy taking in the sights but did not enjoy the shopping. There is a wonderful toy store right at the entrance where the children enjoyed but it was also very pricey. And to think of lugging all those big box toys on the airplane was fretful. There are many places to eat but they're also high-end and pricey there are not any places quite suitable for the little ones. We did find a beer hall which the food was enjoyable, but oily. It was a historic beer hall though !We did take in a fantastic foot massage over at Queens day. That was right at the entrance of Ginza.That was wonderful considering our feet retired after a week of walking around Tokyo.Ginza is a thief he must visit but I would not make a day of it. Particularly with little ones .

Ginza pack your credit card & camera. Never seen so many high end shops all in one place in this case a whole suburb. Every single brand named product is available.Whether it's competitively price as compared to home or not you will find something that isn't stocked in your home country or is available in Japan first and you want to be the first to have it, then this is your place.Whether you shop or sightseeing, we did a bit of both but more sightseeing and left in awe of the amount of high end goods on offer.The buildings are amazing as well, back home the shopfront is important or the main windows in the big department stores but here in Ginza it's literally the whole building is decorated in the brands colours / name or every window on a three or four or six storey building will display the companies products.During the day is one view then at night all the signs are lit up and all the display windows are lit up no matter how many storeys high the building is, great photos if you have a tripod for your camera.
Expensive and Glitzy. Always worth a look at how some of the expensive brands do their marketing. Good for a walk and maybe only window shopping.

Great for mid to high end shopping. There are the usual top of the range boutiques as well as huge departmental stores carrying stupendous range of international and local brands. However, if you're not into the high end stuff, a Ginza is still fun for a stroll for sight seeing and people watching. There is also a Uniqlo flagship store, 10 stories! And there's also Itoya's flagship store selling really nice stationery (and other goods). There's a whole floor dedicated to 'fine paper' and believe me, you can get them in any colour your heart desires! Oh and we also managed to find reasonably priced yukatas (just under ¥3000) at Mitsukoshi and a baby and kids' shop right next to it after searching for them at various places.
Perfect place!. If you are looking for a place to shop, eat and have some fun, you should go to Ginza. The luxury brands and many beautiful restaurants are there.

Ginza by Day & Night. Our stay at the Ginza Mitsui Garden Premier Hotel meant close proximity to Tokyo's Glamour Shopping strip.Apart from losing yourself between Louis Vuitton & UNIQLO . . my tip is to get off the crowded Main Drag and smash the back Streets / Lanes . . the smaller independent stores are much more exciting and the walk a lot more interesting and pleasant . . full of wonderful Restaurants Cafes and Window Shopping. This is how you find Cafes like Miyakoshiya Coffee Ginza . . It became a daily visit as the Coffee is that good!Nev

Shop until you drop here. Most shops open at 11am and stay open late. At weekends part of Ginza becomes a mall. We found the side and smaller back streets most interesting as the main mall has all the usual designer label suspects.Queues for some of the designer brand stores can start at about 10:30am.A colourful and vibrant shopping area, worth a visit if visiting Tokyo.
Shopping Paradise. You like design and good quality and rather expensive price, still good value for money.. Ginza is the place. If you like some Japanse culture, visit the Kabuki theatre

Lots of famous shops on a street. Ginza is Tokyo's most famous upmarket shopping, dining and entertainment district, featuring numerous department stores and numerous world known fashion brands. Worth to spend half a day in Ginza to feel the vibrant side of Tokyo
Shopping Spree. Crowded with people. Not suitable family with small kids. Too many people walking along the streets could make you feel dizzy.
