Glitzy Shopping but neither aww inspiring nor that interesting anymore. It used to be a real experience, now it's a nice shopping district, that is easy to walk around in and has a nice underground area but honestly it's no longer a highlight.
Not what I expected. Great if you love shopping. I hate shopping. When you're told it's the old area, they mean it has been surpassed by Shibuya. Soulless.
better shopping. I love how Ginza is set-up easier to move around compared to Shibuya or Shinjuku. However, if you aim cheap shopping, this isn't the right place.

shopping district with large Uniqlo store. For shopping lovers, this district has many brand name shop. For not expensive cloth, there is 12th floor Uniqlo branch there. May be largest Uniqlo in the world!

Great area ! Would stay here again. Ginza is full of upscale boutiques but also has plenty of other stores. It is nice to walk around, many restaurants, and it is close to the fish market. Getting from Narita to Ginza it is best to take the train, as taxis are usd 300 or more. At the station in tokyo center take a cab to Ginza and you will be there in 10-20 minutes depending on traffic. To Haneda take a taxi is convenient, not cheap around usd 60, but it gets you faster.

Good place to shopping. In this place you could see a line of branded store along the street
You could say this is the new york of tokyo or Sudirman of Jakarta!
And in this area also the Tsukiji Market located (i only went here for the Tsukiji)
Have fun in this place!
Nice street to walk. Nice street for walking. A lot of shopping.Very central and nice restaurants to eat.We went in the morning and at night.

Must go in Tokyo. If you go to Tokyo, you must go to Ginza. You can go to Ginza to have afternoon tea in a nice place, to go to the department stores in Ginza, or just have a walk down the street to feel Tokyo. Ginza is the characteristic of Tokyo. There are some tearooms in Ginza that I suggest: Henri Charpentier, Shiseido, Ladurée.

Many brand name shops. It is nice to see it (both day and night), however it is just a high end shopping area with many brand names. Many do not really have good deals, i.e. Watch. The authorized dealers in Toronto offer better prices even with HST....

If you have loads of cash and love to shop.... This is a great area to shop. High end designers and department stores, and great people watching. You could easily spend a few days wandering in and out of boutiques, and enjoying the basement food courts of the department stores. A shopper's dream!
This is a place to see. Ginza is a "must see" part of Tokyo. It is noisier than other areas in Tokyo but that is part of the fun.

Great area to stay in. We stayed in Ginza during our time in Tokyo. It was great because it was close to metro stops, shopping and restaurants as well as the fish market. It was a great base to explore many different areas of Tokyo.

Awesome. Breathtaking. You definitely need a whole day at least to explore here. The Kabukiya theatre is an experience and Tokyu plaza is amazing, the $25 we spent on a hot chocolate and chocolate rose tea were worth every cent.

Shopping in Tokyo. Very well laid out. It is mainly a shopping area though Tokyo has other such shopping areas also. It has all range of stores- from the high end designer stores to the average priced ones. The subway station is right there so very easily accessible.

Loved it!. Ginza is such a fun and vibrant part of the city. It's likely your trip will take you here, be it for the amazing shopping, its delicious restaurants or just to soak up the atmosphere. Really fun place.

A cool place feeling less spectular than it used to. The Ginza area and it's main street is full of people, shops and restuarants. Doesn't feel that different as it used to coming here. A combination of the rest of the world catching up and maybe a bit of stagnation here. Worth to stop by if you are in the area but I wouldn't travel to get here
Love Ginza. A great place to hangout with my girls, lovely restaurants, I bought a few fashion bags. Products from Japan are top quality. You can find it anywhere in Ginza.
A Tokyo Must. The Ginza is the best place to wander along with all the shops , bars , restaurants and entertainments options in Tokyo

Great shopping and decent restaurants . Ginza is more for shoppers than tourists. It has great stores and restaurants but offers nothing else. If you go do visit the mitsukoshi store and the stationary shop ITOYA.

The 5th Avenue of Tokyo. The flashy, Fashion district of Tokyo. Apart from spotting all the major luxury brands you know (and even many you don't!), walking around in Ginza gives one a peak into local Fashion through just people-watching Tokyoites going about their day!

Alive & abuzz. Ginza is a fun place both above and below ground, during the day and at night. During the day you can find a wealth of shopping at high end name brand stores. At night you can enjoy a meal at many of the places off the main road and often on a lower level. While visiting in March the Kabuki theater had a performonce and an adjacent mall had a wonderful Cherry Blossom Fest. So Ginza is more than just glitz, shopping, and eating.
Wow. In past had heard about Ginza but saw it first time. Its an amazing place, busy and bustling with activities.

Fun Place. Checked out Ginza for a day, on the weekend when they close the streets off. The variety of upmarket stores and the general vibe makes this a fun place to hang out and wander around. Most stuff is expensive and there a variety of eateries,but if you are just taking in the atmosphere and wander though some of the back streets it makes it a fun day out. Night time it comes alive with a variety of lights and colors. Worth checking out.

Japan's fashion district. Only in Ginza can you find branded items such as clothes, shoes, jewelry, bags and many more all in one place. Women would love this place. Oh and did i mention that brands have their own buildings?
High brand store only. Like a lot of these. This is just an overpriced shopping centre. There wasn't any thing new or unique to see. Walked in and walked back

Shopping areas with rude Japanese staff. A lot of shops to shop, quite a number of restaurants to choose but suggest to eat earlier since there are lots of tourists gathering in Ginza.
Maybe the Japanese are sick of tourists, they are very rude to the tourists unlike usual Japanese.

Ginza- Here's a List of Department Stores and Restaurants in Tokyo's Crown Jewel. The Ginza (銀座) is Tokyo's crown jewel in terms of shopping, dining and entertainment, featuring numerous department stores, boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, night clubs and cafes. Before I go on:If you want to spend some major yen and you are a FOREIGNER, PLEASE BRING YOUR PASSPORT! YES, BRING YOUR PASSPORT! You will get TAX-FREE SHOPPING at most of the big stores listed below. So, HAPPY SHOPPING!!! As for restaurants, some are pricey, but the quality justifies the price. Nevertheless, don't go overboard. Spend within your means. Have a great time!TIP- Each Saturday and Sunday, from 12:00 noon until 5:00 pm, the main street through Ginza is closed traffic. This is called Hokōsha Tengoku (歩行者天国?) or Hokoten for short, literally meaning "pedestrian heaven". I love this. NO cars. No people blocking your way. You can stop, enjoy the scenery and take pictures without blocking other people. VERY NICE!Here is a brief list of stores you can find in this district. You will recognize some names with international reputations and learn some names that are famous only in Japan. I recommend a sampling of each. I enjoy the Japanese department stores the most- you get a view into what Japanese people like and get a sampling of their very high expectations from clothing to household items to food items (vegetables, fruits, meats). AdidasAlfred DunhillApple ArmaniBarney's New YorkBIC Camera- best electronic store you will ever find! Usually 5 to 8 floors of computers, games, movies, household electronics, toys, hair dryers, you name it. Basically everything electronicBrooks Brother BurberryBvlgari JewelryCartier JewelryChanelChaumetCoachDiorDover StreetFanci - Excellent cosmetic company specializing in skin creams and liquid supplements to restore youthFurlaShisheidoGucciHermesItoyaLouis VuittonMatsuyaMatsuzakayaMitsukoshi Dept. store- MUST SEE especially the basement which is Super Deluxe grocery store!Mont BlancMujiSoftbankPradaSalvatore FerragamoSamantha TiarreSeibu Department storeSonyTiffany JewelryUNIQLO department storeVan Cleefs and ArpelsYoshinoyaZara JewelryAnd a brief list of Restaurants and their numbers (ONLY for GINZA)See my reviews for some of these restaurants.NOTE: There are a lot of excellent restaurants outside of GINZA, but still in Tokyo. - SEE MY REVIEWS. Thanks.TIP: you can call to make reservations yourself or have your hotel concierge call them to make a reservation. I usually email the hotel concierge months ahead of time to make my reservations. Some are EXTREMELY tough to procure. So, enjoy. IF you want to sample ramen , go to RAMEN STREET in Tokyo or RAMEN MUSEUM in Yokohama (yes, not just a museum, but also contains about 20 ramen restaurants, each serving their own flavored ramen.) Yakiniku (grilled meat)Ushiya Ginbe (牛屋 銀兵衛)- 050-5868-8655 Ginza Shoutaien (銀座 正泰苑)- 03-6274-5003Rose Bakery- light, healthy food that is neither raw nor fried,nice selection of salads, quiches, vegetables, and other deli-style dishesBASEMENTS of Dept. stores like Mitsukoshi - Feast your eyes. So much beautiful and delicious food choices! Most of them are cooked and ready to eat. Also lots of stuff you can buy that are ready for travel (candies, small cakes,etc).Special Mentions- MUST TRY IF YOU CAN GET IT. NOTE: Can be $$$. Ginza Okamoto- CrabParis Yugao- French cuisine and KOBE BEEF Sukiyabashi Jiro- SushiSushi Saito- SushiYoshitake- SushiKappo-Ajoika- PUFFER FISH- DEADLY if prepared incorrectlyAshoka- Indian foodOshima- Great food, Waitresses dressed in KimonosRangetsu- Wagyu Beef,Crab, Japanese CuisineSake No Ana- Over 130 Sake with a Sake sommelier on handHave fun!!! You will not be able to check out all the places with one visit. So you will need to come back as I have.
Good place for shopping. Not cheap but you can get value for money ya. Steet food in Ginza is delicious. I think you should buy souvenir here.
Heavenly corer for shop lovers. not only Ginza gave you shops, the architecture are also awesome. Most brands are available here, Japanese and International brand.

Great shopping. The best time, to me, to visit Ginza is on the weekends when they close down the road and Ginza turns into a huge shopping strip filled with locals and visitors. It's a nice place to spend the day shopping and eating as there are lots of shops for everyone and many eating places for every budget.

Great Stay in Ginza. Very happy with our stay in Ginza - we had great access to 3 different subway lines and it was easy to get around Tokyo. Amazing shopping but also lots of convenience stores for snacks and essentials nearby.
Crowded . Was here at last night for dinner. Very crowded with tourists. Very little Japanese want to come here any more. Things are still expensive and beautiful. But the atmosphere is no more.

Ginza-shopping /tour site options . Ginza district is sometimes misconstrued as an area of only expensive boutique stores.Aside from the name brand stores,there are also other stores that are reasonably priced like the Mitsokoshi and Matsuya Department stores( openvat 11am-8pm) and Uniqlo(12floors),GU store,H&M, to name a few!!You can also see the Giant Clock of Ginza that rings every hour.There is the Kabukizi Theater and along the same direction,the Tzukiji market..if you are unable to watch the famous early morning fish bidding in Tzukiji Market,this is the best place to try out the freshest seafoods in Tokyo!!

Be careful when the Chinese New Year is on. I strolled or more like trekked in this famous Ginza Strip. I stopped on the way back to the Vegas through L.A. after my brother in law's first memorial service. After checked out the hotel and left the bags till 8:20 pm or so, nearby went Tsukiji Fish market, and bought only in Japan products(we pay some of the daily use consumable products at approx. 4 time of Tokyo) at discount stores,I knew I will run into the crowd by the Chinese New Year, but it was bulls eye. Anywhere I went, the bus loads of them are. I wanted a bottle of supplement at the drug store but it turned out to be a 20 minutes challenge to find the store clerk. I grew up in Tokyo but this never happened till 5 years ago.Their habit of shopping is called "Bakugai" or impulsive shopping.It used to be a rice cooker, then the automatic toilet seat(wash and dry your bottom - used by many Hollywood celebs), shifted to cosmetics, meds. -many occasions their friends and relatives money to buy those bring back for them or pitch in and buy a lot then later sold them for profit, the proceeds are shared).It is Tokyo, so the cup of coffee at the Dotor Coffee ( inexpensive coffee house in Japan) costed some like US$4.

Fantastic shopping and sightseeing. The Ginza district is by far the best destination for first time travellers and those with limited time.The shopping is amazing, the service is even better.There is something for everyone from the fantastic restaurants, imperial palace and famous fish market.
Shop till you drop. Its in Ginza that all the high end luxury brands have their stores. Its a busy area swarming with tourists.

Tokyos fifth Avenue . Beautifull by day, amazing by night.
Full of shops and restaurants for all tastes and budgets.
Everything is super clean and well maintained.
It's worth the visit

For shopping lovers. Of course there are many international brands with their flagship stores, great architecture, unique fronts in their shops and interior. Not to mention the clean, absolutely beautiful design and harmony. But wait, there are standard and cheap shops also, not everything is expensive in Ginza! Great mix when going with kids. Quit, easy to walk and enjoy from store to store, the cafes, the restaurants, everything is beatiful.

Designer shopping. If you have a black credit card and like brands like Versace, Barney's NY etc you will enjoy Ginza. We walked from Shimbashi to Tokyo station and liked the walk but not the shop prices.

Why Ginza ?. Shopping in Ginza is no different to shopping in the other capital cities. All the well known brands are there. Have a look to see and to say that you have been there (on the way to the fish market - which is more interesting). Prefer to shop at smaller shops in the side streets. More interesting "Japanese" items. LV/ Prada can buy anywhere in the world but buying something special from Japan is unique

Ginza Shopping District. You have to go and see to believe. Ginza will be luxury shopping district for Tokyo. You will see LV, Prada, D and G, Sony and all other luxury brands out there.But whats shocking is not that you will see all the luxury brands. But, I will say that the most shocking thing is that Ginza is really clean.One more thing, ignore chinese, they look that they just escaped from jungle.
Best shopping!. You probably have visited here if you are in Tokyo just due to the location, but if you haven't for some reason, do. It's the best shopping in Tokyo.

Best shipping street in Tokyo. If you want to visit the best shopping street in Tokyo, this is where you should go. There are also many other nice areas, but you can find both the products of top brands from various countries, and popular and reasonable products, such as UNIQLO, MUJI or H&M. Of course, you can find good department stores where you can buy anything you want, and also big retail stores of home appliances. There are also good restaurants and drinking places. You can spend ad many hours ad you want in Ginza, if you are shopping lover.

Shopping Super Street. This is a remarkable place. Massive numbers of shops. Everything you could want is available. i went to the 7 floor department store for stationary. It sold items I didn't know existed. There is also a great array of eating places. You need a visit to grasp the character of Tokyo as a shopping capital.
luxe. This area is the area for shopping with a good credit card! All the luxury shops are around, a lot of medium range also

Has almost everything you need. Me and my wife had a great time in Ginza. She is a Japan lover, and had found most of everything she was looking for here!
From food to clothing there is a great choice of quality stuff!

Endless shopping. Busy busy busy. Lots and lots of shops, cheap to boutique and all age groups. Classical Japanese Department stores with amazing clothing, foodhalls etc! Get a map. Easy train access but walk a lot. Lots to eat.
luxry city. Ginza is a great quite are that has brand stores and great places to visit like tsukiji fish market and great spots for photos

Ginza - the real neighbourhood. You can not come to Tokyo and miss out on ginza, food + people watching
The food is the main draw
Ginza is a large area and it takes a lot of time to really explore it and I only scratched the surface and looking forward to come back

Shopping to dropping. If you like shops then Ginza is the place for you. There is no shortage of choice. Our inside tip is to visit the food halls in Mitsukoshi department store (Basement 2 and Basement 3) which are amazing.

Expensive Tokyo Real Estate. Ginza is an area in Tokyo known for exclusive shopping, restaurants and entertainment. It is one of the the highest priced areas of property in Tokyo. It is worth checking out.

shopping and eating paradise. many malls and restaurant around this place, you can shop till you drop in here, shopping, eating, shopping and eating again. there lots of delicious cake and also snack around ginza, should come to visit this place

High class area of Tokyo ... try out catching a show at the Kabukiza Theater if here!!. High class area of Tokyo ... try out catching a show at the Kabukiza Theater if here!!
The Sanrio Hello Kitty Megastore is also in this district.

The Oxford Street of Japan. Comparing London with Japan (as I lived in the UK before), Ginza is pretty similar with Oxford Street with a lot of tall buildings and premium fashion brands along the street! I love to shop here even though it's quiet packed with people on weekend. Real Tokyo feeling!

High Class Shopping area. Ginza is a high class shopping and entertainment area, top grades and top prices,
many first class shops, and luxurious bars, the most expensive part of Tokyo.

Shops!!. Large shopping area near the centre of Tokyo. Many big name stores and big prices to match. If window shopping is your thing you will be in heaven here but leave the credit card at home if you have to ask the price!

Wow! Some of the buildings are astonishing!. I'm not a shopper on any level, but went to Ginza and walked down the main street on a Sunday and the road is closed due to high pedestrian traffic. Walked into a few of the shops and they were amazing, the money put into the shops/buildings is something to be in awe of. Highly recommend a slow walk through.

Love this district. The Ginza is great for people watching and luxury car watching :)
The shopping is world class and there are some really nice french cafes with amazing pastries in the Ginza.

New York of Asia . I stayed in Ginza since the offices of my clients are within the area. But I was caught by surprise on how amazing this place is. this place greatly remind me of 5th Avenue in new York. The shops, the lights, and the fashion is so modern. The place is also expensive so you have to watch for the prices tags.

Luxury Shopping Area. I think it's a well known place and very popular among the travelers. A modern city with lots of brand outlets for your shopping pleasures. To enjoy the city... you don't mine to spend your money for expensive and luxury items. Heaven for rich people you see! If you travel by train, you can visit the entire city of Tokyo conveniently. I couldn't say more, I dropped a few photos for your viewing pleasures. Enjoy!

Check out the most expensive piece of land in Tokyo (and Japan)!. Ginza is known for the extravagant shopping centre and traditional department stores. You will see a ton of tourists and japanese people dressed up in expensive clothes. But check out the Ginza Yoncho-me　銀座4丁目 where the land costs 33.800.000yen (which is equivalent to 338.000 dollars) per square meter.

Sushi in Ginza. You can find more than 200 Sushi place in Ginza those are from JPY3,000. to JPY50,000. depend on where to go. If you want real good one you can try Kyubei which is one of the place where you want to go. Average price par parson may be JPY20,000.+ but very good. Other place will be Karaku the chef is very good at wine and he serves sushi marriage. Average price par parson may be JPY20,000.+ but worth try.
Nice Shopping Street. Ginza is full of high end boutiques shop with all the High brand on their nice buildings.There are lots of good restaurants as well with excellent food

Fantastic shopping!. We spent a lot of time in this area. There were great shops and wonderful restaurants. The basements of the major department stores had amazing food halls! The main streets are wide and elegant but don't miss some of the smaller streets that had heaps of character.

Cool Place to check out shops, especially at night. Ginza, is simply an upmarket shopping strip. It is considered the luxury shopping district of Tokyo, but the prices don't seem to be drastically different to elsewhere in the city. Yes, there are more upmarket brands, but unlike Rodeo Dr, money isn't everything to enjoy this area. There is a wide range of food on offer here and something to eat isn't hard to come by. The area is worth visiting if in Japan and has a lot of shops to offer. It is worth checking out the UNIQLO, the flagship store.

Great for shopping and surprisingly good nightlife!. Ginza is a great place to shop, eat and experience the more glamorous side of Tokyo. The nightlife is also surprisingly good. Bar300 in Ginza is our favourite spot for late evenings. This little underground basement gets really lively late at night, they also provide a number of free drinks upon paying the entry fee.

A must visit!. This famous Tokyo upscale shopping district is certainly a must-visit !We stayed 3 nights in Ginza , and every evening, we strolled around the main street of Ginza to shop and dine.The branded store are all here: Dior, Gucci, Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Burberry, Fendi, Furla, Coach, etc. you can also find Apple Store, Uniqlo (flagship store), Laox (5-floor cosmetic and watch store), Matsuya and Mitsukoshi (department store), Itoya (stationery), etc. There are way too many to mention!Dont worry about the foodies. there are lots of ramen, katsu rice, or teppanyaki shops. the popular Yoshinoya is also here. Coffee shops like Starbucks and other brands are also available.
Rings at the checkouts. Great place to spend and spend! Be sure to visit the toy park (located beside Burberry), the world's largest uniqlo flagship store and Muji cafe. Cash and cards accepted!!
Metropol shopping. The area looks like any other top shopping district in the metropols of the World.Very fancy but a little bit boring if you don't shop.

Shop until your wallet drops. Great place to window shop and if your adventurous can find some really great places to eat in the basement of shopping malls and office buildings. The quality and class of shopping is 5 star. Avoid the duty free shops when there are bus loads of tourists! Slip dow the side streets and find small ramen houses and other delights

Best in Tokyo for shopping and dining but be prepared to spend. I find myself here every time I visit Tokyo, which is 4-5x a year, not only for the shopping, but also because it probably has the most agglomeration of top-quality Japanese restaurants, whether Michelin-starred or highly-rated on Tripadvisor. To be sure, check out Google map before heading to these restaurants as they are usually difficult to find and even the locals likely not be able to help you. I've found Google satellite to be very useful as it would show me landmark buildings that I am already familiar and I use those as starting points. I invariably check out sales of pre-loved luxury items on Komehyo and Brand Off. If you're into all sorts of inexpensive trinkets and gadgets, there's a huge Don Quijote store beside Mitsui Garden Ginza Premier. For dessert, I always stop by Manneken near the Giorgio Armani building or, if I have more time, I have coffee at Laduree in the Mitsukoshi building, watching people on the Ginza crossing. For more authentic and inexpensive sushi, you can walk two blocks to Tsukiji and from that corner, alone, there are probably at least three Sushizanmai stores, one of the most popular among Tokyoites.

Ordinary . This district might be revered for its shopping, but it is bit much different than what one sees on a similar stretch in any nah r city in the world. The same names pop up everywhere, including here in Tokyo, with only a few minor differences. Better to hit the back streets and enjoy what little is unique there.
Not a boy thing.... It is a high class shopping street just like all the other ones you ghave been to. None of the shops are unique in any way

Lots of Restaurants. Ginza is our first wonderful stop on our 9 Dec 2015 holiday trip. It is as beautiful as Orchard Road in Singapore, and more flat out into grids. We didn't do much shopping though as the items are more luxurious. The streets do also have lots of restaurants, interesting experience for us as we went hunting for famous food joints. Be prepared to do lots of walking. All kinds of fascinating eating places are there, including hole-in-one noodle bars that had long queue out in the cold night.
Worth a look.. If you like all the high end brands this will be your paradise. Great place to spend a couple of hours dreaming.Very intetesting.
Ginza is wonderful.. Ginza is as beautiful as Fifth avenue in New York. The shopping is awesome. The streets are wide avenues and surprisingly uncrowned.

luxury avenue. all famous brands goods. all kind of a lifestyle necessities, from coffee house to electronic gadgets, musical instruments, fashion.... people wondering around this area must be splur and in stylist. I bought an Yamaha keyboard there, feel great

Premium Experience. Ginza is one of my must visit place in Tokyo... It has all high end mega stores, fascinating eating joints, great hotels.
It is also one of the best place to stay in Tokyo especially if you want to stay in central Tokyo....

Shopping haven. This is the 5th Avenue of Tokyo, with even Barney's of NY setting up shop for good measure. Some of the roads are closed to traffic on weekends, making the shopping experience even better. Shops range from Gap to Berluti, so you can find everything here. They are also nice restaurants, cafés and food shops for variety. Also small art galleries

Shopping Heaven. Big name brands to local high-end to your budget-friendly brands, you can spend maybe 2 full days exploring Ginza and the side streets. My favorite places: Itoya (8 floors in the main store) and the Uniqlo flagship store (11 floors!). You might want to do some more research through the other reviews for specific stores so you can plan your shopping and dining trip properly. Accessible via two subway stations, Ginza and Higashi-Ginza.

The center of tokyo trade. It's a city area able to attract people from all over the world. Department stores, traditional shops, small fashion galleries, elegant showroom...huge Sony building! Exciting and all people are busy.

You can see expensive stores in any city in the world do not waste your time. Sorry to say my wife said it would be a waste of time but I just had to say I was there. She had it exactly right. Nothing different than 5th Ave NYC, Rodeo Dive Hollywood, or any of the 1000's of other high priced streets and stores.I snapped a couple pictures, walked a few blocks and then we headed back to the subway to more interesting things to do in the great city of Tokyo.

Magic at night, great buildings. Normally all Tokyo goes into a magical state at night and Ginza is not an exception. Elegant and trendy. Great architecture, great stores and restaurants. Best area to stay. Tokyo is perfectly connected so you can get anywhere from here.

Must Go! Haven't been to Ginza you have not shopped in Japan. Ginza is a east meets wests shopping hub where you will be able to find the European luxury brands Chanel, Prada, Gucci, MCM and many more. Go for Japanese international brands how about shiseido, Uniqlo there were a big store in Ginza. If you are into fashion and like to explore, learning 2016 Spring style, the colours, the trend, not difficult to find some designer products ONLY available in Japan. They may not necessary be expensive. My special recommendation this trip for Ginza. The Shiseido building. If you think shiseido only sell cosmetics that was wrong. Opposite to the big cosmetic shops. There was a beautiful shiseido pastry shop, there were biscuits, chocolates, take away coffee, Shiseido restaurant instant curry, princess jelly drinks for ¥375. Grabbed some souvenirs for my friends. Within Shiseido Parlour has 10 stories of restaurants. We try the Italian restaurant on the 10/F , Faro with elegant decorations and good food, a set lunch around USD30 with 4 courses meal great value. Will try other floors next time when we return. There were 2 department stores in Ginza Matsuya and Mitsukoshi. Where you can get tax refund straight away after shopping. With depreciation of ¥ Tokyo definitely a good place to shop and eat !!

Great area for Food and Drink. Fantastic for shopping, eating and drinking. Amazing little bars and friendly people everywhere. plenty of variety if you're looking for the nicer things in life. don't be scared to check out some random little bars and eateries - they are usually the most satisfying!

Stunning High End Shopping. Ginza is a delight full of wonderful luxury stores plus many high street brands as well.
Check out the back streets which are full of bars and excellent eateries.
Great walking. I'm convinced no one really goes to the Ginza to shop - it's all about walking, people watching and taking in the fabulous Tokyo culture.

Shopping Must!!!. If you have found yourself in Tokyo, you have certainly heard of The Ginza. This is where you go to do your shopping while in Japan. Many of the stores are high-end and expensive but there are good deals to be found with little effort.

I Got Lost!. There is so much hustle an bustle in Tokyo, it is easy to get lost; especially in Ginza. Not that I didn't know where I was going but you can easily continue walking right through it not knowing that you already passed it. Neat and fun, it is a cool place to people watch and of course.

Fabulous street. Never saw so many fabulous shops, food and people in one street! Beats Rodeo Drive! The department t store is brilliant and the food section is even better than Harrod's food stalls ( if that is at all possible)

Fashion and everything in between. Ginza has something for everyone. A high end luxury fashion district with the usual labels and luxury stored and then scratch the surface to find some gems in the big department stores. Wonder off the main road into the side streets and shops that are uniquely Japanese can be found. Itoya is on the main road through Ginza and is an awesome paper and store, but more than Paper, 8 stories of paper, stationary, pens, pencils, travel goods, a must see and shows that Japanese know how to retail.

High end shopping at it world class best!. Everything is here - from a guys perspective I would not have wanted to be here with a woman but would have most likely left her to her own devices and met up with her later because e I am fairly certain a woman could spend 4 days here. Neat to see and window shop, very easy to get to from the subway.
Uniqlo store. Must visit their Uniqlo store, the biggest in the world! Twelve floors of pure clothing here and there!!! Good choices and cheaper rates than back home!

The Mayfair of Tokyo. If you like expensive goods, top restaurants, oodles of shops and department stores then there is probably nowhere as good as Ginza when in Tokyo. You can spend a whole day exploring this area and enjoying what it has to offer. My favourite department store was the Mitsukashi department store.

important and expensive shopping area!. The shopping here is verry expensive. You find all important brands in one street. I miss the normal shops for the average people here. It is nice to see what the sell here.

Neon lights and shopping. I went to Ginza by accident, but I am glad I did. The mix of shops and brands is great. Even the Uniqlo store is something special in this neighbourhood and it is close to the Metrostation or just walk a little bit further to the JR line.

Ginza, the 5th Avenue of Tokyo. I'm not a shopper, but you cant help but enjoy the vibrancy of the Ginza district. Every brand shop on the main drag but my advice is to get off the main drag and walk around the quieter side streets that have fantastic restaurants and the non-main stream shops.Big wide pavements meant walking around the Ginza area less stressful that it could have been

Safe and Expensive. Holy crap... every high end designer store is here and you can drop thousands without even thinking. Bought a simple silk scarf from Escada for the wife and that was 45000 yen. (do the math). You want a Breitling watch? Gucci slippers? Chanel # anything? Designers you've never heard of but prices start at 450,000 yen and up? Go to this high end shopping district. Make sure you pack your black amex.

You will not be disappointed but maybe the wallet might go lighter. This is your top of the range shopping and restaurant in tokyoOxford street of london and chams elleysse of parisIt's has all brand names and more and if you looking for something you will find it on that laneAnd the whole area including the inner lanes are worth going to
Bus Tour. I can't much because we were touring the Ginza on Tour Bus, but all the same, it was an experience seeing the Ginza with all her Shops!

High-end Boutiques and shops! . Was here in january. Most of the retailers were having crazy sale. Uniqlo - 12 stories! Walking distance to tsukiji. This area , just like any other is very clean and safe! Couple of halal food in this area.
Cute shopping in side streets. Main street is a must-see for Tokyo experience. It is very beautiful, also for window shopping. Side streets are better with smaller local shops.

Up-market area with interesting back streets. The main street is nice but stores like Chanel, Hermes, etc. that you can find anywhere in the worlds -- but the back streets are very nice, also down towards Tsukiji fish market especially Miyuki Avenue.

Such a cool area! . We booked a hotel in this area not really knowing what the area was like! We were so happy with the area , quiet at night, mainly a shopping area we found. Very safe, very pretty, very posh! Try the Mercure hotel - cheap and nice!

Expensive but much to see. This area is a shopping district, obviously. There are nice little ramen shops tucked away between the huge buildings. I would go here to see the 7 floor Uniqlo by itself...

Make it on a Sunday if you can. Ginza is a fabulous upmarket street to walk around at any time, but if you go on a Sunday the main section of it is closed to traffic. There are many al fresco dining areas at this time and a variety of street artists. Alternatively, go in the evening when the lights make it even more attractive than day time. Many interesting stores to look around and/or shop at.
Upscale shopping area. Nice place to hang out. There were some good places to eat here as well. Its a nice place to spend sometime

Great place to explore and window shop. Real shopping if your wallet can afford it... Prada, Louis Vuitton, Bvlgari, and more. Tokyo's premier department store and Paris' isn't too far either. Fun to wander. Even the Sony store was fun (and I'm not a gadget gal).

Ginza is a must for all that come to Tokyo. Walk down the main street in Ginza at night or the beautiful back streets you might forget you are in japan with the amazing european aspired architecture. If you want to shop you are in the right place with area full of boutique shops and high end department stores.
5th Avenue of Tokyo. If mid town shopping and dining are your things, this is the place for you in Tokyo. Shopping is limited hours so go early.

Upmarket & classy shopping. We took a subway from our Hotel in Shinjuku to visit Ginza. It is top listed in our itinerary as a must-visit place in Tokyo. Arrays for famous branded shops are literally found along the Chuo Dori street. Upmarket shopping centres such as Matsui Ginza, Mitsukoshi, Ginza Wako are among those visited by both locals and tourists. People tend to dress up nicely and much more civilised compared to Shibuya or Shinjuku. Not to mention that Apple Store is also located here. Very easy access by Tokyo Metro as several exits are interconnected beneath the Chuo Dori Street. Great spot for both day and night photography. Well worth a visit.

Upscale Shopping and Hanging out Area . Ginza is an upscale area, where expensive shopping options are available. You find all the brand names at Ginza. Affordable shopping options include Uniqlo and other chain stores. Recommend to come at night, so all the lights are up, and one would see the spectacular view of Ginza. Recommend 2-3 hours for sightseeing and shopping. It takes about 15 minutes to walk to Tsukiji fish market. At night the market doesn't open (only a few sushi shops are open), and the ones that are open normally don't have lines. Come eat during the after hours to avoid the line.

High end shopping area. This is an area exclusively reserved for high end shopping. For foodies there is also an area s full of restaurants and bars on each side of the street.Take the opportunity to visit the Tokyo JR station.Some shops are tax free for tourists as long as you spend the minimum amount required.Don't miss out the pedestrian crossing where the Ricoh sign on the round building is, it's really something at night time.

Generic Shopping City. This isn't a sleight at Ginza specifically but all of the cookie cutter cities that are revolved around shopping these days. Culture is a wonderful thing and something that you travel for, or at least some people travel for I guess, but here it seems as if all I endless rows of shops, doesn't scream Tokyo, doesn't scream Japan, just screams global commercial business. Not for my type of traveller I guess but perhaps that's the point.

Ginza-Another Hustle bustle City ...great to look at and browse ...still some japanese culture to look at and admire. Ginza is another great easy to get to city of Tokyo ....loved looking around - many designer stores and Japanese Culture in the mix

Classy Ginza. Always choose to stay in Ginza on our 4 day stay in Tokyo at the start of our annual Japan trip. Much more civilised and less chaotic than the likes of Shinjuku and Shibuya. Sure the shopping is a bit out of our price range in many of the stores but it has a nice vibe and beautiful buildings.
All the flagship stores are here. You can find the Uniqlo flagship store here, along with Apple store and a host of other Western brands in this are. Not cheap, but perfect if you value brands

Shinjuku is better. This place has a variety of store and department store however I would say it is nothing special. the only thing here which is worthwhile is the Kabuki show theater. I personally preferred shopping in Shinjuku.

If you like expensive shopping in a crowded area. Second time in Japan and second visit to Ginza. Unimpressed with the amount of people there, all looking for "bargains" which is impossible as everything is expensive. Call me old fashioned, but this to me does not represent Japan in any way. Other than that i hate elbowing my way through tourists to get to where i am going (As a tourist yes)...
ginza shopping district. ginza has everything the curious visitor could want, shopping, eating as well as coffee or bars, enough to entertain even the most fussy traveller

Clean city. It's amazing how clean this area is. It's high end shopping with stores everywhere. If you're looking for souvenirs, then this isn't the place for you. However if you're looking for high end luxury stores, this is it. For tourist, it is tax free shopping. You'll be saving 8 percent.

Awesome suburb.. Fancy shops and the clean Japanese streets make you stay with a open mouth most of the time.The lights, the accessibility for shopping, eating are very good.Everything it's available at Ginza.

High end, mid end and department stores shopping district. The walk along Ginza is one experience you want to do when in Tokyo. It has high end shops such as Louis Vuitton and Apple Store and the largest Uniqlo to name a few. There are also 2 major department store along the strip namely Mastuya and Mitsukoshi and at the end of it is the Hakuhinkan Toy Park.

Tokyo's premier shopping district. Ginza is a great shopping attractive (a bit like London's Oxford Street) - it's home to all the large brands and Uni Qlo's 10 story flagship store. Lots of bright coloured lights and places to eat too. Well worth a visit.

Enjoy walking along the street. I always have a pleasure time while walking along this street. There have many attractive activities in this street ex. stand alone high ends fashions, cosmetics(ex shiseido parlor), premium watches(ex. Montblanc, seiko), variety and delicious restaurants, good cafe and sweets, big kids store and big stationery store (Itoya) etc. Never get bored with this place.

High End Shopping Tokyo. There are a great number of shops, many very high end, in the area. Also for the larger department stores the basement has a great international food market. Much to see and buy. Also great Apple store there.

Ginza. I took a walk on the streets of Gina on a Sunday where pedestrians have access to walk the streets freely. Being a few weeks before Christmas the streets were decked out in Christmas decorations and the department store windows were all beautifully displayed. If your hungry pop on to the Isetan department store Food Hall and pick one of the venues offered there. A go to place offering first class shopping experience albeit of the top labels kind. An area crammed with shops, boutiques, department stores, restaurants,and cafes.

Over rated. The Ginza district has been left nine behind in terms of glamour shopping (try Roppongi Hills if that's what you're into). The main reason to go is for the Sony building which my kids really enjoyed - think lots of cameras and technology for them to try out.

If you are rich go there. It is a wonderful place to visit but it is a big disappointment if you are not a brand shopper. All of the expensive brands are there repeatedly with sky high prices. Waste of time for average shopping. A nice place to go just to have a look around.
Great!!!. You have to walk ginza, its plenty of good restaurants, stores, and beautiful buildings, hotels, here you'll find one of the biggest Uniqlo and you must buy some clothes there.
A hoot at Ginza. Had a great visit to Ginza with family including three boys 10, 8 and 6. Used the subway with ease and stayed in an AirBNB. Great at night.

Shopping . Is like an Oxford & Regent streets in London or Champ-elysees in ParisLove this place. I bought Hermes I watch there for wife.Excellent thing is, if you hv your passport, the shop can straight away deduct taxes. Save us from form filling and queueing at the airport to get a refund!

Ginza is a must-see in Tokyo. The Ginza area has it all - fabulous department stores, high end retail, great restaurants, museums. You can spend all day and night there and never run out of things to do. Some of our favorites: Idemitsu Museum of Arts with terrific view over the Palace Gardens, Mitsuya Department Store (check out lower two floors of specialty food and groceries), huge Apple store, Sony store, vertical signage at night - very tasteful, Kabuki-za theater.
Modern of Tokyo. When come to Ginza, you can see modern building that really different with Japan style. Don't forget to see clock building as icon of Ginza.
Great shopping! Worth buying!!. Spend alot of time just shopping at Gu and Uniqlo! Great buys compared to the prices back home! Prepare spare foldbags, folks!!
Great shopping. We had a blast walking around and looking at all the stores. Check out Komeho, a high end second hand store. Uni clo also has their largest store in the world in Ginza.

Bright lights, big city. This is a great place to visit in the evening and enjoy the ambience. We also dropped into the Ginza Lion Beer Hall for a few beers and snacks. This is a 1934 beer hall in the heart of the Ginza.

Ginza wher the hubbub of Tokyo is personified.. Having a hotel in the Ginza was a great advantage to see the vast array of shops, stores and arcades in one central area. The traditional Japanese art paper store and the print shops were a particulat favourite but to be able to god to the largest store and buy food in the basement and picnic on the 9th floor roof garden was a real treat. We we there at the time of Halloween and for the occasion in the evening the central streets were closed to traffic - unique experience not to be missed.
Perfect hangout and shopping place in tokyo. Lots of shops, dept store and high end boutique shops in tokyo. The sidewalk is big enough for walking. Lots of store and restaurant for everyone.

Interesting place with trendy shops. There are a few big department stores which are 8 floors high with a few basements, and the food hall, is beyond anything I have seen. There are more than 1000 different kinds of snacks on sale ! Unbelievable ! There are also many trendy shops around the area and its really worth going to check out if in Tokyo !

High fashion packed in a small area. Ginza is pretty much the fashion district in Tokyo. All the high end labels have a store in this area and you pretty much should be able to find whatever you want. It is cool to just people watch and see the crowds and what others are wearing
Highlight in Tokyo. A posh area for Tokyo. You can from socks all the way up to formal dress in the area. From MacDonalds to Chanel can all be found in the area
Tokyo Chap-Elysee!. Ginza is an upscale district with lots of high end retail stores, luxury brands are all along the roads, loved strolling around i!

Extremely Safe with loads of shops and restaurants. What a great alternative option than to stay in Shibuya/Shinjuku. So central really if you're looking to go to the Fish markets, Akihabara (electric town), Sky Tree, Shibuya, Harijuku, Shinjuku, Ropponghi.Abundance of shopping, so many restaurants. So Safe. Tokyo in general is very safe but here, as a female i would walk around at midnight by myself and feel safe to do so. When i come back to Tokyo i would probably stay here again.

Glitz, Glitter - Ginza. An extremely vibrant area with shopping and dining options too vast to go into. While crowded, the area is open enough, and the crowds polite enough, so as not to cause any problems.The level of concentration of businesses is amazing, plus much of the architecture stunning.One must visit, even if they do not plan on shopping. The only drawback is that if one is looking for a street address, they should know that in Tokyo, they will need to patiently walk about, and should not hesitate to ask for directions - it is not as easy, as in some other parts of the world.

Flagship stores right next to each other!. This is a very convenient place to shop as most of international brands and flagship stores are located along the same street. The good thing about Ginza is that the stores have sales on a regular basis. I found a lot of items that are way cheaper here than in my home country. As a tourist, you can also avail of the tax free items if you spend at least 10000 yen.I found a cheap Japanese restaurant that serves very good udon and ground beef with rice. For 520 yen, you get all of those. I didn't get the chance to get the name of the restaurant but I can definitely identify it it again from the logo and the characters when I visit next time.Despite of Ginza having a reputation of a high-end, '5th ave'-ish shopping district, there are affordable items and reasonably priced stuff for everyone to enjoy.

A trendy and sophisticated high end area. Well the title says it all!Its an undeniably immaculate and a sleek place designed for the mid upper class.Everyone dresses to a tee and you can indulge in shopping while you are here.UNIQLO , Mitsukoshi and other notable shops are here too.Its like the FiFth Avenue of New York but this one oozes with a more sense of upper class restrain and class.

Sophisticated part of Tokyo. We were in Ginza to have Yakitori Dinner. Yakitori is usually affordable but not in Ginza, you'll pay premium $$ for premium grilled skewers meats! They are well worth the $$. Many high end boutiques and western clothing brands have stores here in Ginza. And they seems to open till pretty late night. Reminded me of London a little. Very easy access by a public transportation.

Ginza shopping. Good mixture of department stores, high end boutiques, niche boutiques (e.g. dog accessories, fashion). Not the area for trendy, fast or youth fashion.Main street (Chuo-dori) closes on Saturday and Sunday, becomes pedestrian street.
Fashion and Upscale District in Tokyo. One of the most visited spot in Tokyo by the Chinese tourists too. This is where fashion meets good taste in this metropolitan city.

The heart of Tokyo. This is our chosen neighborhood in Tokyo. No matter what time of day or night there is always something to do. and no matter how many times you visit there is something to discover. There are so many hidden gems here just a half-block off the main drags. The added bonus of staying is you always have lots of extra time to explore -- whether it is food, shopping, or nearby sights.

Enjoyed wandering and looking. Nice way to spend an afternoon. The street is closed to traffic on weekend afternoons so makes it easier to navigate. Many very expensive stores - but some surprisingly affordable places (check out itoya - particularly the craft floor).
High end stuff mostly. Just a street of mainly high end boutiques. If you are there for branded stuff, sure why not. If you are also going to Tsukiji market, pop by here. It's not far.

Best place to stay in Tokyo. Ginza is the best area to stay in while visiting tokyo for vacation. Plenty great restaurants at any price level, shopping mecca, and close to major train stations/subways.

Reminds me of 5th Ave NYC, but with a bit more flavor for all levels of what people are looking for..... Lots of high level brand shops, and walking distance to dept stores and /or shoppettes...and in between there are smaller midclass shops, and also low price ramen nearby. Would go there again and again and again!

A place to visit.. This place got everything! food, shopping - massage- name it.This place is where the branded shops are- almost all global brands are in this place. You might also need to check inside the buildings because there are smaller shops hiding in this places. I don't think though that if you are shopping for a bargain - this is probably not a suburb for you

Up market - quiet. . I prefer it. Nice and safe, quiet for Tokyo standards. Really flash area with flash shopping precinct. Clean & tidy. Close to trains. Good restaurants all around you. Not over the top expensive.
Very nice part of town. Excellent location. Stylish area. Close to Tokyo station. Not crowded. Expensive shopping. Easy acess to metro and Shinkansen. Palads gardens etc.

A delightful area to visit... don’t miss it.. Following a tip, we visited the Ginza area on a Sunday and enjoyed it tremendously. Late-afternoon and into the evening, during the road closure, are the best times to enjoy Ginza. The main street – Chuo Dori – closes to vehicular traffic on weekend afternoons (12noon to 5pm) and up to 8pm on Sundays.Note: Refer recommendations below including spots to view passing Shinkansens.A caveat: Ginza is Tokyo’s premier upmarket shopping and dining district, and we are hardly people who shop at the likes of Bvlgari and Cartier, or dine at Michelin restaurants.A warning: Be prepared for Ginza’s infamous $10 cups of coffee.The best way to see Ginza is to first walk the length of the Chuo Dori road closure before winding into the other streets. This is an area which encompasses the world-famous Ginza Wako building. It was a tremendous experience just absorbing the delightful street lights, signage and watching shoppers. In fact, we only stepped into one retail store! It was quite a surreal experience walking in the middle of the street without vehicles.Highlights: Ginza Wako Building, Bvlgari building, street lights, cityscape.My recommendation is to arrive by way of Shimbashi (aka Shinbashi) Station – one of oldest train stations in Tokyo and a few leisurely minutes walk to the southern end of Chuo Dori. Then end your evening near the Yurakucho Station, which is the more economical area for your evening meal or supper.Recommendation 1: Great places to view Shinkansens are - (a) in the shopping centre outdoor plaza area east of Yurakucho Station - the first station out of Tokyo Central; and (b) on the Yurakucho Station Yamanote line platform. Shinkansens go by – literally - every 3 minutes. Recommendation 2: In combination with the above, visit the Shiodome and Hayao Miyazaki’s ‘NI-TELE Really Big Clock’ at 2:50pm before starting up the Chuo Dori. The clock wind up hours are 10am, 12noon, 3pm, 6pm and 8pm. Important: Be there a few minutes before as the animated show starts about 4 minutes before the hour and ends on the hour!Enjoy Japan!Thanks for reading this review and my gratitude if you choose to rate it as helpful. No pressure though. Cheers!

Shopping shopping shopping. When in Tokyo, it would be hard not to visit the Ginza area. Lots of high end shops everywhere you turn. If you don't have deep pockets, window shopping is free and there is always the Uniqlo flagship store to get a good bargain.
Fun, upscale shopping area. Great area to enjoy upscale shopping, dinning and kabuki theater! Check out the flagship Sanrio store while here! It is two stories!
my eyes were full!. my eyes were full just lots to see took tons of pics just lots to see and do go with a plan or actually just wander around that is good too

Shopping galore!. No trip to Tokyo is complete without a visit to the shopping haven of Ginza. As well as a huge plethora of designer shops and boutiques, you can also find well-known high street brands such as H&M and Zara.The best thing to do is put on your walking shoes and work your way around the area, visiting the large department stores such as Mitsokoshi, Matsuzakaya, Wako and Matsuya on the main strip before branching out to the many shops that line the various side streets. A personal favourite hotspot for shopping are the many local fashion shops of Ginza Inz where it's hard to leave empty handed. If you are looking for electronic bargains, phone accessories or golf equipment, the nearby Bic Camera store is a must too.Make sure you have a whole day to experience this fantastic area, and if you are feeling peckish, there's no shortage of fantastic eateries too!

Shopping!. Pretty awesome shopping place.High end as well as budget friendly items.Found a rondaseru at Ginza at less than Y10k! Believe me that's a steal!Also had blast buying strawberries, raspberries and cranberries by the side walk.

Shopping and shopping. One area of Tokyo that you can enjoy shopping till you drop. The most of popular expensive shop are here for you from exclusive diamonds brand , luxuary brand to the good department stores are in this area. You can spend the whole day walking around. Also there are many good cafes and restaurants around.

Busy shopping area - free wifi. Typical large shopping area with all the high end shops - possibly too expensive but worth a look. There are a number of large high end stores as well as some international ones such as UniGlo Muji
Nice shopping area!. They block traffic into main street of Ginza on the weekends between 12 and 5pm.That's the best time to get some shopping done!

Best Uniqlo Shop is here.. Convenient and nice area for shopping compare to Shinjuku or Shibuya. Huge walking path along the road. If you come on Sunday from noon, you can enjoy walking on Ginza street.

Pedestrian Shopping Street of Tokyo. We stayed a few days at Tsukiji and pretty much walked to Ginza from Tsukiji 3 nights in a row. It was Autumn so it was comfortable and cool.The main shopping street is a pedestrian street until 5pm or so. This is basically where the high end shopping for Tokyo is located. There are a few things that really stands out for me:1) There are a LOT of good restaurants in or around Ginza. Head to the basement of the train station and you have several famous Michelin Star restaurants innocuously tucked in a corner, including what is Japan's most famous 3-star sushi restaurant, Sukiyabashi Jiro. If paying top dollar is not your thing, you can walk to a street of yakitori (bbq chicken on sticks) shops nearby. We couldn't get a reservation at Jiro's (we're not japanese) and so we had more fun at the Yakitori shops.2) They have 11 floors of Uniqlo! And they stock plus sizes for womens and menswear! You don't have to be stick thin to buy the good quality thermal wear at this branch.3) They have Shiseido.... Bakery. Most people, women in particular, know of Shiseido as a famous japanese cosmetics brand favored by many people in Asia. In Ginza, there is a Shiseido bakery / patisserie. It's worth a look.
A high end place. We went here for shopping. Almost all designer brands are here.We had dinner at an Italian restaurant. Food is good!
Good place. I found full night life here ir clean and romantic road ,Then they have everything in the street. I will be back.

CBD of Tokyo. You can have a flavor of how the Central Business District of Tokyo is like. If you happen to visit in the evening, try out one of those いざかや, or izakaya, which is a kind of Japanese-style pub. You can experience how local people spend their off hours.

Busy area with lots of shops and restaurants.. We stopped at Gooz cafe. Very good food. It's fast, mostly for take-out, but you can also sit. Has Japanese specialties, has prepacked lunches. There are high end stores, but also a department store that had very practical clothing items at very cheap prices. Also could get tax-free if spent around $100. There are many restaurants and many people. All in all it's pleasant for walking and people watching.
Endless designer shops. If you are into designer goods then this is the place to go. Not for me but the choice is endless. The top end shops also have fantastic exteriors to entice you to them.

Very nice street for shopping high end luxury and contemporary. Definitely the place for shopping for clothes and other wearables in Tokyo. The whole street is lined with luxury to local casual brands such as my wife's favorite japanese clothes store Unicqlo. The unicqlo store here is the largest and best in the world as per the store's pa system. Gucci, prada, rolex also line this main street in Ginza which is even closed to vehicular traffic so pedestrians have more space to shop.

When in Tokyo. Busy busy busy busy busy its Tokyo come and be blown away by a fantastic experience don't let things pass you by get up and get out. loved Tokyo and all it has to offer. As with all things in Tokyo the best stuff is free!

Glitzy Ginza!!!!. December in Tokyo is a really cool time to visit…literally and figuratively. I had been to Ginza before, but seeing the effervescence of this city at Christmastime through my son's eyes was amazing. GINZA glitters...apparently the name means ‘place where silver is minted’. Go at night! Its like no other spot on the planet…crazy neon lights, videos blaring from giant screens on skyscrapers...add giant Christmas trees and displays to that and you’ve got an iconic explosion of what one would expect from Tokyo.Ginza is filled with high-end stores from all over the world. I personally don’t care about Tiffany and Shiseido and Mikimoto – BUT I do lust after Ito-ya. Ito-ya is floor after floor of handmade papers, and pens and stationary and art supplies. Ginza is also filled with Department Stores (known as DEPATO). Here’s one major reason why the Tokyo DEPATO are cool: The food courts...basement mini-food-kingdoms I suggest going to the food court in the Mistukoshi department store...open since the 1600s!

Shopping high end boutiques. All shops here are the high end boutiques. So you can spend considerable time window shopping. We did get into a few shops which had good handbags. There was a also a sale going on at one of the luggage stores where suitcases were being sold at discounted price. Suppose to be a good brand and many locals had turned up to pick up the suitcases.

Highend boutique and restaurants. Best of everything in Ginza, brands to food. Very clean city and lots of tourist and high end business people.Well known for High-end, also you will find good quality products.

Shopping at Ginza. Expensive place to be. Shopping haven. Chanel, LV, Gucci, Burberry, Bulgari, Tiffany, etc. etc. etc. Everything is here. If you want to spend money, you don't need to go any further. This is the place. A must place to see. We enjoyed every minute of it. What I really like about Japan, overall, is the cleanliness and the discipline of all people. You cannot find trash bins but you won't find trash either. The people, locals and tourists brought their trash with them and dispose it in the right place. Kudos to all Japanese. The way you were brought up is excellent. People all over the world is envious of you.

Car Free on the weekend. if you are a big fan of shopping here is the place to be. i always enjoy strolling around ginza area, enjoying the cleanliness and watching people strolling with their fancy shopping bags.
All you can find in Tokyo. Great shopping place. Great dining place. Great upper class area. It was all you can find in one place. Shop. Dine. Travel. Be part of the Japs culture

Expensive but interesting. According to some Japanese this is the most expensive places to visit in Japan. Stroll the street and look in the stores. Here you will find all the designer stores and big names in fashion. Chanel, Gucci, Tag Heuer, and many more. Large department stores, easy to get to on the Metro - Ginza Line.
Dazzling street Light !. its great lighting on the street and there has amazing shopping outlets, still remember got jacket from Gu brand its worth spending time at Ginza.

Very expensive window shopping area. A real global window with all the most expensive goods available in the world. Very impressive in the evening with its glittering lights and luxury cars but not different from 5th avenue, Les Champs Elysees etc... Not representative of Japan!

Shop till you drop!. If you enjoy shopping , don't miss this! You can shop for hours exploring the department store and up market shops in this area.
A must for shopaholics!

Upmarket Street. This is Tokyo’s famous upmarket district. The time to be in Ginza is night when it gets brightly lit up and there is action all around. It has numerous department stores, all major fashion brands and great dining options and nightclubs. As we were staying in the Ginza area at the Mercure Hotel, we were able to walk down to the main Ginza street every evening for shopping and some great meals. Surprisingly, not all shops are expensive. We were able to get great clothes at Uniqlo the Japanese casual brand at super prices . Their outlet at Ginza is the largest they have and is spread over 8 floors. An evening in this area is a must for all visitors.
High-end place.. Great neighborhood. You can find a lot of hotels, numerous restaurants (local or international cuisine) and bars to hang around. Its main attraction is the high-profile stores.

Luxury area. Too many must see area in tokyo, Ginza is one of them. See all the branded shops there and the beautiful buildings by day and night. Many eating areas and good hotrls there too. Was there on sunday and one of the streets is closed, reckon is the main shopping belt there.

Glitzy shopping district a must see for visitors to Tokyo. My wife and I did some shopping on the Ginza strip during our last visit to Tokyo together. You can find anything and everything here. And, prices can be quite reasonable if you look around a bit

Big area, lots of stores and restaurants. Visit after dark to view all the lights and huge video screens. This is a very large area with lots of side alleys (full of stores as well). It is also not just limited to brand products.
Eat before/after Ginza. Ginza has alot of nice shops and shopping possibilities, but less restaurants. So eat before or after shopping.

Nice area. This a nice district of Tokyo. Mainly for shopping but good for walking as well. Actually it is one of the oldest districts of Tokyo but currently very modern. Tokyo station is walking distance.

GINZA THE HIGH END OF TOWN. Shopping in the Ginza is very high end, you will have to have deep pockets here. with stores like Chanel, Cartier, Ralph Lauren ETC. However there are department storesthat have the quality at a reasonable price tag. Inza Ginza and other cheaper outlets can be found away from the main street of the Ginza. This is a place to visit at night as the stores a light up with their neon signs and can be quite beautiful.
Ginza. This is very much like any expensive major metropolitan city neighborhood. The shopping is high-end. There are office building and restaurants galore. And the people watching is great.

Shopaholics heaven. This area is great if you love the major big brands. Clean streets and lots of restaurants. You are spoilt for choice. But remember there are other places to shop so do venture out as there lots of other department stores and Japanese brands offering a great variety.
Shoppers Paradise. Whether looking to window shop or ring up the credit card ,the Ginza is a must see location for anyone visiting Tokyo.

Times Square of Tokyo. The premier shopping district of Tokyo, this famous area doesn't disappoint. Every major retailer (Japanese and international alike) can be found here. The flagship Mitsukoshi department store is here, where you can get lost shopping for days. Seeing it at night is even more impressive, with the bevy of neon lights illuminating this uber-clean shopping district.
You can find everything this area!. Ginza is best for tourlist.You can find everything you want buy and eat! Maybe you should spend 2 daysL
City life at its best. It's a crazy place to be on Saturday, with shoppers and tourists. But I guess that's the essence of Ginza - lights, shops and people.
Classic Tokyo neighborhood with closed pedestrian streets on weekends.. Best shopping on earth for average sized people, beware no large sizes! Amazing food, shopping and people watching.
Shops. Um, it's shopping. Relative to the UK, it's cheap, too. But that's about it. It's pedestrian - only on weekend day times, too, fwiw

Ginza is oftern overlooked as just an expensive shopping stretch. Ginza has more than just hi end shops. There are many galleries (Tokyo Gallery, Shiseido Gallery, and Ginza Graphic Galley GGG), interesting boutiques, and some great fusion style Japanese restaurants (Kaishoku Michiba, from one of the original iron chefs, now in his 80's), that are not cheap but in my opionon good value for the money.

Beautiful. After leaving the fish market we came to Ginza. It was very quickly easy to see that we were underdressed for such an outing. Here you will see the best dressed in Tokyo society. The department stores feature booths the likes of Hermes and Tiffany and Co. Great restaurants in all of the department store too. Although the shopping was very stroller friendly the restaurants were not as accommodating.

Beautiful, especially at night. Even if you're not planning to buy, walking along the main street(s) of Ginza is a real treat, especially at night, when the tasteful lights - including street lights - and glam buildings show at their best. We hadn't seen it for some years, and were impressed at how well the area has developed and with what good taste. Some of the elegant new architecture (especially of the luxury brands, plus the Yamaha Building) is striking, and more development, in time for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, is under way (as it is throughout the city).

Brilliant. Ginza is a brilliant, luxury, high class shopping region, comparing Shinjuku the shopping area for young generations and Shibuya the eating region. Ginza means in Chinese as Silver stage. Gold symbolizes the emperor, silver is brilliant symbolizing movie stars and actresses. By subway, stations are Ginza or Higashi (east) ginza.
Ginza. Great neighbourhood for food, expensive high end fashions, and great people watching. Avoid expensive restaurant and bar tabs by going local in smaller outlets. Avoid crowds by going early.
Shopping galore!. Fantastic place to shop for mid to high range products. Either way, you would be treated like a queen.

Poshy Walk. You will immediately see the difference once you step out of the train station. It's a poshy walk around Ginza. It's good to see, but an expensive shop for budgeted travelers. We went here just to shop on the biggest Uniqlo in Japan - which has 11 floors! :)What I like best is the volume of people walking around here - not that much in this place. Volume is just fine.So all in all, it was a feel-good poshy walk with not so much paper bags in our hands :)

Our first Taste of a Tokyo 😀😀. Wow - sine expensive shops Dian here that's for sure - have your credit card handy if your wife's in tow but it was fun wandering around looking at the shops and sights - great few hours had by all.

Mix of shops. Good mix of shops. Mostly posh shops and department stores. Still worth a look even if you don't buy much. Some great restaurants nearby but can be expensive. Good place to stay as a base. We stayed at the Mercure hotel. Near metro stations and between the main landmarks of Tokyo.

High end streets of Tokyo!. If you're looking for high end brands i.e. LV, Chanel, Bottega then this is the place for you. Each store is easily 4 floors, you'll have plenty of time to walk around and shop. Food is pricey compared to other restaurants in other area, so if you have the time to travel - I would suggest to eat somewhere else besides Ginza.

Girls paradise . A place more for adults especially ladies to shop for designers goods with the best service given in the worldIt will be a place quite bored for children so family with children can consider to give a miss here

Lively and exciting. Ginza is within walking distance from Tokyo station about 15 minutes. There are plenty of shops including international brands to keep you busy. Lots of food in the food halls of large department stores like Takashimaya. At night, the whole place is lighted up. Looks fantastic.

Another shopping street. Although it is a beautiful place to walk and have diner, it is a shopping area so if you don't want to make shopping, there is nothing to do. You can find all brands but prices are a bit high.

Fun but not overwhelmingly fabulous. Hmm. We made a special trip here one evening to see all the lights and to check out the paper products at Itoya. The lights didn't dazzle me, except for the fantastic light show on the external wall of Chanel. For more razzle dazzle, neon and bustling crowds, Shinjuku is way better. If you're into some seriously luxe shopping, you'll love Ginza. All luxury brands, wide footpaths and not much else. Have a look then head off somewhere else for dinner.
Shopping!. Shopping, shopping, shopping! If you're looking for designer brands and high-end boutiques, this is definitely for you!
center tokyo. Ginza is one of the best places for shopping in tokyo, many big brands ( dont forget you passport for tax-free), and many restaurants ( not cheap)
Impressive midtown Tokyo. It's great to walk around, look at the stores and the people. Very stylish stores and great stores for electronics.

Shoppers paradise. If it's shopping you want then this is the place to some similar to oxford st in London. Lots of well know and upmarket stores along with many cheaper outlets , some bargains to be had. Lots of cafés and restaurants open till 8 pm generally
Shopping!. Beautiful part of Tokyo with loads of shops and malls.The whole area comes to life at night when all the amazing lights are on.

A must in Tokyo. Ginza is a must visit in Tokyo. So many amazing places here, from shopping heaven to gastronomy heaven. Amazing department stores and dont forget to visit the food hall on each department stores. Its usually located at basement 1.
if you like shopping or traditional japanese theatre. if you like that this is the place to go, it has it all. and good restaurants too as they are so close by the fish market
nice area in Tokyo. Stayed in a hotel there and could walk to nice restaurants and at every corner there is a convenience store which sells everything. Nice shopping, polite people and safe at night

Fancy food, fancy stores, fancy people. Ginza is an obligatory stop (and shop) in Tokyo. The entire area is glitzy and delightfully glamorous without being snooty. This area makes Manhattan's 5th Avenue look squalid and shop-worn. Make sure to explore the department store basements. Also, I loved Itoya, a paper/stationery store, a Ginza fixture since 1904.

One of the Best. One of the best shopping districts in Tokyo.
Get ready to indulge on the food and boutiques around.
Definitely a good way to enjoy your day.
PJ

The place for shopping and good food.. Ginza is the place to start you Tokyo visit. It is lifely, high end fashion, very good restaurants and a central point to explore the rest of the city.
Impression: search Chiara bakker japan in a flash
Food. While the department stores are too expensive for most, the food courts in the basements are nothing less than amazing.

Must do. Much to do here. Glamorous part of Tokyo with lots of high end shops including department stores and designer boutiques. Lots of nice streetscapes too. Hard to spot an unstylish person. Well worth a visit.

High end shopping and more. We are not into high end shopping but just wanted to explore the Ginza area. We were planning to look for a place to have dinner, apparently since it was a Friday night, most restaurants even along the side streets were fully booked. We ended up going to Mitsukoshi department store and had Korean food at one of the top floors where all the restaurants are situated. Shopaholics will appreciate this area with all the fancy stores as well as some mid range brands as well.

Shopping and more shopping. Well, as we all know its a shopping district. Lots of high end stores in the area, with big stores like Uniqlo, GU and etc. Those looking for toys, please check out the toy store (sorry, forgot the name) end of the street from Uniqlo. Corner place, great selection and lower prices. Tax free as well for tourist.

First visit. I just had the chance to stop by and walk around. I feel more comfortable to walk around and do some shopping here. You can fine almost of things as Shibuya but more relax. There is a large Muji shop with Loft shop here which very attractive. Using Ginza line metro will be reaching directly.
Nice to see. This is a nice area of Tokyo. It is definitely the more up marker and more expensive area but still nice to have a wonder around.

Shopping experience. Tokyo never sleeps with restaurants open till late bars til 5am and most shops 9pm to 10 or you may find 24 hour shop but that maybe a supermarket or pharmacy. Ginza is a fantastic shopping area too much to walk out. Shops I mistaken for hotels, that shows how many floors the designer shops have and each very welcoming. You don't feel you don't belong in any store. Also there are a few well known shops sitting proudly in this designer area

Nice to walk around. nice place to hang out.Kind of expensive so if you have a small budget is just to walk around.A lot of departments stores and fancy places.From there you can take the train to Daiba.

Just an upmarket shopping area. Not really must scene. It'll be good if you wanted to do some high end shopping and I mean high end like Gucci etcBut I did enjoy going to to Matsuya Department Store for the food hall in the basement. I'm a foodie traveller and it was amazing and surprisingly cheap. I walked away with so many goods to try!!

Paradise for Shopaholics. Ginza is a place filled with shopping malls and all the branded goods you can think of. One can easily spend a day here. The walkways are wide enough and easy to find the streetnames. Clean streets everywhere. You can expect the tallest Uniqlo with 10 levels too. It is a must to visit this glittering street!
Interesting area to walk but not much more. Its most expensive real estate area in the world. So the shops are high-end, people dress rather nicely - but apart from that there is not much to do.

Old high class Tokyo. Ginza is the place where senior Japanese shop for luxury goods. I personally find it all outdated, however the area has had an influx of Chinese tourist in recent years. That is more of a negative than a positive. Ginza is also home to the Sony flagship store and Kabuki-cho. If it's the weekend, only Sunday I think, the main road will be closed to traffic, so it makes for a better strolling experience.
Close to Asakusa. You can do it 2 in 1 which is Ginza and Asakusa.. Ginza is more to modern type of street but still got the traditional side..

Best shopping and a nice district. This is a very nice shopping area that is easy to navigate in and also has good places to eat...easy to reach and fantastic variation of high end brands...just love this place

Go twice: once for window shopping during the way and then for night life and lights at night. Hard to explain you just have to go. It's part New York Times Square and part New York Fifth Avenue. And it's 100 % Japanese Tokyo. Many of the stores are straight from the U.S.but even those are Japanese. Very few western tourists this October but plenty of crowds. Architecture is striking, the variety of stores, restaurants and the like is almost overwhelming ang the lights and noise at night is overwhelming in a good sense.

Let Me Check My Rolex, Roscoe. This area is way overhyped for the shopping. The same old glitzy, outrageously expensive shops are there that are in every large city on the planet. I knew I was in trouble when the concierge handed me a "luxury shopping brochure." There are 3 department stores in Ginza but compared to their buddies in other parts of town, small potatoes. There are a couple of interesting museums and the theater, but I really expected more glitz and glamor. Instead, I literally got lost amid the Guccis, Tag-Heurers, Francisco Parduccis, and the Lacomes. Yikes! I'm too old to have much of a night life, and I imagine it's very good here.
