I saw all number of "men's clubs," karaokes, bars, and discos. Also, like all of Tokyo there's myriad restaurants of all description.
Shopping. SHOPPING LOVER...a place for high society to hang out...lots of good place to enjoy and SHOPPING...the place where night feels like noon
Best Shopping in Tokyo !!. Ginza has all - Hermes, Armani, Salvatore ferragamo, Burberry, Gucci, Abercrombie & Fitch, Gap, Zara, H&M, Uniqlo & Gu.... endless list...

Place to be in Tokyo. The place is abuzz with quite a few branded stores and the Clock tower looking grand. The shop displays are very innovative and attractive. Very lively at night and busy during the day. Good for shopping and eating out.

The rodeo drive of Tokyo. Upscale , chic , opulent . Great to walk thru . Sometimes they close part of the street area to make it walking only . Very suitable for dining and shopping . A pleasant place amid the city hectic and less comfortable streets . Has a high networth mall full with all the main brands . Great delicacies downstairs
Beautifull at night and great place for shoping.. Beautifull at night and great place for shoping. Many trendy shop and restaurants. Amazing in evening.

Big High Fashion brand street. Walked around the Ginza area on a lazy weekend, plenty of big brand name stores, was nice that the road was blocked off as a walking street, some nice looking restaurants around, but plenty of queues, plenty of tourists dragging luggage around.

Busy, busy!. Our tour bus dropped us off in front of the very busy Duty-free shop in Ginza. We didn't even bother to fight the crowds to get inside. We walked away from the crowds into the quieter area and visited a couple of stores. This area is just too busy for my taste especially during the day. We came here once on our own a couple of years back in the evening. Much nicer.

The CBD of Tokyo and good for window shopping. Ginza is known to be an expensive district in the past and now because it is the Central Business District in Tokyo. There are many high end brands from overseas as well as some local big department stores. It was a good experience to walk around looking at nice (and expensive) things in Ginza.

Great shopping - the best. If you love shopping... this is it!. Nothing better in the world.All the good quality brands... Give your credit card a work out.Clean, tidy, plenty of restaurants, shops, walking distances, just nice.

Great place to observe people. Intersting to watch people here but as I'm not a "shopper" the stores didn't interest me.Worth a look and walk along the street and if so minded drop into any of the many "name" stores.

Shopping Shopping Shopping. Great place for shopping, eating and in getting some of the special service you may be looking for. Clean roads, friendly people, etc. etc. This is the place to be in Tokyo
shopping!!. a great place to shop for designer stuff,with lots of brands and restaurants around.must place for shopaholics.they have lower brands as well.
Loved Ginza Area. Excellent area with a wide selection of shops and food choices. A great choice when visiting Tokyo with kids and family.
Business area. A couple of nice buildings but otherwise not a lot to see. Be aware that most shops only open 1030 - 11am

Sophisticated Place in Tokyo. Shopping
Shopping
Shopping
and
Hangout
Ginza is the best location for Shopping branded stuff in Tokyo
and here you also can have nice location for hangout too
I love ambient of Ginza
Super elegant and sophisticated

Shopping in style. Yes, this is the shopping destination. Especially if you are looking for designers such as Gucci, Prada etc.
One note: everything closes by 7pm-8pm!!
This means - schedule for a day time activity.
Shopping district of the world. Taking shopping to a whole new level. The architecture is amazing, the amount of shops unthinkable. Shops everywhere you look

is a fashion district, Is not what i'm looking for in Tokyo.. is a fashion district, Is not what i'm looking for in Tokyo.
Extremely occidental and posh.
A tour in the yamaha tower is the only reason to go there.
Interesting. The entire street was shut down on a Sunday. Towering buildings and expensive shops. Pretty neat to see
Luxuty brands Mecca. the Mecca of luxury goods,world famous brands in one place,notice that dinning here or coffee is about 50% higher than in other places in Tokyo

Great Shopping Experience. The Ginza shopping are was quite an experience. I think you could find just about anything here. What I particularly liked wee the food courts at the bottom floors of the two large department stores. Both were enormous and had all kinds of delicious things for sale. I bought some cookies that are among the best I have in several years. I also enjoyed just window shopping since many of the stores were outside my budget range. When I was there during the weekend day, it was closed to traffic which made it very convenient. Later when I went back at night it was open for traffic. If you go to Tokyo I highly recommend visiting Ginza.

Ginza Pedestrian Paradise. We went to Ginza on a Sunday, as the streets were closed for pedestrians to walk. This is known as "Ginza Pedestrian Paradise", where some of the streets are off-limits to vehicles from 12 - 5pm. No shopping was done (it's a rather expensive area for budget travellers) but it was nice to see everyone out and about in spite of the afternoon showers.

Tokyo's 5th Avenue or Rodeo Drive. Very cool place to visit, window shop (shop for real if you can afford it). Ginza is a large district of Tokyo with all of the high end stores, Channel, Prada, Matzuya (like Sacks 5th or Maycy's).Ton's of great restaurants from street foods, inexpensive to high end restaurants. Also home to the first Starbucks in Tokyo. Is a nice place to stroll and walk around. Also very close (10 minute walk) to Tsukiji fish market.

High end shopping district!. The high end shopping are with many branded fashion store.It's open until night. You can find many restaurant and place to hangout here.Its one of most place to visit when you in Tokyo. There also a famous restaurant in Ginza called Torigin Ginza. It has many crowd and usually long queuing here.

Tokyo's Rodeo Drive. Tokyo's famous shopping district. Even if you don't shop, it's worth a visit. The department stores are different than in the west, offering a bewildering array of foodstuff in the basement. I browsed the kimono sections - gorgeous. The stores also offer rotating art displays. If you visit Takashimaya (further along the street) they still have the elevator girls!
been there last month. The whole road are fulled of people. You can walk along the road and enjoy shopping just like me. I love it
Wonderful experience. Everyone goes to the Ginza. I prefer the roads one or two blocks off main road. Very unique bars and gift shops. Nothing is cheap however, as it is the Ginza.

A shopaholic's Paradise. From inexpensive to expensive, Ginza has something for everybody. If you work up an appetite, there are plenty of restaurants to choose from. At night, Ginza lights up like Las Vegas.

Special place for shopaholics! :D. I promised myself not to shop a lot for myself in Japan, and that was actually a very hard-to-keep promise when you are at Ginza XDWhat I remember the most is the how-many-floors Uniqlo--I think it's almost a dozen, and Uniqlo here is very much cheaper than ones in my country :D :D :D

Fashion area with luxury boutiques and popular shops.. Ginza is Tokyo's most famous shopping, dining and entertainment district, featuring numerous department stores, boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, night clubs and cafes.Ginza is one of the best places to see the neon lights of Tokyo. Also famous Kabukiza is Tokyo's main Kabuki theatre. The theatre offers three performances most days and finally also in this area the Tsukiji Fish Market. The world’s biggest seafood market, moving an astounding 2400 tonnes of seafood a day and supplying Tokyo’s top restaurants.An area to go absolutely

Pretty at night. We stayed in the Ginza area. Where in some areas is a little bit quieter in some areas. The shopping is incredible. The lights at night are incredible. Such a beautiful area to walk around.

All Within Walking Distance. Ginza is centrally located so most of the "must visit" places are within walking distance. If you use the clock tower of Mitsukoshi Department Store as part of your orientation, you will not get lost. Mitsukoshi Department Store has a large selection of "food items". Foodies' heaven! The breads and pastries are top notch... there's where we get our breakfast treats most of the time. We stayed at the Mitsui Garden Hotel which is about a block away... a nice find. See my rating for the hotel separately.
I love Ginza. I love the department stores in Ginza and have been hundreds of times. I always spend some time in Ginza when I travel to Japan.

Ginza shopping extravaganza. Visit this place to get a sense of Tokyo's luxury shopping. A visit to the mall with it's fabulous food court in the basement is recommended! Grab some food and sit on the roof terrace to enjoy it!

Widely recognized commercial and shopping area of Tokyo in the whole world. Just to the southeast from the Hibiya Park and our Imperial Hotel is located this district of Chuo, one of the wards of Tokyo. We really assured ourselves, in what measure Ginza, shopping area is so popular among the residents of Tokyo, the metropole, that counts in total with all 26 cities,small cities and villages, 32 millions inhabitants. But not only the hosts, the guests from all over the world, also admire and enjoy in such multitude of internationally renowned department stores, boutiques, restaurants and coffeehouses located in its vicinity. And what is for sure, is that this shopping and commercial district is one of the most luxurious in the world. The main street is free for the pedestrians and in one intersection or place, we noticed even the crossings for walkers, put on the pavement in slant positions.In the other street ,we saw the famous kabuki theatres.There is a crowd everytime here in Ginza, and especially in the evening hours, You can see such richness of the numerous colorful blurbs, which shed the light on You from everywhere. Not to miss, indeed.
Great area to stay for my first time in Tokyo. Everything happening here. The hot I stayed just right at the Conor of main street. This area full of bars, restaurants, shopping and etc.

It's more than just the main street. If you're looking for the latest high-end fashion, Ginza is the place for you. You've got department stores like Mitsukoshi, Matsuya and the grand dame of them all, Wako. Let's not forget all the brand shops lining Ginza dori. Personally, my favourite is the stationary shop, Ito-ya. If you're a fan of fountain pens, go through the main store to the back, across the street to the "K" building and then up to the 2nd floor to their pen showcase. Fantastic!Weekends are interesting because the main road is shut down to vehicle traffic and the street becomes one long area to people watch. Great for photography as you'll see a mix of real characters as well as people out dressed in their finest fashion. Oh, there's also free wi-fi all along Ginza dori so if you really need to get a text out, or you're updating your instagram, it's very convenient. Step away from the main drag and explore the streets running parallel to Ginza dori and you'll encounter some interesting little shops and eateries. The side toward the Imperial Palace is still pretty high-end until you reach Yurakucho but head the other direction, toward the water, and it becomes decidedly more middle-class; this isn't a bad thing. You'll see that the area of Ginza is far more than just high-end shops.

Lots of shops. This is an area is very busy and full of shops and restaurants. As I am not a big shopper it was not my favourite place in Tokyo but if shopping is your thing I think you would have a great time wandering around. Loads of restaurants make it a great place for dinner or lunch.

Meh. High end shopping district. On weekends they block off the street which was nice. Lots of jewelry and bridal shops. Free wifi was nice.... Nothing you can't see in any other major city such as SF, NY, or Hong Kong.

Tries too hard to be hip, but there is good eating. A bit too "hip" for my taste, but some great restaurants are located here, so I inevitably come here in a fair bit whenever I return to Tokyo. But I wouldn't come here without a particular destination in mind. On the other hand, if you are the type who loves Prada, then this is a must see.
Fashion district!. Lovely to walk around..especially late evening. Dotted with all the high end brand stores. Must visit.

Champs-Élysées of East. Extremely Posh , with great crowd and world's best high end stores- Ginza is a shoppers dream. Try visiting in the evening as the lights make the place more vibrant and lively.

The polished side of Tokyo. We stayed in an apartment at the Tsukiji Fish Market end of of Ginza for a week.This is a perfect area in Tokyo to stay at when you're visiting.It has an abundance of great eateries ranging from the very affordable, like Ippudo, to very top end, like Sushi Yoshitake, and everything in between.Close to the metro, shopping for every taste and budget, surrounded by great site and most within an energetic walk.We loved it and will certainly return for more.
Busy Ginza. Shopping mecca. Every high fashion you need is in Ginza. Not cheap..but what are you doing here then. Great for just window shopping and people watching.

Worth a visit. Good for shopping, or in our case window shopping! The lights after dark make for some good city photos. The basement food shopping areas in a couple of the department stores could rival Harrods!

High class shopping area. If you like windows shopping and enjoy shopping time, this is the area you are looking for in Tokyo. Most of the shops are of luxury brands and expensive, but there are as well some department stores of convenient prices. Coffee shops and restaurants are nice. Sure I recommend visiting the area even if are not willing to buy anything.
Well established stores. Went to Wako, Misukoshi, Itoya, etc.Good atmosphere, but did not see anything worth getting.Some interesting architecture.
Just another shopping area.. Not being shopping addict ginza was nothing special for me. Just another big area of various shops. For all those shopping addicts this will be probably heaven :)

Shopping Street, slightly expensive. Ginza is simply a shopping street. It is very long filled with department stores and luxury stores. The prices are expensive which makes me hesitant before purchasing them but it is enjoyable when entering stores to see the products. You can find the detailed products Japanese people have created. Also, their customer service is one of the world-best.

A good place for shopping - Worth a look to tick "Been there". Not much here but a succession of luxury shops and department stores. If you like shopping then you have to go there. If you feel like shopping is not a holiday thing then you can go there, enjoy the walk and grab some good food (a few excellent restaurants in the area).
Atas place for Atas people. even the food are branded.....everything here is basically expensive (I am just an average person)....difficult to find food too...
Highest-End Shopping in Tokyo. The ritziest shopping prefecture in Tokyo. The most expensive and elegant stores, fine dining and desert, designer booths, and beautiful city scenery.

Shopping. High-end shopping and ritzy bars are commonplace in Ginza. We only stopped by here on our way to Tsukiji Market and for the Sony building. Both locations are easily accessible from Wako building as a central point

Every shop. Every shop you could ask for.
Bright lights big city to the max
Safe too walking around especially for ladies.

Forever Ginza. Ginza will always be Ginza with the stores and restaurants of different sizes and grades. It is safe, clean and people are friendly consider it is in a big city of a advanced country. Never feel tired walking, shopping or just window glancing as there are always be good coffee shops near by to sit down for a nice cup of coffee and world class desserts.

Loving Ginza. Great place to stroll, wide sidewalks, clean street, tons of high end stores, 12 floors of Uniqlo (crazy!), shopping paradise, Ginza station will lead you to most tourist destination (or you can transfer) in Tokyo.

Shop till you drop. At Ginza you can find almost any brandstore you can imagine, they are all there. Shoes, watches, haute couture, juwelry, anything! Incl. some huge department stores (preparing and selling fantastic food down the basement) absolutely worth to visit.

Tokyo Upscale Shopping District. A nice area full of offices and upscale shopping malls, its not such a fun area for the normal tourist. Served by several metro stations, its a nice area to visit if you need to kill sometime in downtown Tokyo but besides the occasional stroll, there is nothing special to see or admire.
Great district for ... eating and shopping !. Wonderful shopping district, nightlife, eateries and hotels, a great area to base your stay while in Tokyo with easy access to everything.
Buzzing Streets and Amazing Shopping. The streets are buzzing with shoppers and nightlife. The area is very lively with all brands and stores available.
Nice area. an upscale shopping and offices area. The best means of exploring is either by bicycle or walking. Many rental bicycles nearby. Historical and well preseved past

Great shopping district. Loads of boutique stores and also great shopping centres too. I noticed the further away from the train station the more upmarket the stores. Fun to walk around and window gaze at many of the upmarket stores. Found some quaint little shops integrated into amazing architecture. Bought tones of ladies clothing and fashion accessories from shopping centres.

Great Shooping and Dining. Here in Ginza there are a lot of great shopping center and fashion shops. They closed several street on Sunday so we can walk easily. They had like the tallest Uniqlo store I've ever seen. Largest Sony showroom I ever seen and a lot of good restaurant serve great food too.

place to shop. i go here to sightseeing, in ginza you can take a picture of odd building such as deers building, mikihito building, you can also watch kabuki performance here at 11 am for 45 minutes, they have 5 session..

Pretty place. A lot of luxury shops, affordable restaurants easy to find, a cd/dvd mall in Ginza which I was happy to find!
Clean street and awesome building.
During week-end you can walk on the road it's closed to car and others vehicle, it's amazing!!!

GINZA IS THE HEART OF TOKYO. Ginza is a sublime mix of trendy and traditional, outrageous and conservative, exorbitantly expensive and great value for money. Engulfing eight blocks of the most prestigious stores in the world including Chanel, Cartier, Armani, Brooks Brothers and the local Daimaru and Matsuzakaya it is no wonder land is the most expensive in Japan, selling for 10 million Yen a square metre. It is 15 minute walk from Tokyo Station or one subway stop away if you have some baggage to carry. There is an hourly bus from Narita Airport and it will drop you at Sukiabashi corner, the entrance to the suburb and within walking distance to any hotel you choose. It is also home to Sukiabashi Jiro, known as the best Sushi restaurant in the world and the most difficult to get a dinner reservation. Historic Ginza has always been a major art, entertainment, commercial and restaurant centre for residents of Tokyo and was rebuilt after fires caused by the 1923 earthquake destroyed most of the then wooden shops and buildings. It the genuine historic HEART of Tokyo which is and always has been the centre or art, entertainment and food. If you are going to Tokyo make sure you visit Ginza or you will missing the very core of Tokyo life.

Shoppers paradise . For avid shoppers, this is a serious place to be. Our family isn't big on shopping but we enjoyed window shopping and soaking in the atmosphere of the place. Evenings are a good time since the lights make the area more urban picturesque. Check out the paper goods store with 4-5 floors dedicated to cards, stationery, etc.

High End Stores. This is a place known for expensive items like Chanel, Salvadore Ferragamo, Prada, Hermes And many other stores. There is a lot of restaurants and coffee shops too. The train station is nearby.

Nice Place for Shoppers!. Nice place for shopping. Every store is clean, fancy, but with a lot of shoppers. Comparing to shopping malls in US, this place is much fancier and make you like to buy something because you just feel good when you are inside a store!

The place to stay and shop. The hotel we like to stay in is in Ginza. This neighborhood has everything: a park (just opposite our hotel), plenty of restaurants, famous Japanese department stores and boutiques. The streets are safe and clean. Taxis are plentiful. And the subway station is easily accessible. Getting around is easy and compared to other neighborhoods, it is not as crowded.
Busy area. Very busy and thriving area with a lot of shops and restaurants. Easy to access from the Ginza subway and most places are within walking distance.
An urban area. An urban area of Japan, showcasing luxurious brands shops nearby since it is the place elite stays. Not a fan.

Great near Christmas. This is a top area for shopping and access to the metro. In November the Christmas decorations light up the streets. We stayed at the Mercure in the Ginza area. I can highly recommend this especially if you are in the Accor Le Club as you get 50% off all meals.

It's a Must to Visit Ginza Every Time Your in Tokyo. I usually go and visit Ginza every time I'm in Tokyo. Lots of shopping and food here. The good international brands are located here. When it comes to food I usually don't eat at the main street. Instead I wander in the smaller streets where the price is more reasonable and food more authentic.

Good walk!. Nice area to walk around, most of it is high end shopping, but there are some shops that are more affordable. Uniqlo ginza has a great store. if youre in the area it makes for an easy walk through, plus its close enough to tsukiji market to make it a 1-2 punch

Swanky. This place is swanky...reminds of you NY in the movies I would say...wide streets, billboards and all...pretty uptown...we had lunch at an Indian restaurant here...the food was alright...a place with many photo-ops.

Designer shoppers paradise. If you're looking for designer products, Ginza is the place to go. Including the incredible department store Mitsukoshi which includes floors and floors of designer items, Ginza is also the home to many stand alone designer stores such as Chanel, Tiffany & Co., LV, Prada and Fendi, as well as stores such as Apple, H&M, UniQlo and Bershka.

Ginza is good at day-evening time, but not at night)). Beautiful buildings, beautiful people, yammy food in the basements of department stores. But at night walking around in the upper left side of Ginza (if you look at the map) - the place full of bars and little restaurants, - is twice more expensive and twice less fun than in Roppongi :) So many "likes" to High Five bar in that aera - total disappoitment and a cocktail for 40$ was what i could make myself at home even better.

INTERESTING UPMARKET SHOPPING. Number one ,if you love shopping or just window shopping this is the place for you, this is really interesting upmarket shopping.All the top names are there some we have never heard of and they are all beautifully presented.The thing about Japanese shopping is that every thing you can buy gift packed, they do it so well. There are some fantastic restaurants and the service and politeness of all staff no matter what type of business you enter is absolutely the best ,I would say in the world. Yes some places are expensive but the product is top shelf, sure there are some very expensive places to eat but we have found that comparing such with such it is no dearer than back home , in plenty of places cheaper and of course in this part of the world there are more Michellin Star Restaurant than any where else on the planet. I do believe it is the dearest real estate in Tokyo and probably the world.It is nice on the weekends, both days I think ,that at a certain time the main street is closed to all traffic. It is a real buzz then to see every one strolling about without a care in the world, very busy but that is normal in Japan. In some areas there are tables and chairs placed right in the middle of the road for people to do whatever they want.Ginza is not all new glitz and glamour, there are plenty of old historical places to find , some great parkland nearby and of course the Imperial Palace and it's magnificent gardens are only a few minutes walk away.I find it a great place to walk around, absolutely love it and I am not a good shopper. A must part of Tokyo to spend a bit of time at.

The Avenue Champs-Élysées of Tokyo. I once read Ginza has the highest commercial floor space prices in Tokyo and the world. I'm not sure if it's still the case now. As one can deduce, this means Ginza is geared more towards the luxury shopper and less towards the commoner. I'm glad I didn't make Ginza the base of my first Tokyo trip or I might never venture into other quirky and charismatic Tokyo neighbourhoods and have a feel of what living in Tokyo is really like.
Great dining and shopping street. Plenty of restaurants to choose from. If you like shopping, many department stores and brand name stores line the street.
Boring part of Tokyo. Not much going on, way too expensive. This is not the real Tokyo. Dont waste time, have a look on way to fish markets but thats it.

What's the fuss about?. The best thing about the Ginza is saying you visited it.
Just a bunch of over priced up market shops.
If you want to see the place at it's best get there early, say around 8am, you'll have the place to yourself.
The place for great shopping. If you are in Tokyo and look for the place to shop, this is where you need to go. All brands are there and you cannot miss it. It is easily accessible by metro.

Whole world in few streets. This shoping and eating district requires weeks or months to be explored deeply, but even short stay can be sufficient to uncover and to like Tokyo. Prices are on the higer end of the scale comparing same things in Eu or USA, but salespeople make it different with their smile and wish to satisfy. Problem can be that even in the best shops is difficult to find somebody who speaks English.

Weekends shopping. It's my first experience to see the surrounding roads around the malls being blocked up during weekends just for the shoppers to walk across the roads safely to the mall for more shopping especially that they still arranged chairs and tables in the middle of the roads for shoppers to sit and relax after a busy afternoon of shoppingI think only in Tokyo we are able to find such comfortable shopping experience Suggest to visit on weekends to experience these unique arrangements of the place

Kabukiza (Higashi Ginza station). My absolute favorite of Tokyo was the Higashiginza station underground market and the Kabukiza theatre above. MUST see to observe many in traditional kimono selling and coming to see the operah (Kabuki). You don't have to stay all day for full performance. They sell tickets separate for each scene. Small park on top of building with great views of the area. Seeming a time capsule in the center of the city.

A good place to see and walk around at night. I came here mainly to watch the Kabuki performance at Kabukiza Theatre, but ended up spending a good chunk of time walking and enjoying the streets as well. I am not a fan of shopping, but there is something wonderful about observing the many stylish outfits of the people in Ginza. Surprisingly, there are some very tasty and affordable restaurants here, and the snacks and desserts are beautifully crafted and delicious.

shopping paradise!. Stayed in Ginza for 6 days. All the major department stores are here! Uniqlo has their flagship store here. Sister brand gu is also here. Be prepared to encounter a lot of mainland chinese tourists doing their duty free shopping. Lines on the tax refund counter tend to get really long. Also, There are several yummy restaurants tucked in the side streets of ginza.

Shoppers Paradise. We visited this area after the fish market, which was pretty early in the morning. Although I didn't get to visit any of the shops (they don't open until 11am), I still enjoyed seeing the home to Tokyos finest department stores. Go to visitacity.com to help you plan your itinerary.

Amazing shopping street, fun to just walk around. We came to the Ginza's main shopping street to do some browsing and see the sights, turns out on Sundays the street is closed so the whole area is a pedestrian way - very cool. All the best stores are there, and the prices are really high, so depending on your budget you may want to just stick with sight-seeing. As for restaurants, as my wife says "in Ginza just add a zero to what other restaurants would charge", but there are some good places nearby to fuel up, just a short walk away. Must visit, try for a Sunday when you don't have to battle with traffic and noise.

Luxurious & expensive shopping district. We went there on Sunday, full of tourists and locals. A modernized & luxurious shopping district with lots of different famous & leading brands around. A few department stores such as Matsuya, Mitsukoshi, Wako are in the area. I only went to Matsuya & Mitsukoshi but could not believe that they were old and out-dated in decoration inside. An expensive place for food & shopping, hustle & bustle.

A Must See in Japan. Really great place to see by foot, especially when visiting Japan for the first time. Very clean, everyone is extremely nice. Our 2-3 day stay was too short and we look forward to going to Japan for an extended vacation. Food was delicious. Gluten Free can be hard to find when it comes to cooked dishes and sauces, but everyone worked with me and I ate a delicious meal every time..

Knightsbridge of Tokyo. This area, like many districts in Toyko is immense. If you love your high end designer names then Ginza is the place to visit. Nightlife isn't so busy like other parts of Toyko but there are a couple of bars and karaoke venues nearby.

Not for thrifty people. The shops are more luxurious, things are more expensive but in good quality. There's Uniqlo though. For people who can't afford like me, opt for bakeries and cafes, grab a cup of coffee and enjoy people watching. You can also walk across a few streets to find a lot of toy shops and also Don Quixote, there're tonnes of fun toys to try out and their stationery is ever cutest and the designs are unique and creative.
You will need your credit card. Lots of high end designer shops, worth having a look if your into shopping. Every capital city has an area like this and Tokyo is no different.
Amazing. A must visit place to see the night life and wonderful bars. Easily accessible from the subway or by bus.
Upmarket Shopping . For branded items, this is where to go. Majority of tourist group tour will bring you here. Very commercial. Nice walk and great to stop by taking some coffee.

Ok to have a look at night. This place is for me somewhat obsolete. Sure you have all this famous brand names shops from Rolex to Gucci and the neon lights. This is expensive district around the Sony building. Sony is also not the market leader in elecrtonics anymore as 20 years ago. So is Ginza. Little bit not up to date.Worth the look if nearby.
Classy. Ginza is a lovely high-end neighborhood with lots of posh shops. It was a nice change from the more seedy neighborhoods (like Shibuya, Shinjuku and Roppongi -- all of which I also love).
Upmarket shopping in Tokyo. Malls, designer laberls, little or large restaurants, modern. Awash with lights and popular with locals. Not to miss.

Bright lights and fancy shopping. Ginza is definitely Tokyo's belle of the ball: gorgeous bright lights and lots of high-end shopping. The layout and architecture is also slightly different from the rest of Tokyo - more fancifully planned out with a less crowded feel. I especially love the twinkling lights Ginza will find itself adorned in over Christmas season.

Feels like Beverly Hills and Fifth Ave. The moment you step out of the Ginza station, you feel different. People on the streets walk slower, and streets are less crowded except for shops that cater to tour groups. You can spend the whole afternoon there even if you do not want to shop, you can window shop :). I would suggest going to Ginza after a morning of Tsukiji since they are on the same line. You MUST visit the flagship 12-storey Uniqlo store and visit every level. Do drop by the Lauderee tea room as it's the only one in Asia now. There is free Wifi on the streets!
High end stores.....$$$$. Don't forget your visa, mastercard and amex.....you will need all of them...Very nice street with very nice super expensive stores.

Glamorous shopping precinct. All the world's luxury brands can be found in Ginza and it's an excellent place to walk and browse, particularly when the main road gets closed on weekend afternoons - you get room to wander, instead of having to negotiate your way through crowds on the footpath. There are plenty of places to eat and drink - and many of them have long queues out the front. Not all the shopping is expensive - some side streets have the American chains such as Gap, which is a bonus for non Japanese shoppers because the cut of clothing is a bit more generous. One of the local food experiences is the sweets cafe Higashiya, in the Pola cosmetics building - a revelation for afternoon tea. Generally, it's a nice spot to walk although finding your way into some of the department stores can be tricky. If you get footsore, you can always head into the subway and escape.

Excellent. What lovely options to eat, shop and relax. perfect place. From the high street brands to local shopping, and taste of local and global cuisine. Plenty of subway and train stations too so its fairly easy to get around.

A Different Tokyo. If you hear that Tokyo is compact, condensed and full of people - then you will be surprised that Ginza is not. This is the high end area of Tokyo but you can also find plenty of mid-range shops and restaurants here. A nice area to stroll around especially at night. Many top restaurants are located here.
It's a free world!!. One of the nicest areas in Tokyo! Some roads are converted into pedestrian plazas where you can wander around.Nice shops and restaurants!

Great shopping meca. This part of Tokyo is historic and a joy to walk around - especaially if ypu like shopping. There are high end boutiques, department stores with food halls, duty free shopping, restaurants and clubs. It is easy to get to, and very clean and safe.
The Times Square of Tokyo. Very busy square of Tokyo city with lots of tall buildings and the hub of many MNC Offices. Looks pretty after sunset with the colorful hues in all the buildings.
Great for shopping. Didn't shop at Ginza except for uniqlo.uniqlo was few stories .took some photographs enjoyed an ice cream

Wife says best in the world. This 5* review is for my wife, since I am not a shopper. She most definitely is a shopper and has been to all the major spots around the world: New York, Paris, Milan, etc. Ginza blows them all away. The quality, the selection, unmatched. Husbands: keep the wife out of here!!

Excellent presentation and expensive. The Ginza district is known for its high end shopping opportunities. I found the fruit to be very expensive. One large mango in a beautiful box costs $129 and one will pay $10 for a cup of coffee there. There are fish, sushi, and vegetable options, all neatly packaged. This is an exquisite shopping experience.

A must see place. A very nice and intetesting place whete you will find a lot of nice stuff and places..spend a day a just walk around and get lost and overwhelmed as this area got it all....and only nice people and places go see

Window shopping for tourists. We went to Ginza to have a look at the Hakuhinkan toy store as my daughter loves toys. After that we had a look around Ginza. There are the high end name brand stores which we could only window shop. There were coach loads of tourists wheeling there newly purchased luggage and led by their tour guide to various shops. Uniqlo was a popular choice due to their tax free shopping. It's worth a visit just to say you have been there.

Not as high end as it used to be. Years ago, Ginza used to be a high-end shopping destination. Sadly, this time around, its filled with foreign tourists looking for good deals. I actually enjoyed Roppongi more for high-end shopping. Ginza is now filled with bus load of tourists lugging suitcases around looking for sales. With the exception of Uniglo (?spelling), many of the shops we went were a disappointment. It still has many good restaurants, so its worthwhile visiting, but I don't get the feel of Beverly Hills anymore. More like the feel of the "cheaper" end of Las Vegas Blvd.
I didn't like but if you want to go.... It's just a lot of famous brands stores and high-class restaurants. I just spent 10 minutes cause I don't like so much this kind of place.

Shopping on Steroids. This was quite the experience. Every label from any fashion magazine was there. Armani, Etro, Chloe, Dior, Louis Vuitton, Ferragamo, and on and on. There was nothing in US sizes which was ok as I wouldn't be able to afford anything, but it was great fun to look.
the upper market area. neon light lit up the street and everywhere is branded high end names. the street is clean and full of people. nice place to do window shopping

Shopping Ginza. Great atmosphere and incredible shops. The department stores like Mitsukoshi are incredible. Well lit and basement food court is phenomenal. At night the lights are spectacular. Great restaurants with excellent food selection.
Business sector. This is the busienss sector of Tokyo. My family had a nice time walking around and appreciating the tall buidling and the men all suited up.

Just shopping. I used to love walking up and down Ginza but now it is flocked up bus after bus of very loud and disrespectful tourists. The only upside is the largest Uniqlo (it does stock everything) and the Zara has the biggest range I've seen (compared to Osaka & Tokyo). Worth just coming in and out, but if you hate fighting the crowds, it's not worth it!

Nothing Particular than A Typical Shopping Area. If you want to do good shopping of brands, you might go there, but you would easily find those products in any of the Western cities like in Paris or London. For me, nothing particular than a typical shopping district. Dont waste much time for shopping in such a great city!

Nothing special. Could have been in any major city with the boulevards the brand name shops and the well heeled patrons we didn't find this place very unique or special. The Japanese department stores are worth a visit especially for their heated toilet seats but if you are pressed for time maybe venture elsewhere

Shopping Heaven. This is a place for very high end shopping and dining. All the top luxury malls in the world are present here and just walking on the colourful well-lit streets is an experience.I found the rates at the various designer bag / accessory shops higher than USA / Europe but thats expected in Tokyo. They have the worlds largest Uniquolo shop, I spent 2 hours shopping there but wasnt satisfied, had to leave because they were closing the store!Tips: - If you are on a budget, please skip all the restaurants here. - - The only mid-range affordable place to drink and eat is Beer Hall (apart from the small cafes). - The Uniquolo store is a must visit. - Skip the high end cosmetic stores (like Shieseido) you will find the same brands cheaper in discount chains elsewhere. - Best time to visit is between 5 and 8 if you want to watch and browse, most places start shutting down by 7 so if you want to shop please reach by 4pm.
absolutely visit. Essential area of ​​Tokyo : all major luxury brands are present ( Chanel , Armani ....) to popular ( UNICLO , Forever 21 ....) as well as department stores.

Japan luxury shopping street. Ginza was a high class shopping district with numerous luxury brands. i went there for Ginza akebono ichigo daifuku and then go to neighbouring nihonbashi for sightseeing.However, Ginza is overcrowded with tourists so you may find less locals shopping here.

Trendy shopping. Ginza is a great shopping area and the place to people watch especially on a Saturday afternoon where main streets are closed off to traffic so that thousnads of people can easily move around to shop or hang out. If you aren't into shopping it's still worth the experience of urban Japan
Expensive brands. All the top end shops are here. Great just to window shop.check out the shopping mall food courts for an inexpensive meal.

Decadence by design. This is a busy, bright commercial ramble, in the same camp as State Street in Chicago or Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Lots of big, opulent stores designed for gawkers by big ego, extravagant architects. I don't know who actually buys this stuff - Fendi bags, Louis Vitton clutches - but the stroll up and down the pleasant six blocks is entertaining, especially at night. On Saturdays they close the street to cars for the middle of the day, which makes it quieter and more festive. Worth a stroll, and you can stop in at any number of restaurants along the way.

Shopping, shopping, some food, and more shopping.. Not quite sure what the difference is between high end retail in Ginza versus high end retail in London, versus high end retail in Paris, versus high end retail in Prague, versus etc. Don't get me wrong..It's an interesting & lively area, but Cartier is Cartier is Cartier. If you're a Starbucks fan, the first Japanese Starbucks is located in Ginza. There is a nice selection of restaurants... but many of the decent ones close early leaving only the casual bar/restaurant types available to those folks suffering from jet lag (after an hour or so of looking we headed back to the hotel for room service).. While I wouldn't say to avoid the area, I wouldn't put Ginza as an overly Japanese experience. I don't regret spending time here but would probably limit the time to half a day looking arround/shopping and a few hours walking around at night.

A paradise for all shoppers.. Ginza is a place with the most expensive land price (/meter) in Tokyo. I enjoy taking a stroll here especially when the weather is great. If you're a fashion addict, shop junkie or even love branded items ( new or vintage ) this place is a paradise for you. If you're traveling with your family ( especially with little children ) I'll recommend you to go to ginza during the weekend as the main road is close ( car free day ) and children can roam the road as much as they want. Well, every step you take will take you to different stores or different restaurants and overall it will be a nice visit. Before you come here, make sure to check the cafes inside of the shop ( most of high end brands have little cafe inside of their boutique ). It's such a unique experience :)And they have lots of station so you don't need to worry about anything. Biggest department store would be Matsuya Ginza and Mitsukoshi.

Stores, stores, and more stores, restaurants too. Shop till you drop may have originated in this Mecca of the very rich, and the very ,I wish I was rich, crowd. Every designer has their golden claws out, ready to grab your black Amex card
Most of the readers will cringe at the prices, but it's nice to dream.

Posh establishment ! Ginza ! Ginza !. We went for a stroll along the street of famous Ginza 3 chome, stop by at the Mikimoto Pearl shop, you can't miss this the whole exterior is decorated with pearl. Had a mild dizziness with all the shining pearls. Was surprise that now the have a range cosmetic made from pearl. Lovely experience !! Than we take a loon at one of the famous stationary shop in Ginza to buy a Japanese design stationary and Japanese paper (washi) - Bunkyoku. This shop is full with expatriate. This is the only shop where you can but the lovely, classical Japanese paper design. I bought incense stick smelt of Sakura, Yuzu and Christantenum flower. Happy with the purchase ! yay ! totally worth your time here, plenty of lovely cafe along the stroll. Gorgeous evening !

Love Ginza!. Definitely upscale! We saw a watch for $94k (yes, dollars). Feels like you're on rodeo drive. Fun to choose a corner cafe a people watch... You'll see high powered business men being dropped off by their chauffeur, Mom and daughter shopping, sports cars whizzing down the streets... I ran into a "Barkery" which had the most adorable puppies Ever!

Shoppers paradise. Upscale to junk and everything in between . ALL the designer names have stores in the Ginza district. More impressive is the Japanese department stores, they are a must visit. Be sure to go to the lower levels to see the food offerings.
Pretty expensive but worth a visit. Come here on a Sunday afternoon when there won't be any traffic. It's a great pleasure to walk on the wide street and enjoy the architecture and expensive shops.

Great Sunday Shopping. I went to this place on the car free day. As the result, I enjoyed every second there as pedestrians control the town! :D Many great restaurants, shopping arcades, and great place to enjoy your coffee in town.

We do love Ginza's shopping. Visiting Japan is simple wanderful! Everytime I stay in Tokyo, I have to take the metro and go enjoying Ginza.Hello Kitty's store has a lot of gadgets, toys and accessories for girls.
Foodie finds!. Great place to find hidden foodie gems, and plenty of areas to people watch and shop. Easy walk from Tokyo station, and The Metro stop is close.

Upscale shopping district.. It looks really nice. But there ain't much to do. Designers shops, upscale boutiques. We had a bite in one of many cafes. Our friend told us about this area and Seiko building. We drank our coffee, ate beautifully presented cake and headed to Minato.
Great shopping and dining. Ginza is a fun place, terrific shopping and dining. It is easy to get to via the metro. The department store in Ginza is huge and also offers great restaurants.
Shopping Shopping and more shopping. Get your cards and cash ready and head here. You won't regret it if you can afford it. Walking around is free though and the atmosphere is lively :)

Shop til you Drop. First time visiting Ginza, biked through it, and even that was enjoyable. It is so distinctively different from other neighbourhoods, which is really cool. Lots of shopping, and the best sushi restaurants can be found here. Worth a check out.

Go at night to experience all the fabulous store fronts!. Every high end store you can think of on the strip. Don't forget to check out the basement levels of the department stores for the amazing confectionaries! Also, remember that many restaurants may be located one or 2 floors up, so look up for their signage!

A mixture rather than just an upscale area. Third time in Tokyo and with friends Who are familiar I discover that Ginza is not just about the main boulevards full of upscale and branded shops. If you start to explore the areas behind the main boulevards you will discover there are a lot of eating places and nice small independent shops that sells and service with reasonable prices. I also discover nice reasonable and interesting eating places at Ginza Corridorlike midori which is one of the best sushi and Shashimi I had in Tokyo. There are many more interesting restaurants underneath the railway lines which I did not managed to try. But by the look of it very appetising and interesting. Less crowded area as compared to shinjuku or shibuya. Prices of items sold in Ginza actually the same when compared other areas in Tokyo. Love the Uniqlo flagship store there. Amazing selection and choises that you can't find anywhere else in the world. Love Ginza

Great neighbourhood.. Shop till you drop with all the high end stores but even budget shoppers are catered for eg 12floors of Uniqo, then collapse in one of the many dining options again from up scale to budget priced.

Somehow overrated, but still worth a visit.. While Ginza is a "must" place to visit while in Tokyo, I actually found it to be somehow overrated.OK, so it's a nice upscale shopping area in the city. So what?Having said that, some of the buildings' architecture is impressive, and the masses of people and the famous crossings are enough to make you pass by for a quick 2-3 stroll.

Window shopping. All the major brand names are gathered here and those who love shopping can easily spend the whole day here. Best to visit during weekends where streets are closed to traffic and various street performers play.

Upscale shopping. Lots of upscale department stores around here. If you got the money, this place is for you. The basement of the Wako department store (the one with the clock at the main intersection) has the whole basement dedicated to food and bakery. If you are on a budget, head to Uniqlo. It has 12 floors and also the cashier on 2nd floor is tax free. Just bring your passport. The store is hard to spot unless you are close by, so check out the location on google maps before heading over.

The place to window shop and fine business dinners. A shoppers paradise, if you have the money.... Looking does not cost anything and so interesting to see the way business is done in many of the finest department stores and high end designer stores.Love to walk around the famous Ginza area during the day for the shopping sights and at night the fine restaurants and bars come alive. It can get a little expensive but this is the upscale area for the Tokyo business scene.The place for business dinners and if you want to be away from the trendy (and crazy) Shinjuku area or the foreign tourists in Roppongi.

High end shopping . If you have deep pockets and do not mind paying extra for almost everything, then this is the place for you to do your shopping in Tokyo. All the major luxury brands are there. It offers a comfortable shopping experience for those who can afford it. It's not a must do unless paying more for your shopping is not an issue.

Upscale all the way !. We stayed in Ginza during our Tokyo vacation. Ginza is the most upscale section in Tokyo. It is easy to navigate and most places are on walking distance from your hotel.Ginza has many stores with the best Japan has to offer. Ginza has also a wonderful variety of restaurants, cafes and bars. It has a great aesthetic and sophisticated feeling with very pretty sights at night as well. We did not explore the club scene, karaoke and we did not go to the Kabuki Theatre, perhaps next trip...
The pricey part of town. Lots of shopping malls and good food. Head down to the basement of the department stores for fancy deserts!

Place where the Major Brands are. If you are looking for brands: Chanel, Burberry, etc. This is the place to go. Most of the branded flagship stores are along this one stretch. Major departmental store Mitsukoshi and Matsuya are located in Ginza as well. For tourists, do remember to get your tax refund done. Consumption tax is at 8%. Some places charge a 1.1% processing fee while others don't.

Shopping spree. Basically the whole street is for upscale shopping and you can find anything branded there. We went to the bisdgest Uniqlo store there with 12 storey. And there is EU there. Which is the cheaper version of Uniqlo. Mitsukoshi was another one of their super upscale departmental stores there.

Ginza, the heart of Tokyo's shopping!. If you want to see shopping at its best Ginza is the place you should go to or stay like we did. The largest department store in Ginza, "Mitsukoshi", has an amazing 3 floors in the basement dedicated to food and wines. It is breathtaking to see the variety of take-outs and the way they are presented. A joy for the eye and the pallet. Ginza is filled with all the designer shops one can imagine as well as large electronic brands and thus a real shopping paradise. You definitely cannot go hungry in this area as you'll find everywhere restaurants of all types and budgets, cafés and bars and all in walking distance of the 3 major Ginza metro stations, "Ginza", "Higashi-ginza" and "Ginza Itchome". Ginza, a part of Tokyo, to be visited, lived and really enjoyed!

Just another shopping area. "Haute couture" top brand stores and high class restaurants are not my cup of tea, and this districts has tons of it, along with many Japanese department stores.Go there at night when all neon lights are lit up, it looks impressive. Just take an hour or two stroll through that area, unless you're a shopping freak.

Upmarket Shopping district of Tokyo. Wife ranked Ginza a 5 but not much in the way of bargains A district for designer labels & deep pockets In terms of department stores , Mitsukoshi is the one to visit
High end shopping area. Ginza is a high end district for shopping in Tokyo, you can get various brands here.. But there's actually no other attraction but shopping...

not to be missed. a real view in the exciting heart of Tokyo, with authentic places, tiny picturesque Streets and food outlets galore, for all tastes.it is clean, safe and pleasant.even on a short business trip it is Worth spending some time there!
boring. Just a bunch of overpriced stores. Come for the Kabuki, or if you want to do some very high end shopping. There are much better places to shop in Tokyo.

This is a very interesting shopping district. This shopping district is "high end" shopping, but window shopping cost nothing. The location is very clean and attractive. We did a lot of walkng around the region. Try the train system its easy and always on time.

One of Tokyo's upscale areas. I travel to Tokyo every year. I have always stayed in Ginza, except two other times in Shibuya.I love Ginza character: it is a very upscale area with nice buildings, luxury shops, high quality restaurants, temples, and Tokyo's largest fish market. I also bumped into a geisha house. The streets look so clean and the road in perfect shape that one can get the impression that they are renovated and washed every day. There are large arteries; behind them are small street where people live.It is a convenient area to travel any of the other main areas by subway. It takes about 40 minutes to go to Haneda airport by subway; Narita is about 80 minutes by taxi (very expensive), or by train.

Shoppers' Delight!. If you love shopping for the latest in fashion trends, have a sweet tooth for pastries, clothing and accessories galore for men, women, and children, are physically in good health, then put your most comfortable walking shoes and bring your inheritance to the Ginza, the Mecca of shoppers!There are very few bargains with the majority of items having tenfold markup. Many items may also be found online at seriously reduced prices in comparison to those found on the strip. However, if you really have qualms about spending your inheritance here, you obviously don't belong here. My recommendation is for you to shop elsewhere, like at Daiso stores or the many 100 Yen stores found throughout the other cities.This real estate is reserved for the rich and famous! However, window shopping is still an option; bring a bib to wipe up your envy!

Perfect place to base yourself in Tokyo!. We chose Ginza as our base for our 7 day honeymoon in Tokyo. After experiencing all of the other neighbourhoods (Shibuya, Roppongi, Shinjuku, Harajuku) I was really glad to return back at the end of the day and walk around the tree lined, safe streets of Ginza. It is such a pretty neighbourhood with fantastic shops, cafes and great food options too. Ginza is ideally based for the Tokyo Station (access to all Shinkasen/Subway & JR Lines) as well as attractions like Kabuki-Za, Tsjuki Fish Market, Imperial Palace and more. We stayed at the Solaria Nishitetsu - one block away from the main street (which becomes pedestrianised on a Saturday). It was great value - for a relatively spacious (for Tokyo standards) room in the heart of it all.

upscale shopping area. it's an upscale shopping area with many big brands around.u can do people watching here, just find a nice cafe and grab a drink n book while watching the busy busy people moving around.

The Expensive Shopping Belt. If you have to shop at Ginza, go there in the evenings. The bright lights, local crowd ambience is a cultural soak. Great bars and cafes too. Next better option to shop for branded stuff is at Gotemba Premium Outlets - only think it is 3 hours away by trains - worth it tho!

Not just shopping!. I don't like shopping but it was still a nice area to people-watch, grab a beer (or coffee might have worked just as well) and walk around, particularly the pedestrianised street. The department stores are worth a quick visit as they are impressive, but that goes for pretty much anywhere in Japan, not just here.
Very Couth shopping. Excellent shopping, good restaurants, good coffee sometimes, The Gardens, the Fish Market, the Kabuki Theatre

A Fascinating Area. By night I is bright lights and large screen displays and by day it is equally interesting. Gina Dori is a street of swanky top end shops and not so top end but anything you want is there. Go back from the main street and you will find a myriad of highly priced and not so highly priced restaurants and bars covering food of most nations. Most of the area is very clean and safe although from 9.00 PM there are a few harmless drunk salary men floating around after their first or second party for the evening. It is well worth a walk around and go to the basement of the major departments stores for the best array of food ever.
Spotless. Never seen such a clean street.Everything is spotlessly clean.Loads of top brand names & the excellent Mitsukoshi shop.Busy high end area during the day & fairly quiet during the night

The World Biggest Uniqlo. We were at Ginza last Sunday. There is a road closure to cars but opened as a walkway.There was many shopping to be done there.We went to the 12th storey uniqlo and spent more than 2 hours in it.For anyone who like to go to uniqlo, don't bother to go to the others as there are limited size and designs.Majority of the stuffs i want can be found here, buying them together it allows them to be tax-free.
Dont Miss if you are shopping mad!!!. my wife and I went to there and found many high fashion brands. almost all highest brands have opened the shops there.

Nice shopping area. Very nice shopping area, with all the "big expensive" brands...the place to go to if you have a lot of money to spend...otherwise you can just walk around, a nice walk when it's sunny...

Great location as base in exploring Tokyo.. My wife, our 11 y/o daughter and me stayed in CHUO, a few minutes walk to where Ginza area is located. We used the Kaisei bus going to Tokyo stn. On our return we take the Narita Access bus, using the Ginza bus stop which is very near the subway or a short taxi ride from our appartment (we used Airbnb). One of our main consideration in choosing Ginza area as our base is its proximity to Tokyo stn. From Narita airport you have 2 major option of reaching the city - subway or bus. Presently there is a promo for NEX, Y4000 two way. We did not consider this one because we anticipate the heavy luggage we'll be carrying going back not to mention we have our daughter with us. So our our only option is to take a bus, this eliminates a lot of hassles in taking the subway; 1. long queue at JR office to purchase the the NEX ticket. 2. Since Tokyo stn is so huge you'll be left with a lot of walking with your luggage in tow. Going to Tokyo stn takes 1 hr 30 mins, and upon return took us just an hour (7:30 am schedule), for only Y1000 adult, Y500 kids.Ginza area is walking distance to Tsukijji Fish market, few stops to other major tourist place around Tokyo.

Great Buildings!. Ginza, what can I say? Everyone talks about the shopping, but I thought the stylish buildings were far more interesting. Mind you, those stylish buildings generally seem to be each fashion house trying to out-do the next with the latest fashion in building materials, lighting, and facades. Ginza positively comes to life at night, as do these fabulous buildings ... so whether it's dining, people or great modern architecture you seek, Ginza has it all. Plus, Ginza is where the main Tokyo railway station is - how much more convenient could it be?

Nice, quiet and safe area.. I was there just a few days ago and I felt extreamly comfortable. Ginza street has elegant and luxurious brands: Cartier, Louis Vuitton, etc. Lots of restaurants and buildings, one of them strikes the hour with music, with its panoramics glittering at night . Gynza line subway crosses with three other lines so you get very well connected with several other places. It is near the main train station, with the new "Kitte" Mall (where the main post office is) at its right side. I agree with comments of some other travelers: in this area the predominant population you see around is mature people, whereas youngsters are in Shinjuku.
Premium brands located in one area. This area has all the top end brands from around the world. Trendsetters paradise, where you can find the most up to date international fashions.
Just loose your self. It's Tokyo so just walk and enjoy the atmosphere and the environment.Just walk and and enjoy. Just find a nice place to eat and take glance of THE city shopping area.

Buzzing Upscale Shopping Area. We stayed in Ginza during our visit to Tokyo. We were out of the area most mornings but the evenings were real fun here - just walking around the neighbourhood provides an ample feel of the place. It buzzes with activity. We didn't really shop here but the stores are mostly upscale branded outlets. There are fair number of mid range eateries and cafes as well, so it's not all pricey!

The Top and expensive shopping area in tokyo. It's a wonderful places to go for a shopping. You can spend the whole day. The best thing is the Expensive and Exclusive Jewelries, Clothes etc. Stores are clean and maintained , sales representatives are very cooperating. If you are looking for expensive south sea pearls, you can look here. you will get plenty of them different sizes and colors. Sony building is very famous, you can see there new gadgets and also explore there.

THE top shopping area I Tokyo. Major department stores on the two main streets (which are not labeled frequently). Uniformed sales women bow in greeting when the doors open in the morning. Streets nearby are more accessible. All are high end.

Ginza vibe. Ginza is a large neighborhood with upscale shops, many restaurants and the famous fish market. It is well worth exploring the amazing Japanese department stores in the area with their galleries of Japanese crafts, food floors and kimono departments.

Wonderful food and shopping experience!. Huge department stores in an immaculately-clean area! Head to the basement level of any store and you'll suddenly be in a completely different underground world! The stores are divided up into many food areas that host stunning food displays at extremely reasonable prices. Locals (and smart tourists) purchase meals and gifts to take on nearby trains. Seriously, some of the most gorgeous pastries, sushi, and wrappings we have ever seen, anywhere on earth, presented with pride.
Boring for teenagers. The prices of the items here are relatively steep. I was personally unable to find anything that interest me

Fashionable. One of the places that you must visit when you visit Tokyo. All the high end fashion stores are side by side with the traditional Japanese department stores which are worth a visit for the experience of Japanese service. There is also one great restaurant after another.

3 levels of pure heaven..... Muji GinzaOk for any of you who do not know or have been to Muji, this is 3 levels of heaven......they have a full cafe & also do takeaway meals for the train trip.......we managed to buy a suit, several food items & still had time to spare before the Shinkansen to Osaka !!!
Empty your wallet!!. They have it all here. Food. Fashion. Small bars all over the place. Labels of your choice left right center!!!
Bar scene. Incredible, blocks of small little alleyways, the roads are closed in the evening, over 3000 small bars in the area, all kinds of attractions to see. Very cool.

Branded, Luxury stores. Stayed very near to Ginza during my visit to Tokyo. There were many departmental stores and restaurants around. Ginza is lively till around 8PM when the departmental stores start closing. Ginza is easily accessible by Metro lines.

You find everything here.. It's a compact area where you would find everything you need, shops, restaurants, department stores, etc. You may also buy the unique Japanese deserts, bags, etc. here. We enjoy walking in this area very much.

to experience the modern and luxury Tokyo.. I like it's super modern/fashion atmosphere & charming night view of the buildings in this city.
and also, "very clean".

"Pulse of the Japanese economy". You can get a pulse of the Japanese economy by strolling through Ginza as this part of Tokyo is where business, fashion and entertaiment intersect. If salarymen are out at night drinking in Ginza, then the economy is not doing too badly. When the bubble economy burst, Ginza was "uncharacteristically deserted" at night. Now, there is a sense of normalcy and vibe that is back.Ginza is not just all about drinking. You can walk its streets at night and marvel at the shopping windows of the big department stores like Mitsukoshi, Matzusakaya and Matsuya or the stores of fashion brands like Uniqlo. Japanese women are more fashionable in winter. They come in boots and winter wear. If you can brave the cold, sip coffee and watch them go by.
Loved this place. This is best place to roam around for people who love shopping. Even if you dont love, its worth visiting.

Money talks. This is the most expensive comercial piece of land in the planet, as a neighborhood. It has all the great brands, all the gadgets, all the things that you see in little shops here you see it in warehouse. Don't Forget to see the cats.

Japan's fifth avenue. A must see and visit for every traveller, where all high end stores, shops and deli's are located....Most well know specialty japanese restaurants are located here...like Tempura place, sushi place etc.

Love the shops pricey but go to the Sony Centre, eateries near the train. This place is famous for the brand names popular with Japanese products but we walked around and found several places not necessarily going to break your budget! There's the Sony Centre, where you can find the latest products and gadgets, little stalls in the centre of the mall is for good quality items not so expensive, like the umbrellas (was raining whene we were there, our ponchos were no good) , stockings and hosiery, small items we were able to take back to Australia and not so heavy. There were also eateries near Ginza train station which were amazing! They look tiny but inside there is even room/baskets to put you bags, etc and coat/jacket holders! As usual, food is great and good value, service tops! Anywhere is really good- whether big or small dining places. We like to eat where locals eat and we found these eateries..just browse and it is a problem only as where to eat as most of the places are good value, just look around first. Tokyo doesn't have to be too expensive!

NYC Midtown vibe, Modern Cosmopolitan Tokyo. Beautiful albeit expensive area of Tokyo with a concentration of large international fashion and luxury brands like Hugo Boss and Kate Spade. Good spot for walking around if you enjoy window shopping or you fancy a bit of lunch in the ritzy part of town. Bring your wallet.
Good selection of designer shops. but expensive compared to London or New York. Some great cafes & places to eat close by. But if you want to shop then come here

Pricey shopping by day, party by night. Ginza is a must see destination in Tokyo. In daytime it is not much to see, unless you're into high-end shopping. Itcomes alive at night with too many bars and restaurants to count.

Designer heaven. Ginza is a very expensive area in Tokyo. You find almost only designer stores like Chanel, Dior, Gucci and so on. Every shop is full of high end products, so if you are on a budget and want to go shopping, don't come here. It is not a super beautiful place, but super clean as the rest of Tokyo. You can easily go window shopping, there are no snobs here in Ginza, so if you just want to look, that is also okay. Go on saturday or Sunday where the main street is closed for traffic, and you can just walk around as you please.

Brilliant shopping district. A great day out has shops to meet all desires. From world fashions, high tech gadgets to the local art and gifts to take home. The area is full of cool bars and great restaurants so there's plenty to do.
Try and make a Sunday when they close down the main street and makes for a more relaxing day.
Dined out and shopping . A Very Lovely place with plenty of restaurants and shops. Love the extra large shops all along the street. Had spend too much once we were there ☺️

Great shopping and eating street. Some very swish department stores and restaurants, Whilst your wife is shopping you can enjoy drinks. E,g, Ginza Lion has great beer in a German-like beer hall, with some good food as well

Brick town. Western-style shopping promenade on the street.It is a popular upscale shopping area of Tokyo, with numerous internationally renowned department stores, boutiques, restaurants and coffeehouses located in its vicinity.

The Full Shopping Spectrum, infused with Japanese Politeness. Ginza is great fun to wander, especially in early evening when many of the stores are spectacularly lit up. You'll encounter the full shopping spectrum, from the very affordable (Uniqlo) to the redonkulously expensive (Louis Vuitton). A spin thru one of the massive Japanese department stores (e.g. Matsuya) is also fun and provides some interesting insights to Japanese culture. The icing on the cake? The same amazing Japanese politeness that you encounter everywhere is just as present in the uber-high-end stores like Gucci. You will encounter NONE of the snooty attitude that you might expect in other world cities. Breeze to get to ... just pop out of the Tokyo Metro Ginza station.

Exciting High End Shopping. Ginza is a truly exciting place with high end stores along the main streets and cute restaurants and interesting shops in the many backstreets. Even away from the centre which we consider near Mistsukoshi Department Store there are many interesting shops such as those selling traditional silk clothing. Outside Misukoshi on the corner is the famous view of the Wako Building which is a very famous view.

If you want to spend thousands of a pair of socks then this is the place to be!. Ginza is a nice area, don't get me wrong, but there's nothing here that sets it apart from other upmarket areas in Japan or elsewhere. The shops are flashy & most of the restaurants pricey but it's still a nice walk around and accesible by the metro.
Yawn!. Nice to see Tokyo, but Ginza's upmarket shops are exactly the same as every other big city - boring labels and nothing new.

Shopping experience for all tastes!. Loved staying in the Ginza area as the shopping was vast and plentiful from the affordable Uniglo and H & M to the upscale designer shops, LV, Gucci, Bvlgari, Chanel, etc. The shopping complexes of Matsuya, Matsuzakaya and Mitsukoshi Ginza Department stores located within less than a block of each other were enormous and had a great selection of local and imported goods, all with a supermarket grocery located at the bottom level basement 2 and a food court to die for in the basement level one. The stores reminded me of Harrods with 7-8 levels of shopping heaven! Off the beaten path of the main street Ginza, you will find hidden gems of noodle, tempura and japanese cuisine shops all affordably priced considering the area. Looking forward to a return visit.

shoping, restaurant, clubs. Tokyo is my dream come true, Ginza is heart of Tokyo!Nice restaurant and shoping places like Mitsukoshi departament store and all ultra luxory monobrand shops with duty free option for tourists.

Up Market Area Worth A Look. Ginza was one of the first areas visited and so did not realise the difference in areas until visiting other areas. Enjoyed Ginza for its variety and wealth where the people are well dressed and the landscape orderly with little green areas/ flowers etc dotted around the place. It has expensive real estate and is worth a visit.

Restaurants in every conceivable space. Boy if anyone wants to tray at every restaurant in Ginza District then good luck. They are everywhere and all full. What an exciting place and full of life. The Japanese are so hospitable and friendly. Great fun

Just shopping really. We didn't see much of Ginza but it was mostly shops. The UNIQLO is quite big and has a nice view of a vacant lot. Save yourself the trouble and catch a subway straight through it.

The Champs Elysses/Madison Ave/Bond Street of Tokyo.... If you have only one district to visit and if you're at the Tokyo Station, then Ginza is a no brainer. All of the top shops in this Metropolitan of 30 plus million, are here and you won't be disappointed. My highlights are Matsuya, Dover Street Market Tokyo, Mitsukoshi and Hermes, LV, Chanel. Good Luck and Enjoy...

Nice location. Ginza is an upmarket area with plenty of shopping and plenty if places to eat. It is home to both high end and regular retail stores. It has a couple of major Japanese department store and has a clean, safe feel about the area
Fancy Shopping Blocks. If you're looking for branded stuff, here's the place. Only thing affordable for me as budget traveler was 12 stories UNIQLO and toy store at the end of road.

Expensive shops. Visit Ginza shops on a Sunday as the main street is closed to traffic and pedestrianised complete with tables,chairs and parasols
and a few oddballs who are good for a laugh. Everybody very friendly. You will need plenty of dosh to shop here.
nice. great location many shopping malls and boutique along the way. Many nice izakaya or cafe also. Walk here around night time to add the ambiance.

Buy, buy, buy, buy, buy. Definitely if you are a sicko-buyer-consumerist this is the place to visit.
Entire buildings where you can spend days or even months just picking the perfect item you have in mind!

Lights, crowds, noise ... you have to go there. You simply can't visit Tokyo without a walk through Ginza. Whether shopping, eating or just people watching, there's something about Ginza that's just exemplifies Tokyo.
If you have the option, visit on a Sunday afternoon when the road is closed to traffic. It's also great at night, of course, when the lights are all on.

One night in Ginza. Hotel being directly above Metro Station and shopping in Ginza.
Lots of food places. Streets are very clean, no rubbish bins around. We saw a couple of men (council staff??) picking up any little rubbish in the street scape.
Felt very safe walking in Ginza at night.
There is nothing that I dislike.

Good for a variety of reasons. A few things that make Ginza interesting for some people:- Lots of shopping available- Plenty of cafe's- Good pretty much any time of the day- Great food in a variety of price ranges- Great for a rainy day (kinda)Ginza, Yurakucho, Hibiya, Tokyo, etc.. are all in one way or another, connected via underground walkways and tunnels. You will get lost, but it can be a ton of fun to explore. You can go from Ginza shopping and cafe's to the movie theaters and electronics stores of Yurakucho, to the International Forum, and even the Yaesu underground shopping center and Tokyo station, without ever having to set foot out in the rain or cold!Additional interesting points from someone who used to live in Ginza:- If you want to see it crowded, head there on a weekend, where the roads are closed to traffic.- It is probably one of the worlds most pretentious areas. People will literally dress in their absolute best, and bring expensive brand bangs from home just to walk around the area for a day and look/feel rich.- Especially on a weekend, less than half the people you see walking the streets will be Japanese. Huge tourist spot (especially for visitors from China)- Chinese visitors are highly targeted by EVERY shop. I have countless Japanese friends working at shops in Ginza who all sing the same song: Our sales strategy is to get as much money as possible from rich Chinese tourists.- You can go to some of the best restaurants that Japan has to offer (if you have the cash)- The main street is interesting, but definitely hit up some of the side and back streets (there is a lot of interesting 'behind the scenes' Ginza going on there'Things to watch out for:-Unless you have the money with you, do not sit down to eat at any place that does not have prices on the menu. It can end up costing more than you would imagine.- Although uncommon, an area this crowded with many rich people tends to be an ideal spot for pickpocketing. Again; uncommon, but its always better to be safe.

Shops, Geisha, architecture. It's all here and very famous. Nice restaurants down the alleys, geiko at night wandering to work looking fabulous and perfect for shopping. A really trendy must see district, don't miss it, evenings are best in my opinion.

Architecture at its best - one of the best shooping districts in the world. When you arrive at Tokyo, and if you are staying in Ginza, ask your Concierge for a map. Walking around Ginza itself takes a couple of days. Firstly, the architecture of the shops are quite stunning especially in the evenings. Customer service and cleanliness is top class. Some of the best places to visit are are : Mitsokoshi, Tsukiji Sushi, Uniglo, Toy Shop, Mikimoto, Sony - its like the best of Japan all in one place. Amidst the grandeur, you can find find many tradtional Japanese products and some of the best produce such as rice, and also its famous desserts. Mistokoshi is a must visit destination. The trains are also easily accessible and there are several stations here.
Great. This was one of the most crowded and amazing places in city. Easy to find a restaurant for food, a shop for clothing. It was very busy but atmosphere was great.
the heart of Tokyo, a must see no doubt. high modern buildings, luxurious shops, good restaurants and wide avenues, this is Giza - the heart of Tokyo.
Uppity up!. The upscale neighborhood, the smartly dressed people and the genuine high end vibe is felt throughout. We loved this area!

Good spot to locate in. Lots of restaurants, shops galore, some very expensive and some average. Very Handy to walk to the JR line, plus once a month they have a outdoor Antique market at the Tokyo Forum.Seven eleven near Krispy Kreme donut shop
Similar to the 5th Ave in New York. Lots of options, lots of stores for shoppers, designer brands etc. My favorite is the multi-level Apply Store.
