A Paradise For Those Who Love To Shop.. I was in Japan when I was young and missed going to the Ginza due to bad directions. We went there and stayed until late at night during this trip. We met a local stewardess who was kind enough to show us around. We enjoyed going to the big department store (Mitsukoshi) that had lots of food. Prior to that, we went to window shop in several places.We were there before Christmas so it was very crowded. We did not buy anything because we found everything cost so much more than the U.S.A. The prices of fruit really shocked us.

Bring the credit card. Great for a visit and to see the brands and posh shops. A&F store was awesome, being a fan of the brand. Illumination at night was a highlight. Worth a stroll just to see the fashions and luxury cars.
Too upmarket for us!. Worth a visit if you have the time, but very upmarket and westernised. Shops, shops and more shops! For us it was not as interesting as other areas of the city.
Shops, shops and more shops. If you love shopping, this is the place to go. All the brands are there and the streets are pretty at night with all the fairylights on.

Classy Ginza with Beautiful Shops-Cafes-Restaurants. Ginza Tokyo is a shoppers paradise with a touch of luxury.There are many boutique shops, including several department stores such as Mitsukoshii and Hankyu, and many many Brand name shops.The streets are Impeccably clean with wide footpaths around the main thoroughfare.If you can visit on the weekend then the main shopping street is closed off to Traffic from around midday to early evening.If you want to do a few hours of window shopping in Tokyo this is the place to go to.When you can't decide where to eat, the Department store Basement levels have an amazing variety of foods including many Bento boxes(Food Packs) at reasonable prices.

Brand street. Got some serious money and like fashion then Ginza is for you- the list of famous fashion houses is formidable. The weekend sees the Main Street closed and the window displays are remarkable

Upmarket and not so upmarket. I combined a trip to Ginza with the Hama-rikyu garden (which is just a few minutes walk away). Although Ginza has the designer shops (such as Prada and Burberry) it also has some high street names (such as Zara and Uniqlo). I visited a couple of the department stores and found the home wares, 'demonstration floors' and the food halls to be particularly interesting as they all provided a different take on Japan (as well as the opportunity to buy some unique souvenirs). Even if you're not a shopaholic, the main shopping area has some fabulous displays, great architecture and in January, some lovely outdoor lighting.
Upscale Shopping Gem. If shopping is your driver than this place is heaven, all the big names and brands are walking distance from each others.

Great Place for shopping and hangout. This area is very famous place for shopping and hangout. Lot of branded shop you can name it from Furla to apple store. This area also is easy to reach from narita airport by bus or train. At least 3 train station in this area. Lot of restaurant from western to japanese style. You could also easily find hotel in various price range.

No wonder it's called "Silver Mint". A fine, glamorous street that's one of the world's best shopping districts. Even if you're not the shopaholic type, you will be in awe upon the rows of designer boutiques and department stores lined up the main intersection. Fashion houses' flagship stores are located here, as well as technology giants. Some of the store buildings are designed by famous architects, modern and chic, that are very photo-worthy. On weekend afternoons the street is closed to cars, allowing for more shopping scrambles. There are also cafes and restaurants if you want a break. Great place to people-watch too. It would be more beautiful at night with all the lights. Include this in your itinerary!

Stay here. Ginza is the best location to base yourself in Tokyo. It's quiet enough at night, well served by the Metro and has just about everything you could need. Clothes stores may be a bit pricey and sizes are hard to get for westerners but i enjoyed staying in Ginza.

Excellent place to walk around. Gives you an idea of the scale of Tokyo. Thoroughly recommend going for a walk here, although all the shops are high end shops, so unless you want luxury shopping, you may not want to go shopping here.

Popular place. Even before I had entered Tokyo, I was aware of Ginza. It’s a pretty popular place in terms that it is an upscale neighborhood with lots of glimmering brands and restaurants to empty your pockets. This is basically a shopping hub and not a cheap one at that. But it is also one of the happening places around Tokyo so it deserves to be checked out.
classic district. where great restaurants locate! also a great shopping district. Less annoying than shinjuku. lots of luxury brand flag shop.

Glitz. I love Ginza. I don't shop in the glitzy stores, but it's a beautiful ode to capitalism, fine taste, and architecture. The department stores have wonderful food floors where you can pick up prepared foods for less than eating out, but there is an endless assortment of restaurants. At Christmas Ginza and Marunouchi are especially pretty with their illuminations.
Expensive and somewhat nice. Area good for upscale shopping and eating..everything is expensive and there are many westerners there.

Shopping for branded. There is Kabuki-za in Ginza. When you see this building, you are in Ginza. Ginza is famous for its shopping. There are departmental stores like Mitsukoshi and Matsuya. You can spend hours shopping and dining here. Always a lot of people. If you like to shop, this is the right place.

Fun restaurants , good shopping. We frequented may restaurants in Ginza, however many are only Japanese but you hotel can help you to order the great food.Mitsukoshi Ginza is great and has a decent sized shoe department.Not too far from many hotels

Shopping!. So convenient to reach the department stores like Mitsukoshi and Matsuya through the underground walkway from Ginza Station. Wonderful food markets at these stores. As with most areas around Tokyo, there were just so many people!

Ginza is full of hidden treasures. My favorites:+ Mitsukoshi Department store opening promptly at 10+ Food floors Matusya or nihonbashi mitsukoshi+Lunch at Michelin starred restaurants in area( bulgari, beige)+ Kyukyodo and itoya for stationary+ Ginza core building shabu shabbu or korean bbq>>>> amazing shopping district

Ginza shopping vs HK shopping. Been to both places several times and to me it is Ginza, hands down!!! Three reasons #1 bought my cartier watch in Ginza. Did not feel judged, like in HK (pretty woman in rodeo drive) #2 you can be sure in Ginza you are getting the real deal. Almost got duped in HK trying to buy a camera tsk tsk tsk #3 prices definitely comparable. Happy shopping!

Upscale shopping district . If you are in need of some new Versace or Armani or Louis then this is the place to come too . Or if you enjoy window shopping and people watching . Main Street is closed on a Saturday to allow better pedestrian flow . Explore the entire area as there are some nice resturant's in the area and some interesting shops . Take the train to Ginza .

Please do not miss this place!!. An evening must be dedicated to this place, if not more. The energy and opulence of Ginza is a visual treat. Fashion houses which are rarely seen in the best of malls have whole blocks dedicated to them. One can say that the area resembles a huge mall, rather a very interesting and lively one. No doubt, the area is expensive and shopping is recommended for people with deep pockets.Lots of good restaurants are also present around the main streets.A happening place that can only be felt.

Nice to window shop. . We visited here because we heard it was the best, upscale shopping district in Tokyo. It's very nice to look around in the department stores and a lot of high end boutiques but for us too expensive to actually shop at. We found the prices a lot more reasonable over on Odaiba for shopping. The area however is lovely and it's a good one to get a taste of the city.

Last on the list.. Ginza is tokyo's glitziest shopping district. It is here where you can find all the top brands in the world. During daytime, ginza would just be any shopping district anywhere in the world. But at night, the glittery, bright colorful neon lights transforms it into a shining, magical place. We went there on a Saturday night and the main avenue was closed off to vehicular traffic. Unless you want to buy name brands, I recommend ginza last on the list.
Upscale, very clean and safe shopping district. Make sure you got at night, where the lights creates a great ambiance that makes the Ginza world famous.

Eating Paradise. Great place to eat... and if you're a millionaire great place to shop! Hence we didn't buy anything. But there's a lot of food to choose from. If you head down (in the direction towards Tokyo Train Station) the underpass of the railway has a lot of restaurants located underneath. Book early or get there early because it'll be packed by dinner time.

A bit like every other shopping district in every other city.... Had a wander around Ginza, and all the posh big brand name shops are there, and really not all that much else to see. Nice enough, but not really one for a travel itinerary!

Same shops everywhere. We visited ginza during the day time and must be noted the high number of top end stores. If you are looking for the same shops as you find world wide then you are in the right place , if you are looking for japanese stores this is not your place. It's easily accessible by metro and look for exit 1 - 3 to get you to the shopping street.
Shopping paradise. One of the interesting shopping places in Tokyo if price is not a real impediment. Be ready to walk a bit. The Apple store is quite a sight to see and visit.

Ginza Even if you don't "shop". If you are in Tokyo , day or night, this is at least worth a stop . There are some places that embody modern Japan and the Ginza is one of them. If you are a shopper it is obvious . I'm not , but oh what eye candy. At least go to and have coffee . This will take a while to experience. It is also one of those "been there done that "destinations.

SHOPPING IN GINZA !!!!!!!. Ginza is huge and we went to the huge Uniqlo they have there. Loved going to Mitsukoshi and also ventured to some of the high end boutiques. So many stores!!!!! so many restaurants!!!!!!!!!! Ginza is also a MUST!!!!!
Shopping discrict, Expensive shops. If you like shopping then this is where you go!!!! All the high brands name brands etc. brands are here.

Shopping Galore. If you need to shop and are in need of some larger US sizes this is the place to go. We were able to find a Gap and H&M that had at least sizes up to L men's. They won't carry very many Larges and you might need to hunt for them, but they're there! Most luxury stores you can think of are here ie. Louis Vuitton, Tiffany, etc.

Ultra high end shopping. Fun place to walk around. While it is crowded like other shopping areas of Tokyo, the sidewalks are rather wide. The Japanese are quite fashionable. This is a fantastic place to see that fashion on parade. The architecture of the Wako building was aesthetically appealing. We had dinner in a restaurant on the top floor of the Mitsukoshi department store which was very good.

up-market. A heaven for shoppers travelling to Japan! Really you would find a lot of brands located in this area. Even Uniclo has presence at this place. Uniclo brand is good and pocket friendly. If you want other international brands you can find in the vicinity.

Interesting for the energy. This is a great place to visit just to take on the energy of the city and is youth. However, at times it did feel a little threatening and overwhelming. Great choice of restaurants and lots of people watching opportunities.

Shopping Street like 5th Ave. in NY. I recommend Ginza to every sightseer,it is like 5th Ave in NY.There is a big UNIQLO , GU and also duty free shop.Many good restaurants are there in GINZA.You can enjoy eating and shopping!!!

Great Ginza. Do you want a cup of coffee for $38? I purchased my last Mac at Apple Store Ginza and it was cheaper than buying it in UK. Loved very moment of being in Ginza. So safe even at night when I was carrying my Mac bag as a backpack (my Mac was in it).

Go to Omotesando instead of Ginza. It is an iconic área but Omotesando street in Shibuya-Harjuku área is nicer and more interesting place. The shops are refined and full of restaurants and cafés.Walking down in direction of Takeshita Dori street you will find lots of youngsters dressed diferente.

Big name shopping. It's big name shopping with top notch restaurants. It is interesting to say you've been there once but that's about it. Extremely expensive and lively. If you are into big-name shopping, this is the place...that is not what we travel for, however, and so take the 3 stars with that in mind. If you like this sort of thing, it certainly would be a 5.
Ginza is awesome. Saturday is the best time to visit. The Main Street of Gimza is closed to vehicle traffic on Saturday so it's a great time to visit for a walk. Always very lively.

Great fancy district. Ginza is probably the fanciest district in Tokyo, with top shops and restaurants. Although it is not specially charming, because of its central location it is quite convenient to stay here.

Stationary in Ginza. Hunt down the stationary store 'Ito-ya' if you like stationary. They stock everything. Beautiful Japanese rice paper to bound diaries, the tiniest pens you will ever see and heaps more. The store is 5 floors and if you like great stationary you will easily spend an hour or two here. Beautiful writing paper with matching envelopes and sealing stickers - they truly stock an incredible amount of beautiful stationary. Currently around the corner from matsuya in Ginza but this is a temporary shop - they are usually on the main street near matsuya.
Nice area for a wander. Ginza has lots of lovely shops and restaurants and is nice for a wander both during the day and at night.

very nice district. Fantastic shops, all the big names of fashion. Good prices due to the Yen devaluation. Small curious shops to be seen and visited.Despite the traffic and the thousand of people around what is impressive is the silence and the order.Visit it twice. In the morning and when in dark and shops are still open: the lights show is impressive.

Another Unique Part of Tokyo. One of the things that amazes me about Tokyo is that every region of the city is unique in its own way. Ginza is no exception to this. This was a great area of the city to walk through. Pedestrian areas are very wide so I did not find walking to be too crowded. There are many high end stores in the area, so shopping was out for me, except for the window brand.

Retail Therapy on steroids - don't miss the basement food vendors. No bargains in the Ginza on shopping but lots of great food especially those basement food marts. And if your okay with full retail prices there's no shortage of clothing, jewelry, cosmetics and gadgets. We enjoyed Shiseido's cosmetics store where we found out that visitors who spend over Y5,000 can avoid paying tax - as long as you have your passport with you.Stylistas should not miss the Mitsukoshi and Matsuya stores. Foodies will enjoy the food courts and the restaurants. There's even a darned good Kabuki theater (Kabukiza Theatre) for culture buffs.

Glitter galore, pearls, & beautiful food.. Best jewelry stores ever, even better then 5th Avenue in NY. The department stores have the most gorgeous food in the lower levels you've ever seen, including Harrods in London. A shoppers dream.

Luxury shopping district. It's a luxury shopping district very much like the 5th Avenue in NY. The restaurants are a little expensive. Uniqlo is a very popular and fair priced store. You should definitely buy a light down jacket for yourself.
It is just about shopping.. We thought there would be something special, but it was all about shopping. I wish that we didn't lose our time there and going to there.

Ginza Glitzy. Dress up,look fabulous, feel fantastic,you are in one of the most expensive areas in the world.
This is a place for the rich and famous, then you can have just go feel how it is being super rich to be able to afford to buy just about anything if not everything that is there!

SHOPPING, SHOPPING & SHOPPING. It is definitely a place you should visit, whether you have the time and money to shop is a different thing. We had coffee with our guide on the 3rd or 4th floor of the Gucci property. One of the classiest and most expensive coffee shops I have ever been in, it is not your "starbucks" but it was nice place to get away from the busy pace on the streets
top notch shops. if you want to shop in the 'Bond Street' of Tokyo this is the place to go. Fabulously expensive shops but terrific to window show and look at the carrier bags people was carrying.

historical commercial area. If you compare Ginza to some other cities, Ginza matches 57th Ave. in NYC or Rue St. Honore of Paris, in my opinion. There are many high-end brand shops on the main street as well as interesting long-established stores and resaurants if you get into "back-roads".

High end shopping . It seems this is where the well to do of Tokyo shop and unless you've got gazillions to spend, then your pretty much just window shopping. In saying that, just the architecture of these buildings and how much real estate they occupy are something else. LV, Bulgari et all are here to make you salivate.

If you are a shopaholic.... This place is great and full of lights in night time but only if you are a luxury shopper or a shopaholics you will very enjoy this area.. You can find all western brands here and so do the famous local brands..most people come to buy the Japanese Burberry which only can find and produce in Japan. There is a Black Label for Men and Blue Lable for Woman.. They said it is cheaper than the British Burberry with same quality but for shopping I will say I enjoy the Premium Outlet in Gotemba just before we went to Mt. Fuji.. I am a budget traveller and love to discover all discount items with good quality and I found out the Gotemba Premium Outlet is so much better than shopping here in Ginza. The brands is all about the same but the Gotemba offers better price especially for the Nike Brands, GAP and Coach NY. I just enjoy watching people in this area while sipping my Starbucks and I save most of my money by deciding not to buy anything.. It is just not worth to buy all this western Brands when you can buy it at your own country with the same price..save your luggage space and avoid regreting of over shopping. The best time to go is during weekend as the roads was close for transport so you can walk without worrying being hit by car or waiting for the red lights to turn green.. It was a high-end shopping distric and of course is is a very busy place with bustling tourist..

Ginza, once was famous. Ginza once was notable for the most expensive property and high end retail. Its still all there, but a bit of a yawn really. Lots of middle age rich Japanese ladies on the prowl.

Picturesque but boring. This is marketed as the ultimate shopping paradise but ultimately it's one of those places that contains a lot of over-priced department stores and cafes and very little to see and learn, even the merchandise is very western focused - think a US$540 for a non-leather handbag, brand "Furly" (??). It feels very fake, with smiles plastered onto faces to justify the inflated price tags. Very clean, as you would expect from an expensive plaza but really shouldn't have bothered with this one.

Very Disappointing. We were so excited to go to the Ginza district. We knew what to expect having shopped on 5th Avenue and Rodeo Drive. Well were we ever surprised! We went on a Friday night, and the area was dead! All the stores closed at 7:00 pm. T he lights were pretty, but they weren't anything like the night lights and excitement of other areas in town. Maybe things are better in the day time.

Great for Luxury Shoppers. The final stop of the day was the Ginza district, an upscale area in Tokyo reputed to be the most luxurious shopping district in the world, where numerous department stores, boutiques, restaurants and coffeehouses are located. Since we were there on a Saturday, the streets were closed to traffic, which was tremendously convenient.
If you like fashion shopping. it was worth a stroll but I wouldn't go out of my way specifically but on a warm autumn night it was good to window shop and to watch people

Shopping Paradise. This area is the High End Shopping Street.
Especially good area for the Shopaholic....
For me, it's more of the been there done that....

Ginza - shiny Ginza!. Well same as Omotesando boulevard what you have here is some down town high-end shopping plus some truly high-end modern architecture... and it is even on bigger scale than in Omotesando... We found it very interesting to visit this part of the Tokyo both during a daylight as well as in the evening when everything is even more shiny and glittering... So if you want to do some shopping well prepare a lot of money... but if you just want to take a walk and admire some architecture check your camera's batteries and go!
well if you like shopping.... huge high end shopping district. maybe a good option if you're looking to relax or hang out after a tiring day.

Strolling the night out. Where traditional culture co-exist with the modern era, such a nice place especially at night. Witness this bright city come to life as it lights up and glows beautifully. Highly recommended for fashion-istas and shopaholics. A lot of high end branded stores in this area. P.S - also a perfect place to see Japanese women in their traditional clothing - Yukata and Kimono.

Window shopping is fun Too.. Really nice and trendy area. I enjoyed walking around and going into most of the shop. Most of it is a little bit too expensive for me, but there was a lot to look at and street were completely closed on Sunday for everyone to walk around.

Up market town. Things are expensive there, you should go to Shinjuku/ Asakusa/ Shibuya...for dinner as there are more options. The shop I like there is Shiseido the Ginza, it's special as it has all Shiseido brands but the prices is dearer than drug store.

Disappointing. Maybe I was expecting too much?This is just a high-end shopping street that can be found in most of the world's big cities. I was also expecting a lot more neon and glitz, but it's just not there. The places worth seeing are the food basements in the department stores.Still, if you're in Tokyo you have to check this off your list.

Hold unto your wallets. You will be spending in Ginza. Ginza catches your attention for the high end products that you can get tax free. It is also a great place to eat. You should look for the sushi restaurants and check out the swatch store.

Fun to Visit...and Tempting. I hate shopping, but Ginza makes you want to spend money. The shops are beautiful and relatively quiet. The sales people are attentive, yet not overbearing. The merchandise is beautiful and high quality and (all things considered) not as expensive as I thought. It worth taking a look.
upscale shopping area. Ginza is the fifth ave. of japan, many upscale shops and department stores, restaurants in different cuisine, lots of upscale clubs too. easy metro access
Dining, shopping - Hello Kitty mania if you like cutesy stuff. This colourful and lively area has a great variety of eating and shopping options. Day or night this place is alive.

Japan's Upscale District. Visited this area briefly. It reminds me of New York city with the tall buildings and upscale shopping. We visited the Ito-ya shop for stationary supplies. Would like to explore the area more in the future
Shoppers Paradise. This is the famous shopping district of Tokyo which boasts of signature brands like Hermes, Prada, Gucci, Louis Vuitton, etc.It also abounds with pricey restaurants.

Amazing shopping district. Luxurious but very attractive, it's a place to visit in the weekends as the main streets are closed to cars on Saturday and Sunday. A great place to hang out, shop, look at great architecture and enjoy good and varied food.

Cosmopolitan shopping supreme. If you like cosmopolitan city centers, this is the place for you. Worth to see it and be seen, as in New York's Fifth Avenue or the central boulevards in Paris or any high street in London.

Lots of shops. Lots of shops but you need a lot of time. They have all the name brands, local shops, art shops, many restaurants. They speak English in most places. The cabs normally don't speak English. The food is great in most restaurants but a bit prizy. I could have spent 3 hours just at one store.

5th Ave in Japan. So if you like 5th Ave. in NY then you'll like this. it's cleaner, people are nicer and there is just as much "stuff' to purchase. At night its great to see all of the lights. In the day it still has tones of energy. It was fun but you would only want two days here.

Mileage will vary depending on what you're looking for. If you just want bright lights, lively streets, and high-end shopping then Ginza is a 5-star experience for you. However, if you want something that is distinctly Japanese like I did then look elsewhere.Having it's own subway stop - Ginza station - on the Tokyo Metro and only 2 stations away from Tokyo station, the area is centrally located and easy to get to. The streets are filled with the typical high-end brand name stores from across the world and everywhere you look restaurants, bars, and clubs providing a decent nightlife scene. Be sure to look up and down as every floor or basement can contain a store or club you might miss. It's a nice place to walk to kill some time, do some window shopping, and just see the night lights.Honestly though, there isn't anything here that you wouldn't see in a city like New York or the streets of Hong Kong. If you're making a trip from a different country to visit Japan, I would advise you to spend your time somewhere else to experience something uniquely Japanese.As an aside, if you do find yourself here and want food, check out Umegaoka Sushi no Midori Sohonten (do a Google search with that full name). It's a sushi restaurant with some pretty amazing set meals for great prices. It should be easy to spot, as it's under the train track and there always seems to be a line out the door - be ready to wait ~20-30 minutes to get inside. Just use the machine in front of the entrance to make a reservation and take your ticket. Sit, strike up a conversation with your neighbor, and prepare yourself for some awesome sushi.

Good shopping area, if that's what you want. It's a place you need to visit when you come to Tokyo, especially for the first time. If you want to go shopping, there's a great concentration of shops and countless restaurants. On the downside, there is no real distinction between the shops found here and any other large shopping area around the world. Nevertheless it's good for a walk especially if you want to eat out because there is something for everyone. My wife and I enjoyed the Ginza and are glad we went. I recommend you do the same, but don't expect too much.
A touch of 5th Avenue. A visit to the upmarket shopping district of Ginza is a must if not for anything other than visiting the incredible basement food hall of Mitsukoshi Department store.
Kind of sterile. This area could be anywhere in the world, nothing uniquely Japanese about it. It's essentially just a bunch of large high end retailers, nice for window shopping and that's about it.

Had to see it. I had to visit the place with the most expensive real estate on the planet....though I couldn't afford to shop there,nit was great to visit. The lights in the evening were awesome. The atmosphere was exciting. Had to see it.

Super busy place but all the premium brands (and more). I was there on a Sunday and the main street become pedestrian only. You get the rare chance to take picture, cross the road and generally walking around without fear of the normally busy street.Whatever premium brand you want to have a look, it is more than likely you'll find it here. For slightly more mainstream stuff, there are several department stores in the area. If you shop a lot, make sure to utilise the coin locker facility found at train station or in the department stores.

Great place to walk-In. Ginza area is one of the best places in Tokyo to walk in especially during the weekends when all roads around the area are closed up to evening time It's highly recommended for shopping and walking.
Food. Great sushi places, plenty to choose from. Everything is fresh and made right in front of you. All within walking distance

Great shopping district!. Spent a few hours walking around in Ginza. There are a lot of high end stores and sights to see. There are great restaurants everywhere. I really enjoyed visiting the Yamano Music store. It is a five floor store full of everything music; instruments, recorded music, sheet music and a lot of great accessories. I liked the wide sidewalks on many of the streets which made it easy to stroll and look without getting run over.
Take a walk!. High end shopping but even if you cannot afford it (or do not want to spend that kind of money), it is nice to walk the area. The wide street was impressive to us in itself.

A place to see. It is busy area with a lot of people. Most shops close at 8pm. The price of the area are high. Doesn't buy goods over there unless you have local friends guide you. Be aware of complex of public transport. Make sure you find your way back easily.

Best Place for Window Shopping. Ginza (銀座, ぎんざ) is one of the world’s most famous shopping areas, like Fifth Avenue in New York and Avenue Montaigne in Paris. Ginza is a district located in the Chuo, Tokyo. Ginza was a swamp in the 16th century. During the Edo period, the government established the silver-coin mint (Ginza means "silver mint" in Japanese) in 1612. Since then, people have called the district Ginza. After a serious fire in 1872, the Meiji government had chosen Ginza as the "model of modernization” and started using brick instead of wood to make buildings fireproof. Because of that, Ginza was criticized to look more like western city rather than traditional Japanese, Edo style city. Today, most of the western style buildings were dismantled and only a few are left. The most famous is the Wakō building with its Hattori Clock Tower. There is a well-supported policy in the Ginza area that set a building height limit for the Ginza commercial area at 56 meters in 1998. You can enjoy a comfortable atmosphere when you walk down the streets. Ginza is one of the most expensive real estate areas in Japan – 1 m2 (11 ft2) of land can easily cost you over 10 million yen (US$ 93,200). We stayed at Hotel Monterey Lasoeur Ginza right in the center of Ginza. It takes only few minutes to walk to the Ginza main street (Chuo Dori Street). The Ginza main street covers from Ginza 1-chome to Ginza 8-chome (銀座1丁目 ~ 銀座8丁目). We were there on a Sunday afternoon, and we were surprised to find that the main street was closed to traffic and had become a large pedestrian zone. The street closure started from 12:00 to 17:00 on weekends. It was an unusual experience where we could walk on the usually busy traffic road. I certainly wasted no time in taking photos of those beautiful shops with ease. Ginza is Tokyo’s most well-known upscale shopping, dining, and entertainment area. We saw many big-name department stores, world famous designer boutiques, unique stores, art galleries, clubs, and restaurants. We all know that Tokyo is one of the top 10 most expensive cities in the world. The price tag on most of the merchandise, even regular bread, is very expensive. Personally, I like the window shopping after the stores are closed. The window displays at each store are very creative, and I can take photos without the interruption of people passing by. If you are tired of eating food at restaurants, you can try the bento (food box) and readily cooked foods which you can take away with a very attractive discount on the basement of Ginza Mitsukoshi Department Store before they close at 8:00 pm.The best way to visit the Ginza is by taking the Hibiya, Marunouchi or Ginza Subway Lines to the Ginza Station.
the heart of the shopping district. great wide streets with lots of designer stores and side streets with other local shops and restaurants.

High End Shopping District ~. This place is a high end shopping district. But if you are looking for branded, this is the place. Expensive is the way to described but their customer service is tip top, the best. Able to pop in and take a look, no harm for tourist because every of their building is design uniquely and the whole building actually do belong to one 'brand' individually.
Shopping district. Not my type of place. Upscale shops like in every big city...Japan is expensive so dont expect bargains.
If you have the money.... ...it's all there. Expensive, very expensive, but worth a stroll to do window shopping at least.Every kind of luxury you can imagine. Shopping at its finest.
Expensive..high end. Wasn't able to buy here because all shops are high end indeed! just had a look just to say I have been in the high end area of japan :D

Nothing opens until 11 so come after if you want to shop. I arrived at 10 which was too early for shopping but ok for window watching. Couldn't even find a coffee until after 1030. Once 11am hit the crowds rolled in. The window of Commes de Garçon was amazing and the Uniqlo shop enormous. Would love to come back when the neon was on

Shopping street. In some ways it reminded me the famous 5th Avenue in New York. Must endorse and why not ... maybe buy something ..

Unique with a great mix of tradition and modernity. Walk the streets to experience the sights, sounds and smells of this wonderful destination. Unlike anywhere else in Japan and unlike anywhere else in the world!

A town with 2 different faces. Ginza is known for "high-end" shopping & major corporation/government offices. I like Ginza at night. It's vibrant, energetic and beautiful with all the street neons & lights. There are plenty of great restaurants/bars and boutiques, great access from any parts of Tokyo, taxis are everywhere, and even just walking around the town is fun.

The middle of Tokyo, Ginza. If you will visit in Tokyo in the future, you must visit there. You will encounter world wide brands like Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Tiffany and so on. You can feel how elegant and noble people there, too. You might want to visit other places such as, Shinjuku, Shibuya, and Ikebukuro, but it would be hard to feel relaxed and go shopping because those areas are always jammed. However, you probably wouldn't feel jammed if you visit in Ginza and you can enjoy shopping, dinning, and sight-seeing. Oh, by the way, my company has opened a chiropractic clinic in Ginza on July 15th, so please visit us if you need a total body cure.

great quarter. really great for shopping, not only the luxury labels, but everything. The department stores Matsuya, Waku, Mitsukoshi and Takashimaya are a must. Walk all the Chuo-dori up to Nihonbashi, and come early in the morning (before 10) to take a goodlike at the buildings befor the masses arrive, especially on Saturday and Sunday.

Loved it!. Ginza was quite far away from my hotel but it was worth going!
I spend almost whole day walking around it; shopping, and just having fun.
There's a lot of expensive designer shops, but you can surely find some lovely things at (let's say) normal prices.

The Ginza $hopping District. While in Tokyo, visiting the Ginza district was on my list. We spent about 4 hours exploring this extremely high end area (Hermes, Cartier), and quite frankly just people watching. The area was electric with youthful energy and smartly dressed business people. We did a lot of window shopping, and stopped at a small bakery for lunch and a cold drink.

A fun shopping experience. The Ginza is where you can shop, eat, walk, and people watch. What's nice is on the weekends they actually close the street off to vehicles and so you can freely walk down this huge boulevard, flanked by big department stores and boutique luxury stores alike. If you want a "hipper" shopping experience, you'll probably want to go to Shibuya and head over to Omotesando Hills and Harajuku, but the Ginza has that legacy with it, so you'll want to definitely go over there on a weekend.

Bright & for high end shoppers!!. Heard about it so much then finally see it for my own eyes!! Definitely a place to visit if u come to Tokyo!! Beautiful colors!! Bright lights!! All classy brands building around!! Best to window shop before u start to spend there!! Varies is more than in Singapore!! Service number one!!

Joyful and colorful.. Every time being in Tokyo we visit the Ginza place. We like it for vibrant life, small bakeries, small Japanese food restaurants, great architecture, beautiful people, night illumination, 12 story Uniqlo stor, Maneken waffles.
A little champs élysées. For the lovers of Louis Vuiton, Chanel and other luxury French brands :) ( and Italian as well ....)

Not what I expected...but Great!. The Japanese fashion is something very enjoyable to watch and experience, although many foreign brands dominate the spectacle, it is fun to eat something and visit a few local stores.

Class and sophistication every step.. Apart from the throngs of Chinese mainland bus tourists.Every type of designer store foreign and local can be found here, as well as the 2 of the best department stores carrying designer brands.However it is unlike New York of other capitals it still retains a uniquely Japanese flavor and the ubiquitous Japanese hospitality and respect for others.Spend at least a couple days in Ginza enjoy the shopping and the food in the out of the way restaurants, look for the signboards on the front entrance of buildings and showing the floor level eg: 5F, for eateries you will not be disappointed.
Best spot for people watching . We could not help but notice the high fashion of the locals. We sat back enjoyed coffee and ice cream while people watching. Sweet.

High end shopping for those in the mood. We went to check out the Ginza bot because we wanted to do any serious shopping. It was ok, but I would recommend this more if you were serious about buying designer clothes.

People Watch. This is a shopping area that attracts lots of Japanese, and therefore makes for wonderful people watching. If you have jet lag and need a destination to adjust to your new time zone and megalopolis vibe, check out Ginza.
Champs Elysses of Tokyo. Beautiful shopping district. Trendy high end fashion houses. Lovely ambience. Just note that most shops close down by 8:00pm!
Nice strip. Great shopping district with lots to see and do as well as trendy nightspots and cool restaurants. Go in the PM to get the real feel of Ginza

Bright lights at night. Went to a German beer and sausage place. Lots of window shopping, bought a some bean-paste goods. Passed through this area twice, once during the day, once during the evening. Slightly different atmospheres. Plenty of shopping. Was not part of a tour this time.

"Stylish". The Ginza is Tokyo's most famous upmarket shopping, dining and entertainment district, featuring numerous department stores, boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, night clubs and cafes.One square meter of land in the district's center is worth over ten million yen, making it one of the most expensive real estate in Japan. It is where you can find the infamous $10 cups of coffee and where virtually every leading brand name in fashion and cosmetics has a presence.Most shops in the Ginza district are open every day of the week. A visit is most pleasant on weekend afternoons when the central Chuo Dori street is closed to automobile traffic and become a large pedestrian zone. The road closure takes place from 12:00 to 17:00 (until 18:00 from April through September).The most convenient stations for accessing the Ginza district are Ginza Station on the Hibiya, Marunouchi and Ginza Subway Lines and Yurakucho Station on the JR Yamanote Line, JR Keihin-Tohoku Line and Yurakucho Subway Line.
Shops. If you like high end shops this is for you. If you don't give it a miss. I couldn't see that Ginza had anymore to offer than the shops.
Best shopping in Tokyo. We found Ginza both stylish and high end fashion design. It is not crowded and has selection of coffee shops. Much better for shopping experience than any other part of Tokyo.

you've gotta love Ginza. The beating heart of Tokyo, the wealthiest neighbourhood and home to some great beer halls. I have always enjoyed my time in Ginza and Japan for that matter, and it's a great day or night out.

Most places are expensive with two exceptions. Ginza have all these name brand shops where it seems only the wealthy mainland Chinese can afford to shop but for a poor salaryman like me, there are two reasons to come to the Ginza!They're called Uniqlo and their cheaper cousin, GU! Only 100 metres from the A2 exit at the Ginza station and you'll find reasonably priced good clothing!This Ginza store is their largest in the world and is 11 stories! Just down the road back towards the subway is GU, recently opened with prices a little cheaper and I bought a pseudo green leather jacket for 5000 JPY here. Unless you're absolutely loaded, just make a bee-line for these two shops, you won't be able to push the Chinese shoppers with wallets full of cash out of the way in the other stores! Have fun and buy a lightweight down jacket at Uniqlo for 5000 JPY! I bought three as I can never make up my mind what colour I like best! Oh, saving the best for last, if you're a gaijin (foreigner), take your passport to GU as they'll give you 5% off! Happy shopping!

Great place to shop and walk around at night. The feel in this area is amazing! I loved walking around here and shopping around and finding a place to eat. It is really something! Try to get a place that is in a high tower so you can over look the area, there are a few!

Another New York City shopping district. There's something for everyone here. Large department stores and many small shops for all ages.The large department stores have great food floors to buy prepared meals and desserts to go. At Mitsukoshi, you can eat your "take-out" food purchased from them on the 9th floor which includes an outdoor area for families and kids.

Go at night for all the lights and decoration. I was there at night to just look at the decoration and all the signboards of all the brands. It is one of the most high class districts in Tokyo.
Even though you may not be able to afford the stuffs over there, just go there and take some nice photos and stroll down the street.

Another high end shopping strip!. If you are looking for high end shopping then Ginza is for you.... but as a tourist attraction I really can't see the point. There really is nothing special there just high end shops.
As someone who can't speak/read Japanese I found it a little pointless wandering through the shops.

Lively, beautiful and great social atmosphere.. We walked up the Ginza with good friends from the Mandarin Oriental hotel. This area has several large stores with notable reputations but also some specialty types of shops selling stationary items, wrapping papers, and origami papers. Watch your direction when you enter some of the big stores with several entrances...we made a wrong turn and had a nice tour of Tokyo! The stores are all nicely decorated and fully staffed so you never wait long for assistance. You can't go to Tokyo and not experience The Ginza!

Just Like Every Other City. Ginza is a high end shopping area in Tokyo, but it does not seem any more special than other high end districts in the countless other cities I have visited. Actually, the best things there are Japanese - the massive UniQlo clothing store and the equally big Matsuya department store, with the latter having a huge basement food court like all other Japanese department stores.

great area. Ginza is a great area of Tokyo.. so much to see and do.. all the high end shops can be found here.. some folks from the UK might call this main street "high street" you can find everything your looking for here.

Upmarket shopping.. Ginza is classy, sophisticated, flamboyant & buzzing with expensive upmarket exclusive shops such as Chanel, Gucci, Armani, Burberry , Christian Dior, Louis Vuitton , Prada & many other international brands. We were staying in Shinjuku which was fabulous too but visiting Ginza for a day shopping I wished I had stayed in this area as its more central with exciting shops, departments stores, Art Galleries, restaurants & the famous Tsukiji Fish Markets.

Upper class shopping. Ginza is great if you want to do some shopping. There are plenty of boutiques and high level shopping to do here. There is about 4-5 department stores in Ginza plus some traditional Japanese shops that specialise in traditional Japanese food to traditional Japanese goods. The staff in the stores are very friendly but their English is very limited to none whatsoever. In Ginza you'll also find some Western Style cafe's and a sandwich shop (Subway). There is no Western style take-away in this area for people who don't want to try Japanese food. There is also a large Apple store where you will find English speakers.

No compliant but pleased with my choice to stay there. Clean, orderly, many high quality stores, 12-storey high UNIQLO flagship store now on sales, nu numerous good restaurants of different price levels, safe and refreshing, well served by subway/railway systems.But of course, I would still miss Shinjuku and actually left Ginza for one day there. They are so different.

Amazing if very westernised. This is a "must see" location. Huge, busy and sophisticated. Acres of shops but many sell huge amounts of top end western goods. Reasonable prices for sterling, but not much fun if you seek Japanese clothes.
Shop til you drop- or just enjoy the sights!. Top end shops galore, myriads of elegantly dressed Japanese, Tokyo traffic! Then at midday on Saturday, it all becomes a pedestrian mall! Amazing!

high level shopping area. in the last day of my japan tour, we visit ginza for shopping stop.
there are many branded shop arround here..
suitable for high class tourist..
if for me ..i prefe go to gotemba premium outlet rather than ginza

Must to do in Tokyo. Window shopping or shopping literally. We had a great time strolling through the area. Some stores offer samples to try. It is a great experience to mingle with locals and tourists.

The Place to be Seen (& to people watch). Ginza is Tokyo's up-scale shopping district. It is Japan's equivalent to New York's Park Avenue, Paris' Avenue Montaigne or Melbourne's Collin St. It boasts all the big brands; Louis Vuitton, Bulgari, Tiffany, Gucci. It even has a Harrods. Don't expect too many bargains, although I was surprised when my wife returned last weekend with bags full of bargain kid's clothes she bought at a H&M sale. The main strip, Chuo St, has some high-end eateries and tea houses where you can see well-heeled ladies cooling their heels and comparing their purchases. Don't be surprised if you see small groups of local girls or couples in traditional Japanese dress or elegant older folk strolling the boulevard. It has a less pretentious vibe than many of its' contemporaries in other countries, it seems the shoppers here haven't lost sight of the need to have fun. You must visit Ginza if you travel to Tokyo.

For High End Shoppers. Don't expect many shopping bargains on this high end area of Tokyo, window shopping is less expensive. Virtually all high end brand names are represented but don't expect discounts

Ginza- shopper's Ph.D. Pedestrain street on sunday, the Tokyoites are so fashionably dressed while shopping in their department stores. Finding an unagi restaurant that has been around for more than a 100 years old -Miyagawa Honten on the 8th floor of the Matsuya Dept store was a treat for unagi lovers. Shopping at Ginza is not cheap but you can be assured the products have been tastefully edited-- so much temptations--simply cakes & cookies are presented in crafted packaging. We enjoy the food basement of the department stores at Ginza, from food gift treats to take outs (after 7pm watch out for 20-30% discounts on take out food items). Thee was a MOMA (museum of modern art) souvenir shop at the corner where there is Sony showroom -- I enjoy museum souvenir shop -sometimes more than the museum. You can acquire your Issey Miyake designer BaiBai shopping bag here. Tokyo is no longer the world's most expensive capital city- it now belongs to Singapore. $100 a nite hotels are now easily found throughout Agoda or Booking.com . Dining in Tokyo can be affordable --especially breakfast & lunch where the bento box (set lunch) are at promotional prices. You have great food and good shopping that awaits you in Japan :-)

It's a classic. A classic area of Tokyo, it's worth a look. Easy to spend a lot of time or just a little. Hard to say you were here and didn't come see! I'm not a shopper when we travel, but if you are, well ~ you will probably say it's paradise! And strolling just for the experience doesn't cost a single Yen!

Growing Ginzas... Ginza shopping 1 2 3Hi class shopping; just no fast foods eat in their fancy malls...Jr. Line to Shimbashi just follow the track head on foot without using jr line 1.40 yen cost to the yurikamome line is at the Shimbashi station. Shoppers paradise. We didn't have a lot of time here but from what I saw it was a shoppers paradise, mostly high-end brand names shops. but definitely worth walking around and window shop. :)
Busy shopping area. Ginza is a high end shoppers' mecca. Most people go there just for window shopping. It is always crowded.

Classy but expensive. The place is so cool. Neon lights everywhere. I think Uniqlo Ginza has the biggest store around the world. If you have money to splurge then you have to visit Ginza. Happy shopping!

A Day For Shopper~. I not a great shopper ~ here is a place mostly the famous branded here you can shop for ~ It's very long street if let's say if you want take a fast walk without stop from the starting and to the end i think also need around 20minutes for it ~ because as a shopper you would very like here because mostly famous brand shop like bag , clothes , shop , cosmetic , etc~ all is structure as whole building own by they only ~ it will spend your time in that ~ is a busy street too ~ is convenience due to there are a lot of metro exit available~ but make it clear if you are looking the branded thing you must do some homework because it really hard to find it if you not familiar is big~ or ask some information before you leave the station exit unless you do asking people around you~ if you are a great shopper , i do think your days is not enough for you~

GREAT SHOPPING. This is the place you want to visit if:1) Are looking for a very nice souvenir or detail to take back to your family and friends (I rev come a to go to Matsuya department store).2) Want to find very good restaurants to have lunch or dinner (Just note that 95% of all restaurants close doors between 2:00pm and 5:00pm)3) Wish to do some shopping (international luxury and casual brands, Japanese kimonos, etc.)I will add that I had my worst experience ever at a café in this street.The name of this venue is Café Paulista. Upmarket shopping and eating. No trip to Tokyo is complete without visitng the Ginza district - even if just to window shop given that this is very much the 'Paris end of town'. The shopping is fabulous, as are the restaurants. It is fast-paced, but in many ways surprisingly relaxed - see how the beautiful people in Japan live!
Think Fifth Avenue on Steroids. Wonderful store but very high prices. If fashion is your thing you wont be disappointed in this area.
Great to look - very expensive!. Loved it - stayed in the area and everything close! Shopping great if you are very rich but good to look!!

Excellent shopping.. If you're looking for shopping of a higher quality then Ginza is the place to go to. It's got some high street brands such as Uniqlo and Zara, but also higher end fashions such as Prada and Chanel, as well as department stores selling a range of wares. I thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere and busy streets, but not as busy as other places in Tokyo.

People everywhere. Very thickly populated but it's one f he main places in Tokyo to visit if you are a shopaholic. You need to stand on a corner of the street and watch the Japanese style of living and communication unfold. The main point to be noted is that the place is very safe and I have seen hundreds of people walking about with their wallets sticking out of their back pockets.
GLITZY & GLAMOUR. Far better than London oxford street,super posh,great deals and in the night looks like a sexy shiny place to be.

Lots of shops but costly. Ginza is just another place with restaurants and shopping arcades. We came here after our visit to Asakusa. This place is OK if one would like to do some expensive shopping. There's a Laox duty free electrical store here, which is not too bad but full of tourists. We reached around tea time and we opt to have a cup of coffee in one of the cafe there. The cafe was quite costly, a cup of coffee costed 12-14 Euro. We still prefer to hang around Shinjuku area.
Gone to Ginza. Neat restaurants and lots of unusual high end shopping. You can spend all day here without a problem. Highly recommend walking around here.

Good, but not very lively - Shinjuku is probable a btter choice for stay. We stayed in Ginza for 5 nights which is nice and elegant (pricey as well). But the area is not so lively at night as Shinjuku or Shibuya. If I could choose now I would rather opt for one of the two and not Ginza again.
Great for shopping. Got big bucks and like designer stores? Ginza is for you! But walk away from the bright lights to find small sushi or ramen restaurants down smaller roads.

Here, for a handful of things, you need a bagful of money.... A very hep, expensive place. I stayed close to the ginza area during my visit to Tokyo.You can find anything in this area right from stationery, lingerie, restaurants, fruits and so on... even people around this place are very fashion conscious. Almost every apparel brand - Prada, Zara, Bvlgari, Gucci, etc have their showrooms here. As far as I have seen, many showrooms and restaurants close at 9pm, some restaurants take their last order at 10pm. So, plan your shopping well. The main roads in this area are mostly 12-laned. I cannot forget to mention about the pedestrian discipline even on the footpaths, not just here but everywhere else also. A must visit place.

Shop in Shinjuku instead. For the same item, from the same store, Shinjuku would offer you a better price on the average. Ginza has all the high-end brand name stores. However, I was surprised to find a few hole-in-the-wall nice and reasonably priced eating places...you just have to try your luck.

Shopping, Restaurants, and People, oh my!. I wore my most comfortable shoes..... The most impressive display of shopping and restaurants i have ever seen and I wanted to see everything. Yes, the well known brands are there, but also, small boutique speciality stores that deserve attention. And, there is NO SHORTAGE of restaurants...Ginza has it all. The Toy Park is the best stop. Very fun street to window shop and find a good restaurant. You can find or buy almost anything in the world on this street at the highest prices. The Toy Park was a fun delight. Highly recommended.

Pricey but worth it!. Ginza's a great place to go if you're looking to do some upscale shopping or eat at fancy restaurants. It's a lovely area with a great variety of shops and places to eat. I'd highly recommend it to anyone going through the Ginza area.

The Tokyo that suffered from Globalization. not the best part of Tokyo - not different from any other big city, with the usual big shopping names and very little personality. Ive personally enjoyed much more to visit more authentic neighboroods than Ginza

Commercial area of the city. This is an area full of shops with nothing that special besides the Theatre at one end of the avenue. Comparatively I would strongly advice to go to Shinjuku, where streets, Buildings and shops are amazing!i would say not to waste time in this neighberhood.

Only for upscale shopping. Very little here to hold you interest if you want to experience the culture and history of Japan. The only good thing is that you can walk to the Imperial Gardens, Fish Market and Kabuki Theatre from this district...but as far as soaking up the culture or people watching...go to another district.

Shoppers paradise. It's all full with shops and restaurants. Heaven for shoppers and food lovers. A lot of restaurants and open until late night. It's a fun if you are for late night outings. Can not give a miss whirl visiting Tokyo

The Best Shopping. All the name brands are here, usually with multiple shops, from Mikimoto, Chanel, Burberry, Armani, Hermes .... Hermes the largest store I have ever seen. Abercrombie and Fitch, Zara, H&M and dont forget the worlds largest Uni-QloPeople from the USA may not think much of it because the cost of clothing in the USA is cheap anyway - but compared to pricing of things in Australia ..... especially H&M and Uni-Qlo, these places are cheap and the quality is excellent.
Lovely place. Lots of shops and restaurants, both affordable and expensive. If one can help it, you need not go to the other parts of Tokyo. Everything is here.

A big shopping street like many others. Living in Singapore, Ginza is just like any other designer-mad shopping street, stuffed full of Armani, Chanel and big designer brands. Aside from Japanese department stores, which are special, the street is like any other, and to my great disappointment, the shop I had come to visit had disappeared:- the largest UniQlo in the world. I was put out, but unable to ask anyone where i could find it! Frustrating!

Excellent shopping, beautiful park.. Believe it, Ginza is the perfect location for food, shopping, parks and the world,s famous fish market is a short stroll away. The price is reasonable for food and shopping although the general perception think otherwise. Perfect for making it the base for your Tokyo stay. Convenient transport and everything and anything is a short stroll away.

I love Ginza. Ginza is a great place to shop and I love Ginza. There are many international luxury brands Prada, Burberry, .... etc.. Staff are friendly and enthusiastic. My favorite food is part of their basement. Excellent food!

Great Place to shop for Label items. Ginza is a great place to shop for labels. From gucci to chanel to LouisVuitton.. Its all therefor you.. Ginza is a place where all tourist in Tokyo go. A must go area when visiting tokyo
Tokyo 5th Avenue. Ginza is plenty of expensive shops and is a paradise for the women and can be a nightmare for the men.

Many malls, boutiques, shopping haven. Love Ginza, its really a shopping haven.There's many international high end brands like Prada, Burberry etc and also local Japanese names like Uniqlo. Love the malls there too. There's levels and levels of shopping. My favourite is their basement food section. Great food!

Nice neighborhood, fish market is the highlight here. We visited Ginza mainly for the morning fish market which is quite interesting. At the adjustment all-round market you can taste various fish, plants and stuff that you've never eat again :)
The nearby kabuki theater has single act shows - go there for some rest. As a bonus you can enjoy the show. Personally, I did not.

biG dADdy oF FaShiOn sTorEs. .. this is the place to be .. if you love fashion , brands , desighners its all here .. its a little xpensive than other fashion hubs in the world but worth .. its on a very large scale with good eating hangouts too ..

Best luxury shopping area. If you are going for a shopping spree for designers clothes Ginza is the perfect place to go.all brands are there ,beautiful shops,you can find anything you need.A very pleasant area for shopping.
whole area. Easy to walk around with good landmarks to find where you are.3 metro stations in the area and 2 main line stations. Tokyo station is a terminal for Narita airport.

Ginza Style. Ginza is the style heart of Tokyo boasting all the top names in fashion. It is less rushed than most of Tokyo but retains the ambience. A walk turns up many hidden treasures in side streets with bargains to be found. A short walk to the palace brings parkland and peace. Food is abundant and there are Mandy's styled bars. A must see.

Shopping heaven-or hell, depending on how you look at it. Well, if you like shopping upscale, this is your place. I didn't see all of it, but block after block of shops from Tiffany to Bruno Magli, this is a place to melt every card in your wallet or purse.
Just the regular shops you see everywhere in the world. All the expensive fashion shops (e.g. Cartier, Louis Vuitton, etc) can be found here but more expensive than anywhere else.

Action in the heart of the city. Ginza is a great place to take photos, people-watch and shop til you drop. Even if you aren't buying anything, stopping in some of the department stores can be a fun experience. Mitsukoshi for example, is quite a place, ranking up with Harrod's of London in sheer size and variety. They sell everything from women's clothes to housewares and prepared foods. This whole neighborhood should definitely be experienced by anyone visiting Tokyo.

Lively and trendy. Chanel, Gucci, Hermès, etc....if you love luxury! Go for it.... The food courts are awesome!!!!! There is plenty to see and do there but it's a shopaholic's paradise. Yesn go fast so make sure you have enough ¥ 10,000 banknotes!

Fashion and beautiful!. Ginza is a very nice neighborhood in Tokyo. It is very well located, close to Tokyo Central Station, and have lots of stores and restaurants. Mizukochi is one of the main malls, and it gathers brands like Prada, Louis Vitton and other renamed in one single place! Ginza it's all about fashion!

Shopping. We visited Ginsa after having lunch at the fish market. It was a short cab ride to Ginza. At arrival it seemed slow and quiet. So we walked around and around 4 pm many of the streets were closed and all of the sudden millions of people are on the street. They put chairs and tables in the middle of the street. It was just awesome. I wish I can tell you if they do this everyweek, I wish I can ask someone. My wife said this is a week of a Japanese holiday. So may be they close the street for a special holiday? So many high end shops here.

Shop shop shop. Shopaholics, here's your heaven. The street is filled with tall buildings, with some going up to 6-7 floors. The main street was like a fashion show walkway with young and hip Japanese strutting their ways. A good place to visit with young friends.
Great shopping. It's great shopping place!! A good place to do all your shopping. Fashion designs are like top notch. Very fashionable and perfect for everyone
Fancy. Go here to see Fancy and rich Japanese. All stores are expensive and well known brands. However the food under the train rails is amazballs!

Street that has all the brands you could think of. Wow, this is a great place for window shopping ;) It has almost all the major brands you would have heard of. Its a nice experience to walk around this place in the evening when it is all lit up.

A nice walk around tempting shops. Japanese merchants really know how to do it. Their venues are very clean, they are polite and efficient. Therefore, with the help of attractive Ginza architecture, wonderful looking side streets as well as the main roads, it makes a pleasant walk.There are large department stores as well as charming small shops - all quite exclusive with interesting merchandise, especially ones selling Japanese lacquer ware and textile related products. All the international brands are there as well, but these are places one can find anywhere in the world.Watch your wallets - I say this NOT because the streets are dangerous, but if one responds to the magnetic pull of the shops and sales personnel, these shops can burn a hole in your pockets quite easily.
choices. great choices to eat in Ginza. from traditional japanese to portuguese, turkish, italian, indian etc.

Height of Fashion. Love just people watching the visitors to Ginza, but if you go there to not admire the fashion designs on display, be prepared to have a card with a high credit limit, as all the stores are designer and the restaurants are pretty expensive as well.

Iconic Shopping Area. This is the iconic traditional shopping area in Tokyo. There are newer upscale areas in Tokyo in which to shop but this was the original go-to place. It has always represented class, sophistication and affluence. While it has some age, it is still a great spot for shopping.

Shiny!. Equivalent to the high streets in London! Many big brands here!
We came at night so we could see the lights :)
There is also a car showroom there and there was this super cool looking car on display :)

Best place to go shopping in Tokyo. Ginza is a must for anyone who loves shopping and designer brands. Ginza has everything from Chanel to Dior and the most amazing department stores (Matsuya Ginza). Really easy to get to from the Tokyo Metro line and also has the best eats.

Shopping,stores and creditcards, like anywhere else, with a Japanese touch. If you have money to spend for shopping in Tokyo and you like typical places, or places like everywhere, just go there. Shoes are not so cheap, but definitely, the 12 floors Uniqlo worth the visit and it is even not expensive, much cheaper than in Europe. Here, probably the only Uiqloe where you have really good stuff for children....English speaking vendors has a special pin up...In the area you find some nice coffees and bars. Like in some other big cities in the world, you find here one the famous "ice bar", but easy to find some cheaper sushi (Bikkuri suishi), too. 10 minutes to walk an you are in the Imperial garden, 20 minutes by metro and you are in Asakusa, Ginza line is one of the most popular metro line in Tokyo.
Not to be missed. It is what it is like in the photo - a great place to shop, people watch and take great photos of all the lights. Highly recommend it.

*****Ginza at Christmas*****. I've only visited Ginza during the pre-Christmas season (and this has been several times over the past few years). Most recently last December (2013) and it never lets us down.This is a beautiful time of year and the meticulous detail the top level designer stores go to just to bring the Christmas spirit to Ginza has to be seen to be believed.I have some photos, but truely they don't do full justice to the entire scene.Ginza is for the most part the 'place to be seen shopping'. There are fashion stores and department stores with various levels of shopping budgets in mind. A short stroll and you can also visit the Kabuki Theatre on the edge of Ginza, even if you are not attending a show the actual Kabuki Theatre is something to behold.Back in the main area of Ginza you can shop for just about anything, so take your time and enjoy. Yes, you can see high end designer stores at many places through Japan and indeed the rest of the world, but Ginza has an atmosphere all of it's own. If you are there end November, to Christmas make sure you take a walk through Ginza's main shopping area early evening/night to experience the magnificent lights that bring an amazing spirit of festivity to the area.

Not a major difference to London, Paris and New York. It is like any other big cities like London, Paris and New York. It is very clean city(area) and people respect each other. Good shopping area but not cheap. If you want to buy cheap things then better not go to Ginza!! Good experience to go mind you.

Interesting area. Here you can go to the fish market and enjoy an excellent sushi or shopping in the best department stores in Tokyo. This area offers many thing to do while you are in this amazing city

High end window shopping. With reportedly the most expensive real estate in the world (and the most glamourous shops including one wrapped in a giant jeweled snake!) taking a stroll down the main street of Ginza is quiet an experience even (as I was) you're only window shopping.
Shopping Shopping And Shopping. I hate shopping. Probably not the best place for someone like me. If you like shopping, you may find this to be interesting.

Walk, shop eat and drink. This area is nice to take a walk during evening hours. I enjoyed walk along JR Train tracks. there are many restaurants, bars and grills. One can eat anything there - the food is really good. Don't worry about the fact that many restaurants don't have menu in English. If there is nothing you hate to eat, you can just point with the finger to any course and you will enjoy it. You can also walk up to the river near famous Tsukiji fish market. Of course there are many designer's shops where you can completely deplete your credit cards. :)

You can have a nice walk at the week end. This is a nice area to walk, especially at week end, where amny people will come to this area. Since this is a high-end goods area, so need to be selective when buying things.
pretty expensive stuff!. there are a lot of shopping places to go no matter where you look. just don't come on January 1 because most of the stores are closed and they close early on Dec. 31 as well.

Dior, prada, louis vuiton... expensive shops. there's some building to see ok but if you're not rich ... not so intersting.. so this shoping area just for one or to hours.but if you're in this area I sugest to see1) the business area 2) imperial garden..3) and If youre looking for typical and not expensive food have a look below train rails.. bests typicals adresses are there and better during the night (around 7 or 8pm)
Brand name Shopping area. All Hi-end brand name are on this road and not too crowed. Many good restaurants also here. Easy to come by train
Ants along the road. Loved everything, will buy non stop if I had no budget!! Yamaha floors are an eye opener. If it's sale season everything is too cheap.

Got money to burn for shopping?. Japan's world famous department stores shine here alongside some of the best restaurants in the world. Whether it the best jewelry, clothing or sushi, its here for you as long as you have plenty of Yen.

Branded Shopping Paradise. If you looking for original n geniune goods rest assured this the place to shop n buy...they have tall buildings just for their brands...like LV,PRADA,GUCCI,ARMANI, n etc...unfortunately we have only hours to spend so can't explore the whole areas...if fortunate you can find limited items wherelse can't find...

World's best shopping area?. Exclusive brands everywhere, each with their own high rise building.
Excellent selection, just not for the ones with a normal payroll.
Anyways, a must for everyone visiting Tokyo!

Shopping (and dining/food) paradise. Unfortunately, I only got to spend a few hours here. But if I had more time to spend, there's a good chance my rating would be higher. But Ginza is an easy stop from a few subway stations.I'm not a big shopper, but there are plenty of shopping options available as mentioned by the other reviewers. I was most interested in the food and dining options available, of which there are many. The highlight are the department stores' food departments, in particular Mitsukoshi, Wako, and Matsuya. I can't remember which one, but one or two of the food departments were the biggest that I saw in Japan (I believe it was Matsuya), where there's endless row after row, stall after stall of food for sale, especially Japanese sweets. This included the grocery stores and take out food places There are also plenty of food options on the upper floors of the department stores as well.The bright lights and people present were an attraction as well. The most picturesque is the corner where Wako and Mitsukoshi department stores are located. Again, I wish I had more time to spend here.

The Next Level of Shopping. I will preface this by saying that I generally hate shopping and malls, etc but I was absolutely blown away by Ginza. Yes, there are a lot of high end stores and that is interesting.....but the really interesting part is how the Japanese present the stuff. Everything is beautiful - they must so much work into the presentation, it is basically art. Even the food looks like it is in museum display.Very cool area - highly recommend.

Not for the faint of heart. I could not believe all the amazing stores they had in Ginza! I was staying at the Peninsula and it was just a few minutes away from shopping heaven. My head was literally spinning from looking at all the stores. Even if you do not intend on shopping, you should still take a little glance as there are so many fun things there to explore.

High end shopping but worth a look. Metro rail pass for $6/pp per day, makes visiting this an easy visit and worth the look. Pass was purchased at hotel. Worth googling use of the JR rail and metro lines before coming....and don't forget to bring the happy face for all the STAIRS!!! I think I'm down a couple of kgs and only been here three days

shopping paradise.... ...get ready for the credit cards to take a bashingloved these fabulous shops with their lovely sales assistantseven if you are looking to buy anything it is still worth a visit... especially to the sony building

Michigan Avenue in Tokyo. I always referred to Chuo Dori and the streets adjacent to it as the Michigan Avenue of Tokyo. There are a ton of high-end stores on this street. Even if you're not into shopping, it's still worth a look, as many of the buildings are quite a site.
Shopping Heaven. You'll definitely love Ginza if you love shopping! Great restaurant around as well and plenty of choices.

Shops close early. Great place for shopping. Go beyond the usual big brands, into the Japanese department stores. We found Mitsukoshi to be particularly lovely, especially the food floor (basement). Shops close early though, so this isn't a place to hang out after 8pm.

Enjoy shopping!. Wonderful place to buy, to walk, to explore international and sometimes expensive stores. If you like the feeling of megacities, go! Well, I reccomend if you just want to have fun, or if you want to go shopping. Easy to go by subway. PS: Taxi drivers usually don´t speak English, so bring the directions of your hotel in Japanese if you intend to come back by cab.

Upscale Shopping. For those who can afford it, the shopping is fabulous with every well know major brand there and for the rest of us, there is H&M, Zara and the huge 12 floor Uniqlo store. It is a great area in which to browse and people watch. The Sony Building houses an are where visitors can check out all the latest gadgets that Sony has to offer.

Very much like the 5th Ave in NY. We happened to be there on Sunday, when the street was closed for the traffic - made it more pleasant to stroll. Many side streets were occupied with the tea ceremonies. Was fun to watch, wanted participate, saw a LINE of Japanese people who were getting/buying (?) the tickets - all written in Japanese. And I already realized that time that people are very polite and helpful, but not many people spoke English. There is an Apple store, but not that ambitious as in NY.

okay. no need to come here if you are not interested in foreign shops in general. BUT if you want to shop for Uniqlo, GU, they have like 10 floors of shops! even H n M, Gap have huge stores here. dont be fooled by the 5250 yen luggage on sale along ginza. it is like that every day. probably cheaply made

The Real Tokyo. Forget Roppongi's English speaking strippers, Shibuya's "yet-another-shopping-metropolis" branded fake glamours or Harajuku's "we're so grungy" been there, done that vibe, or Asakusa's tourist trap temple walks - Ginza (and Shinjuku, and Ueno) is where it's at if you're after a taste of the real Tokyo - where company employees let their hair down after work, with geishas and their clients walking the streets and eating out, gloomy basement jazz bars and drinking holes, and hot steamy street food that only a Japanese can truly appreciate. Ginza rocks!

Nightlife , BBQ , Shopping center. I love Ginza!!On weekend, you can jump in front of Ginza signature junction because the road is close. People can stay relax and drink their coffee on the road. Love it!

Good shopping?. I do not really know why people are so excited about this area. It is great shopping, even though some is expensive, and that was the main attraction. We found the shopping similar to what we found in Harajuku. We sat in starbucks that overlooked the famous intersection out of many movies and that was about it for us?
Ok if you like shopping. I am sure if my wife had accompanied me this would have been rated higher, but as is it is ok place. Not much to do there unless you shop.

So-so place. I don't know what people are raving about. It's a shopping destination like what you'll find in Shinjuku - Isetann area. Just fancy department stores clustered together, that's it. But much much better than what you'll find in the lower end Shibuya.
Shopping by any other name. The ginza resembles any other upscale shopping area in the world. There was nothing remarkable about it. As a New Yorker it was a disappointment.

Cool place. Ginza is a must district in Tokyo. It's a typical commercial district, with lot of guys in suits, tall buildings and neo lights! What makes it particularly interesting is that it's in Tokyo, where all mentioned -above have its different charm.

Good option for kids of all ages!. My husband and I (in our 50's) spent a good hour wandering the floors here trying out all the tech gadgets. A neat place to spend a little time. On the ground floor is a very reasonably priced English Style pub with counter food and a beer to quench the thirst after a harrowing time on the 3D playstation!

Rodeo Drive, NYC 5th Ave, Champse Élysées, Ginza will eat your heart out!. Whoa, I may have had the best window-shopping experience ever! Yes, you read the key word correctly. What I enjoyed most: seeing all the posh and high-end stores, being greeted by the polite store staff, looking around freely without being followed like my previous experiences in few countries, endless things to look at on the street, clean and free public bathrooms, abundant eateries and friendly people.What I didn't enjoy: extremely expensive prices. Most things were triple the price of what I would pay in the U.S. For example: $50 for a shirt at GAP that would be $15 in the states..However, there were a few stores that had decent prices. Ladies, for a quick lunch and desert I recommend a tea cafe called Darjeeling Room inside one of the plazas that I missed the name.
