For around 1,100 yen you can get a pretty nice meal and a great people-watching experience. All in all, if you don't have a limit, shop till you drop and enjoy. Absolutely loving Tokyo!

Classy and High-end.. A lot of very High end Shopping and restaurant around this area, if you're willing to spend money there are plenty of great restaurants and high end department stores. But in general its a nice place to walk around, visit a few cafe's, and stop at a couple of the shops you don't see outside of japan. though i would recommend to reserve shopping more for shinjuku and harajuku.

Reminds me of Grafton Street, Dublin. We spent half day over here. This place is a heaven for shopaholics. It has a wide range of big brands and names around here. As i said, this place reminds me of grafton street in dublin.

Even If You Don't Like Shopping - You Need To Experience What It's Like To Shop in a Japanese Department Store!. I've been to Japan four times now and Japanese department stores never cease to amaze me. All of them are at least half a block/one block long which puts most U.S. department stores to shame! The only ones that I could compare are the Macys in NYC and SF but those are just the main branches. Outside of the major cities, Macys can be some little podunk outpost that wouldn't even fit in one floor of a Japanese department store. Also, Japanese stores are TRUE department stores with departments for electronics, toys, stationary, golf and other very, very specialized wares. For example, in Mitsukoshi they have a section in the men's department for cigars, lighters and other smoking paraphernalia. Toys in a U.S. department store? Golf? stationary? ha ha! Don't make me laugh! Stores in the U.S. don't even deserve to be called department stores anymore. When you go to a Japanese store, their sheer size inspires awe and grandeur - it's what shopping used to be in the major cities in the U.S. before the advent of the suburban malls. Another thing to experience is the Japanese focus on service, respect, and detail. When they open the store, UNIFORMED salesmen/ladies will greet and bow the first customers for the day. This may continue as you ascend each floor (as I experienced at Tobu Department store - they had personnel greet me on EVERY floor as I was going up the escalator). I will say that the prices are a little high but you can get bargains if you go during the sale season and even if you don't buy anything, you can always find bargains in the basement food court OR peruse the many restaurants that are usually in the top floors. I'm sure you'll find something within your budget.

Shoppers paradise. Walking through Ginza does have an American metropolis feel to it but definitely worth doing even if you don't have an unlimited budget. In rush hour the crossing is very amusing to see as it very much take your marks, get set, go!!!

Shopping shopping shopping. Did I say shopping? and not for cheap prices. If you like looking at nice brand shops go ahead and spend some time. It's just not for me. I prefer some other places.Maybe I should have gone to that Sony place over there. I just didn't have time. Maybe next time...
Their upscale street. If you like fancy shopping, this is the place. If you have not budget for that, you can walk around, must see.
Tokyo Time Square. All the major shops, cafes, restaurants, a nice way to spend the day browsing around and doing some shopping. Take advantage of the dollar / yen .

Upscale shopping and fabulous food markets!. We enjoyed strolling around Ginza. The main street is closed on Sunday, and there were lots of people milling about. Great people watching. Do not miss the basement level food halls at Mitsukoshi, particularly Johan bakery!

Lovely for a walk. We stayed in this district at the Mercure ginza. It's is a reallyLovely area to stay, plenty of restaurants, bars and shops. Very close to the imperial place and theatre. We loved just strolling around looking at all the restaurants and window shopping at the designer stores. In every all and small street and wonderful little oddity stores such as hand carved wooden clocks and silks.

The Japanese have style. Walking along the Ginza and and checking out their stores/ boutiques will give you a "high". The merchandise here are of topmost quality. Dining here can be pretty expensive...
Good for shopping and dining. More of a expensive area for shopping and dining. It's a great place, but not one I would choose if I wanted to travel on budget maybe.

Ginza - love it or leave it.. Ginza is a great place to visit because so much has been written about it, that you just have to see it for yourself. Ginza shops are undoubtedly up-market but then we knew that before we went there. Sunday in Ginza was interesting. It was a very hot September day so large umbrellas had been placed in the middle of the traffic-free street for people to sit under to catch their breath. People watching is good on Ginza. People on odd looking bicycles ..wearing outlandish clothes/hats ... with their pets all out for show rather than for the exercise etc. The Department store basement floors specialising in food were a delight to visit, even if only to try what is on offer. All in all, if you 'look' around you, you will find lots to see and experience in Ginza. Shopping isn't the end-all after all! Evening is best to view the famous Ginza crossing with its brilliant neon lighting. Lastly if you up to experiencing the skills of a sushi-master, Sawada is just around the corner. It beats shopping!

Bunch of shopping, commercial district, some cool lounges/bars. Really pretty area, lots of commercial shopping. Well maintained street areas, safe to walk around as is much of Tokyo. You can definitely find some cool lounges and bars around the area, but nothing too crazy. Not exceptional for nightlife, but good for a midweek exploration trip.

Meh... Not impressed. I walked through Chuo-dori to experience the shopping craze here.I realized this was probably not my cup of tea. Every store here offered high-end goods. While that may be great, it isn't too friendly on your wallet.On the other hand, it is indeed a good people watching location.

Seventh heaven for shoppers!. Just a dreamland for shopaholic. From local brand to designer stores everything you find here.It’s more towards high-end shopping but of course you do have mid-range shopping outlets as well. Depending on the consumers demand it’s an ideal place. If you not interested in buying still it’s a must visit vibrant street. It’s a whereabout for women to go crazy!!!

Shopping and cultural paradise. The Ginza is remarkable for a number of reasons. It is well known for the shopping which won't let you down due to the variety and quality on offer. There are dozens of restaurants offering a multitude of food styles and many of the streets are closed off on the weekends. Locals and tourists take advantage of a traffic free shopping area and many cultural and entertaining activities take place. Many Japanese dress traditionally which adds colour and beauty to an already stunning array of things to see and do. The Department stores, especially Floors B1 and B2 (if you like your food) are amazing as are the window displays. The staff show many of us from other cultures what real service and consideration is all about. If you are ever in Tokyo a day in Ginza, especially on the weekend should not be missed.

The true shopping mecca of the world. A while ago, I heard from a colleague of mine's that Ginza is "the shopping mecca of the world." And to this day that statement remains true. I actually research the Ginza district of Tokyo before I made my first, and so far only, trip to Japan. Finally when I step foot in Ginza, this place is like none other place(s) I've ever seen before. Ginza is a very large shopping area. I think it would take an whole week just to shop at every shop for those who is obsess with shopping. I must admit even I was drawn into this mystical area. Unfortunately, I didn't have much time to shop because I went with a tour group, but let just me say, I was really amazed with what was offered in those shops. I saw many things, from souvenirs to antiques, that I didn't see in America or even Canada (my home country). On top of that, Ginza have many different restaurants that serves good food. I had great Chinese food one day and Brazilian BBQ the next day. I believe Ginza is home to the International Cuisine scene in Japan. But of course, on the downside, every thing in Japan is so expensive. It always makes me ponder how can people live in Japan with the cost of living so high? Anyways, to sum it all up, Ginza is a great place to visit, especially if it's your first time there. The prices may be high, but it is definitely worth a trip to see what is it like on the other side of the world.

Shopping for the Above Average. Ginza is some of the most breath taking shops there are in the world. But it also comes with the price of shopping there. But the rule is it does not cost to look or window shop. But the one thing there that anyone can afford is eating in Ginza and the food in Japan is some of the best that I have eaten in the world. It is worth the time to see the area in the evenings with a romantic walk with your wife or girlfriend. The lights make you feel like you are worth as much as anyone shopping there. Just do not stay to late if you need to take the train to where you are staying the last train is around 11 PM Please note that I lived in Japan for more than 3 years and can tell you about many of the areas in and around Tokyo as well as Fukashima, Niko, Mito, and many other cities in Japan.
Paradise. The stores, so much to see and spend money.Too expensive. We went to a Germany restaurant ,the food was not too good.

Nice shopping highstreet - great brands. Definitely worth a walk down the main shopping streets, all the big japanese brands (including some very well priced Uniqlo clothes!) as well as International names. Worth a couple of hours whilst you're going between sight-seeing locations

High end shopping and eating. There are blocks and blocks of high end label stores found here, nothing at any world class city doesn't already have on offer. There are some excellent, but pricy restaurants here for dinner. Many of these are Michelin rated and deserve your time and money. The reconstructed kabuki theater is here as well, offering frequent performances for tourists. All in all this is a generic retail neighborhood which is much more picturesque at night.

When the going gets tough, shop at Ginza!. Ginza is a consumer paradise......shops shops shops, from high end designer label to mid range Japanese labels. This is a must do for all tourists .... Soak in the pulsating shopping vibe that permeates Ginza. Look out for the Ginza cats...and if you are looking for a gorgeous silk and selective Japanese silk ties go to Taya....not cheap but discreetly exclusive ; )

Viewing but not to shop. Would I go running to Ginza to shop ? NO. All the upscale brand name stores are here and all those fashion conscious shoppers that feel they must be seen in The Ginza are here also. Also the top Japanese Department Stores, including Mitsukoshi. It is considered to be another entertainment zone (like Shinjuku, but much more expensive) with museums, art galleries and lots of restaurants. But the intrigue is being here at dusk or nighttime and to see the hustle and bustle of this fast paced area, all the spectacular lights and the fact that you said you were in The Ginza. Also the Kabuki theater is here with the world famous Kabuki show. There are many coffee shops and bakeries, so sitting and watching the city move in front of your eyes is exciting. A must see if in Tokyo.

just another blingbling street. an uninspired cash neighborhood with all the big international fashion brands overrepresented. Only for the very rich. Boring for those who are looking for a cultural touch
Fantastic experience!. If you love shopping and have a fat wallet this is the place to go.Ginza is handy to everything, shopping, eating and wandering around at any time.Loved it.
All Tokyo in a district. World Luxury boutiques, traditional Japanese designers, very busy, With small traditional restaurants...Enjoy Tokyo.

Gorgeous but tooo pricy. If you are not on a budget and usually shop at the high end designer shops then this os the place to be....if you are for an experience I suggest going in the evening as the lights on the building are gorgeous....but reminder some stores close by 9 something.....you might want to try a cup of hot chocolate at a cafe on the street im not too sure of the name but i think its le doutour cafe.....its at a coner next to the subway entrance
amazing street. Wonderful street, specially in weekend wn they close the traffic, but course prices very very very expensive coz first all famous brands second u ring Japan

Yen'd out. All the upscale stores are there though there are a ton of other shops and department stores. Mitsukoshi is a large department store similar to Macy's and is more affordable. It has a 2 levels of food that were amazing. It was so crowded though. Could spend multiple hours just there.I would recommend going on a Sunday. They block off the main street through Ginza such that you can just walk down the middle of the street to easily go back and forth. They also place seats in the middle to rest and people watch. Numerous places to eat with all types of food.Close to the subway station and the JR line. Just bring a lot of money

great shopping. so many choices. the dominant is for branded shops. You find one whole building for one branded shop. some other lower priced brands like H&M and Zara are available. I like it there. good walk!
Upmarket. This place is high end, beautiful stores. Very expensive, not for the budget traveller unless window shopping! Great restaurants, like everywhere in Tokyo.
Ahhhhh great retail therapy. Fantastic area for high end stores. Great department stores to wander in. And great people watching. Just around the corner from great park as well.

Good for a stroll. This is like the 5th avenue NY or orchard road Singapore, but on steriods. The department stores are in the dozens, and each is a self contained Mecca of brands housed in 12 floors of space . Most of the stuff is medium to high end, but there are still uniqlo stores etc for the budget conscious . Plenty of food options as well, but probably overpriced. You are better off in the small streets of shibuya or ebisu. Talking about food, go to the basements of some of these department stores where they have the myriad of food available. It's an assault for the senses - the colors, smells and sounds are amazing. Kinda like the Harrods' London food hall, but on steroids again
Luxe to the max. Can't afford luxury brands. Nice to see and experience. Visit on the way to somewhere. The Japanese department stores are awesome. Nothing like Canada or USA

A more upmarket area of Tokyo, Astounding. This is one of my favourite areas of Tokyo. My primary reason for visiting here was to go to the Sony Centre showroom which is an absolute must if your in the area! This area is the area which is the complete contrast of Akihabara, this is the high end designer shopping area of Tokyo. Its full of fantastic places to eat and we ate here quite a few times. Its even better at night!

Great area to stay in. We stayed in this area, renting a flow the Home Away website. Excellent area with loads to do, and lots of very nice restaurants. Well an to come back to Tokyo and will definitely come back
Great restaurants and shopping. Could walk around all day and night, great atmosphere in the evenings. Great local restaurants everywhere!

Overwhelming. It's a nice place t take a walk and check some dept. stores but you will feel overwhelmed after a few minutes. Crowded and very fancy. If you think that 5th Av in NY is fancy you will change your mind after you come here.

Place To See The Beautiful People. Okay, it's commercialism rum amok. But Ginza at night is lots of lights, beautiful people, and fun. The UniGlo store is unbelievable front outside and within. Even the "alleys" have cool stores ad are traffic free. Pleasant place to spend an evening. And yes, the supermarket food courts are cool!

Ginza on a Sunday. When I was in Japan a few years ago my travelling companions walked the main shopping street of Ginza, browsing shops, buying gifts and enjoying it without traffic. I missed it - off elsewhere. I didn't miss it this time. My wife and I wandered the department stores, browsed the famous brand shop windows and paused for lunch in 'The Darjeeling' cafe (scored a window seat too - our lucky day!) and watched everyone else enjoying themselves. If you happen to be in Tokyo on a Sunday - head for Ginza for a pleasant shopping experience.
Great place. Busy place but everybody so friendly . Boat trip worth doing. Plenty of designer shops , so take plenty of cash with you
Glitzy Shopping. Upscale, western-style shopping - many famous department stores as well as flagship stores by several important brands.

Great place to explore by night. We were on a cruise and took the subway from Yokohama into Ginza to explore the area. It is Toyko's version of TImes Square and is a lively, upscale shopping district. Our friends bought some Pearls in a little shop and we stopped at a small restaurant (under the train line) for a snack of Sushi and beer.

Great shopping or just enjoyable to walk around. We went to Ginza on a Sunday when the main street is closed to traffic and they have tables and chairs on the street for folks to sit down. I've been to Ginza before, but have never really enjoyed it like I did on this trip because of visiting it on a serene Sunday versus a Saturday. If you have little time in Tokyo, try to spend an hour and just walk the main street on a Sunday and take in the atmosphere and people watching.

Restaurants Abound. There is a lot to see, eat and do in Ginza. Pace yourself and enjoy the sights. Most of the high end restaurants you have to book in advance, so if you're visiting and want to be spontaneous in choosing an eating spot, just go in and ask and if they can't accommodate you, move on to the next.

Nice and not so crowded Saturday afternoon visit. Visited on a Saturday afternoon when Ginza street was closed off to vehicles. Nice and easy walk without much of a crowd while visiting shops along the way.
shopping. very busy but awesome. Walk around and go to one of the small bars in the area like the 300 bar. Japanese people are very friendly!

Feeling right at home!. This city was very much like visiting 5th avenue in NYC. The streets crowded, in a good way. Beautiful designer stores, lovely window displays lots of neon lights and fun tall buildings. Definitely a necessary visit

Nice upmarket area. Great for shopping.. We stayed in Ginza one night. Seems like a very nice area, clean and upmarket. The main shopping street has everything your heart desires. Department stores have great food halls in the basement - TRY THEM!
Restaurants galore throughout Ginza. Nice place to walk day and night. People are very friendly and respectful.

Nice place to walk. Just walking around is pleasant. If time does not allow you to go more than once, you must absolutely go at night. It is so nice to be in a downtown area that is so clean and safe in spite of the crowd. The neon lights and building architecture is great. Most restaurants had very reasonable prices, most of the time it was lower than what we pay in Canada for similar meals. On Saturday and Sunday afternoons the main street turned into a huge pedestrian street (don't know if they do that every weekend) but it was just fun walking about.

Only if u want high end shopping...nothing abt Japan. Definetly a place to stroll and feels the glitters of Tokyo but akin to any high end shopping street of any developed country. If u wanna explore japan then this place is not in to be in. Found one duty free electronics shop (name ??) which was reasonably priced.

High end retail paradise. If you like browsing high end and boutique retail, then this is your place. Very chic and sophisticated neighbourhood. Lots of good restaurants to eat in too; a must see in Tokyo.

Shoppers paradise. I loved all the shops you could rile away your hours. Really easy to get to from Sumisho Hote- only 3 stops away.Matsuya Ginza department store is a great department store to visit, plenty to choose from. I ate at one of the restaurants on the 8th floor and was really happy what I ordered. It was a set menu for 2100 YEN.Across the road is Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Burberry, Zara, Armani, Max Mara, Gucci, Paul and Joe, Hermes. You name it. I also visited a great shop called, United Arrows and bought a few lovely items.There is a great souvenir shop called, Uno Hana (Rabbit Flower), which sells lots of rabbit souvenirs, kids toys and flower things, but top quality.I reckon I could have spent three days looking through Ginza.
High end shopping. All the top designers within easy reach. Not cheap but they do have access to a great range of labels.

Lights, action, shopping and eating.. Ginza is the center of Tokyo for fun and business. If it's in Tokyo it's somewhere in the Ginza. Shopping is from small boutiques to big fancy high end department stores along with Uniglo and H & M. Food runs the same gamut from yakitori under the train tracks to Michelin stars. Definitely worth a couple of days and an evening or two.

Same shops as Sydney, Paris, New York, London, etc, etc, etc.. Ginza is a giant shopping mall with little else going for it.Do you really go to Tokyo to buy the same stuff you can buy at home?The only reason to go near Ginza is to visit the kabuki theatre, otherwise it's utterly, utterly pointless and very, very dull.
Shop till you drop. wide road and side walks for shopping, unlike akihabara or shibuya, Ginza is less crowded.Great to see Sony showroom, and walk to Tsukiji Fish market for fresh sushu/sashimi.

Great Food. The restaurants and eateries are fabulous. The fish markets are great to try the local cuisine and the service in the stores is impeccable. We could learn a lot about customer service from these very gracious people.

Shopping heaven, luxury to basics. Don't let the association of ginza with high end luxury goods throw you off from coming here, there are plenty of cheap (good quality) brands here as well. A list of our favourite places to shop in ginza with out breaking the bank:Uniqlo - flag ship store with 12 floors, also theres a great cafe (rose bakery) situated in the next building accessible by a walk way on the 6th floor irc. Such a great place to have a snack to rest your tired feet.H&m- fashionable clothing at great cheap prices.Muji - basics and great for food, stationary, and in general everyday living goodsZara - more fashionable then H&m but a bit pricierDon quijote - heaps of branches in Tokyo, this store stocks everything from hair products to Cartier watches. Great place for Japanese goods and gifts !! A MUST VISITAlso remember most stores aren't open before 10

Luxury Shopping. We visited Ginza while we were in Tokyo in the first week of May 2013.We loved the feel of the place, lovely wide road, gorgeously decorated shop display windows,great restaurants, many...in fact all the Luxury Brands have outlets here,,,,a lovely street to walk down and browse. In fact I found it a better experience than Omotesando, which is a narrower street and somehow does'nt feel so grand.

Ginza rocks!. We went to Ginza on our one and only evening in Tokyo. As our stay was so short, we had to use our time very carefully. We were delighted that we chose to include this area in our itinerary. It is claimed to be the biggest upmarket retail area in the world, and when you are there, you can believe it! All the big designer names are there en force and the shops and department stores leave one gaping. We have been to London, Paris, New York, Hong Kong, but our experience of Ginza takes the cake!

Nothing special . Got 1 halal muslim restaurant .. For those who have not been to Tokyo , the name GINZA may excite you , but its just another "Orchard Road, Singapore or Downtown Melbourne or Trafalqar Square area London " etc etc .Its an upmarket shopping area , where all the ' Brands names " are located. Most buildings and shops are named Ginza ........something . I went in the morning , evening n night - same atmosphere - nothing special. If you want to buy a LV bag or a Prada shoes or a Dunhill Jacket , might as well buy it in London or Singapore or if I have the cash to spend , i will buy them in my hometown , Kuala Lumpur Malaysia.( maybe cheaper ) .BUT for Muslim travellers - good news , there is a halal restaurant ( after 6 days in Tokyo , this is the only halal restaurant I found ) Its called RASA MALAYSIA ( from my country ofcourse ) Both the cooks are from Wangsa Maju and Pandan , KL . The chinese lady waitress , Ms.Tin is also a Malaysian .They serve the normal Malaysian food .( of course 5 times the price compared to KL ) .Location - Look out for Masukaya and UNI Glo shopping centre , besides the trafic lights , a building called Ginza 5 Star ( but no signage ) ground floor is MIZUHO Bank , go to the side entrance , take the lift to the 9th floor ( 7th floor is an Indian restaurant ) the sign board is very very small .I think the Japanese do not encouraged ' outsiders ' to do business in their country.
Always wonderful. Living in the same ward, it is the place we usually dine, shop and walk around. Always Ginza is a fun place to visit.

Huge Upmarket Shopping.. This is the most upmarket shopping area of Tokyo. It's very big, and easy to get lost. But all the top shops, and some great restaurants and bars if you know where to go.. or you will probably be stressed at walking around.

See and Be Seen. Ginza is the premiere shopping street of Tokyo, a little of Fifth Avenue, a little suburban chain mall (Gap, Abercrombie and Fitch, Forever 21, Uniqlo), a little manga, a little kimono. We came on a Sunday when streets are blocked to traffic. There are picnic umbrellas and park benches set helpfully in the traffic median, for those like us who would gawk at leisure at the variety of humanity passing by. Not only the fashionista Japanese (honestly, there were grandmothers in 4 inch heels, leather pants, halter tops, hair dyed blonde), ladies with their Gucci and Chanel outfits and bags, but also kids dressed like manga characters, or in cosplay outfits with makeup and hair to match. It was all really fantastic. There were shops to delight the eye and empty the wallet. There was a spanking white Apple store for all the fangirls and fanboys. There was a two-story store devoted to all things Hello Kitty (Lunchbox? Check. Chopsticks? Check. Lip gloss? Check. Head to toe outfit? Check. Four-foot plush toy? Check). There are fancy bakeries selling mochi, the glutinous rice cakes with sweets inside, for $5 a pop. There are sushi and steak joints. There are department stores with beautiful girls greeting you at the door. The department stores, like many in Asia, have cavernous basements with gigantic food courts and sometimes even whole grocery stores, like a Stop and Shop under a Nordstrom, except all the food looks beautifully dressed and will be wrapped in two boxes before you get to eat it. At the Mitsukoshi department store, we saw a loaf of bread for 20,000 Y. This gives you an idea of the kind of prices at Ginza.We came to a Shabu Shabu restaurant for dinner and were not disappointed. All you can eat shabushabu with three different meats and tofu, vegetables. And a taro popsicle at the end. All that window shopping gives one an appetite.

The shopping district. Each famous brand has its appearance here, not a store but a full house. Beside the shopping, you can find some cool night club (I did not remember their names). You should check out UniQlo there (the Japanese fashion giant).

Did not find the electronic stores... Walked a lot in the Ginza district but we could not find all electronic stores we have heard about... We found a lot of stores but not the ones we would have liked to find.. Ginza was as any other shopping street in a major city in the world.
nice street to shop. beautiful place to shop high end goods plus home of the largest UNIQLO in the world 11 stories high!!!!

Street Closed on Saturday. Great shopping especially on Saturday when the whole area is just for pedestrians. Make sure to check the side streets. I found them to be more interesting than the main drag.

World class high end shopping. All the big design houses can be found here, and it puts cities like London to shame. The area in the evening is also dropping with flash cars and money. It's a little soulless like any of these areas, but if you have money to burn then spend it in Ginza.
Note: On the Maranouchi and Ginza metro lines.

Not as busy as Shibuya. I was too tired too explore Ginza by the end of the day of walking tour. So i just spend my aftenoon at La Duree Cafe. I went to Diana and Esperanza shoe shops but found nothing interesting to buy. Matzuzakaya Department Store had a sale when i went there but i found that the better goods collecttion was not on display.

An amazing way to spend a day and evening out.. Ginza is the high-end shopping district of Tokyo...or rather it was. Compared to 20 years ago, it's become more affordable, but it's still a great place to walk around and explore.
Heart of the shopping district in Tokyo. Good food, good shopping, good luxury brands. What's more you can ask for?Go at the weekend where they close off the road for shopping

Maybe the Japanese version of Manhattan?. Gorgeous storefronts with beautifully kimono clad women working at the stores. Don't miss the Toy Park or the Sony building. Both are full of surprises and will leave you wanting more. Grab a bite at Moscafe to try the Japanese version of an upscale hamburger joint. We saw so many well dressed people eating there which was fun. Definitely get a look at night because the lights are dazzling!

If you are a shopper you will love Ginza. Shops, shops and more shops. if you enjoy shopping and like international branded stores, then Ginza is your place. Equally loads of restaurants. If in Tokyo, GInza is a must visit, day or night.

Go...even if u only window shop!. The Ginza is a great location and worthy of even window shopping if u don't want to shop in the high end shops and department stores...fantastic area to wander around and enjoy and its really easy to get to on the subway!
Night life. Loved walking around and people watching. Spent a lot of time watching the businessmen go into and come out of private clubs, often walked to the waiting cars by a hostess or geisha.

Times Square of Tokyo. Fun place to visit. Lots of action. At night it reminds me of Times Square, New York. Many high end shopping places. You can get anything there with plenty of fine restaurants to dine at. Several subway lines serve the area and Tokyo's main station is within walking distance. See it on a weekday as it doesn't have the same impact on a Sunday when many of the shops are closed.

Bright lights and high fashion. Ginza, within walking distance from Tokyo Station, is one of the big three shopping and entertainment areas in Tokyo along with Shinjuku and Shibuya. Like the other two areas, Ginza comes alive at night with streets lined with neon and buildings competing with each other for the prize of 'most unique and most opulent architecture' award! My personal favourite is the Chanel building with its LED facade which encompasses the entire front side of the building and displays some very interesting video images at night. Of course being one of the world's foremost fashion addresses means you'll see all of the major international fashion brands housed here. There are plenty of shopping opportunities and many restaurants and cafes to choose from. The main street is closed off to traffic on Sunday afternoons.
Lively young and vibrant. An exciting area to visit near the Emperors Palace and the fish market with fresh fish a specialty.Ginza is an area for those young in heart and spirit.
Spring in Ginza. Great for a morning walk wherein shops are not yet fully opened. This is the way I love it on a Saturday morning at the one of the most expensive commercial property in the world.

Sony show store v cool. Ginza was a bit meh to us who has Bond Street at our doorstep. However I did enjoy the Sony show store, as they had Gran Turismo goggle play area and all sorts of new gadgets which hasn't arrived in London yet.We spent around an hour here and was worth the time to walk around and try out some of the gadgets. V impressed with the 3D camcorder.Free entry and English speaking staff to assist with tax free purchase.
Shop til you drop!. THis has got to be one of the best shopping centres in the world! There was no downsides to our stay in Ginza and we found some great restaurants as well.

shopping area. big shopping area which was not what I went to Tokyo for since everything is expensive anyway. nice to walk though, but a bit more boring if you don't plan on buying anything. nice enough that I felt safe just strolling though.

You can learn a lot from the department stores!. I really enjoyed visiting the famous department stores of Ginza. We didn't do much actual shopping (much of it's pretty high-end around here!), but the browsing was excellent! I highly recommend visiting the Food Halls (usually found in the basement level), where you can see the most beautifully presented food you've ever seen, taste some samples and grab a delectable snack! Unfortunately not many of them actually have seating areas. Also, check out the store guides, and go to the floor selling homewares, 'gifts' and kimono - these three are usually grouped together, and it was a great insight into what people have in their homes, typical wedding gifts, traditional products such as ceramics and woodware (these items are set out as if on display in an art gallery - amazing!) and kimono and other traditional products. Even my partner enjoyed it (particularly the amazing Japanese kitchen knives). Some of the department stores have been in operation since the 1600s, and their level of service is out of this world!

Luxurious department stores abound. The Ginza area is a great place to spend half a day or more looking at the various department stores. Make sure to visit the basement of at least one department store where you will find a food emporium filled with sweets of all kinds, and other delicacies. At the top of each department store is usually a selection of decent restaurants with menus in English. This area is a great place to people-watch especially the rich Japanese women dressed to the ninth.

Big restrained money. Ginza boasts Tokyo's biggest retail sales, although, busy as it gets, you wouldn't think so compared with the frantic beehive of activity that is, say, Shinjuku or Shibuya. Ginza definitely has a classy edgy, in spite of all the tourists. Department stores, fashion boutiques, art galleries. The best time to visit is on weekends when the main drag, Chuo-dori, is pedestrianized. Dress up!

Some luxury shoppings here.... Plenty of luxury brands are available ranging from Bvlgari to Chanel to Dior to LV and Armani with all the buildings having magnificent display of Architecture.An eye opener even if you're not here for shopping,plenty of restaurant available to pass time on these magnificient Neon Light Signboards Buildings...
THE BEST STREET OF TOKYO. It compares to Rodeo Drive , Los Angeles. lots of nice and expensive depatment stores...take your time and have a coffee there.

Great for people watching. We stayed in Shidome so Ginza was literally on our doorstep. Day or night its a great place to have a wonder round where you will find high end tokyo mixed with the odd little diner etc. There is something for all budgets - for example Uni-Qlo if you wanted to do a bit of wallet friendly shopping. The choice for places top eat / drink is HUGE and als the area feels very very safe (as does tokyo in general)When we found ourselves looking for something to do on an odd evening when in Tokyo we took a walk around the Ginza area

The Rodeo of Japan. Ginza is amazing. 10 blocks of shopping shopping shopping. Every single major fashion house has a store in the Ginza. On sundays they close the street and it is pedestrians only. A great day to go. You can dine on rooftops or just walk. Prices are insane, with north americans paying double or triple what we do at home.

Window Shopping. I remember reading somewhere that you can still find inexpensive things in Ginza but sigh.. we didn't see any. But anyway, its still an experience to visit the big malls and walk the streets. We especially like the basement of Matsuya and Mitsukoshi malls which display and sell an array of food. There's a world's largest 12 storeys Uniqlo store in Ginza which we have to see.

The Top Notch Stores all here!. For all the women out there, Ginza is definitely a must visit. You'll find all sorts of high-end brands. Not just boutiques but a whole building of each brand. Name it: Chanel, Bvlgari, Louis Vuiton, Hermes, etc. If you love make up, go for Shiseido Parlour, they have this hi-tech mirror where you can beep the barcode and the make up is digitally applied on your face in the mirror. Coool! :D
Think 5th Avenue New York City. Every upscale store is located in Ginza along with great restaurants and a few interesting sights like the fish market.

Used to be the place to go. This used to be the place to go dressed up when my mother was young. Now it has two sides. The area with high-end brand boutiques and the other with fast fashion chains (H&M, Uniqlo, Forever 21, etc.) -- now the two are mixed up more or less. If you want to have a quick look, go to Mitsukoshi at the big junction, which has a great food hall. Divided into two floors, B2F has cake shops and delicatessens, and on B3F, quality fish and meat are found. Fish are particularly good, though very expensive, and so are poultry. If you are more into fashion, go to Matsuya Ginza where most brand boutiques are located. If you cannot find what you fancy, you could ask shop assistants who might direct you to another boutique in the area. There are lots of small traditional shops too. With fewer Chinese tourists, it's easier to walk around the area.
The Tokyo scene. The scene is typical Tokyo from what you imagine from TV etc. with the neon lights and big shopping areas. Try to buy some funky electronic toys that Japan is known for.

Fancy shopping. GInza is a bright and shiny place with a ton of high-end shopping. The thing for a 'normal' person to see here, though, are the department stores like Mitsukoshi, especially the bottom two floors - the "food basement" - where you're inundated with all sorts of foods. Fun fact? There is a real Mitsukoshi department store in Epcot, part of the DisneyWorld resort in Orlando!

Wanderlust. It's amazing just to wander the street of Ginza. Early in the morning, you see the place waking up. At night it's a little magical. Esp on weekends. Lots of people shopping and dining (and often you see people in kimonos). So many little restaurants and shops with a beautiful old Japanese sign outside, makes me wish I could read Kanji to know what's inside! Easy to spend HOURS here. Also easy to spend a bomb on a meal -- but that said, have had great lunches for v reasonable prices (1000 yen for yakinuki set... 2k for shabu shabu...) Dinner tends to be more expensive.

Shop 'till you drop!. We went at night and even though I have heard that this part of town was very expensive we found very good deals on some clothing, you just have to look around. Food is another story prices here were higher than other places in Tokyo. Even if you do window shopping its a nice place to go, specially in the evening where you can see it come to live.

Tokyo's Fifth Avenue. Ginza is amazing. The shops are plentiful, it's clean and there's definitely something for everybody here, no matter what your interest.One of the city's two Apple stores is here; it's the company's first store in Asia. The Sony Experience in the Sony Building is fun; you can try out lots of gadgets.
Luxury shopping streets. A luxury shopping streets or upscale area of Tokyo. You can find a lots of branded outlet there. Icon building is Wako store.

Highest end street in the world. No it is not Paris, nor London. probably the only place in the world where you see top brands with more than one outlet within the same street/area. Hermes has 2 huge buildings! Channel has 2 boutiques very close to each other. Sony Building intersection is fun to watch!
art gallery. There are good galleries in Ginza.I reccommend SHISEIDO gallery. It's free.

Good atmosphere on the weekend. I come here every few weeks to go to Mitsukoshi for gifts, and Itoya for stationary-related items. The main road is cordoned off for food traffic only and there is a pleasant, New York style atmosphere (without the hustle and the traffic) if you go for a walk. The night lights are pretty too in the early evening. I usually take guests to the UniQlo store for cheap clothes, and the Abercrombie and Fitch store next door for the murals, handsome staff and nightclub atmosphere. And Itoya is always a hit for Japanese paper and souvenirs.There is a local bath-house too. For eats I have been a few times to a decently priced restaurant called Ganko (Ginza 4-4-1) where you can chose from a variety of mixed lunch sets with hotpot, sushi, tempura etc. so, Ginza is a great place if you're in a rush and are trying to fit in lots of Japanese experiences in one day.
like any shopping street: brand stores and expensive. Ginza street is not a must see i think: nice shops, but expensive, and same as any place in the world

The lights and people of Tokyo. I am not a big shopper but Ginza is worth a visit. It is one big name fashion or brand name shop after another. If you are not into this type of thing a quick visit is enough. I like Ginza at night because of the amazing lights. It is like walking a column of lights. This is where the well heeled come to shop and walk around. There are some nice restaurants and some more interesting little shops off the main streets. The Apple Store is also here as well as a variety of coffee shops. Worth a visit to see the lights and the fashions of Tokyo. Distinctly Tokyo.

It's'got its right to be Ginza in Tokyo. If you're not the type to shop branded items, you stil can enjoy the "branded" sights of ginza, and there are numerous smaller shops in the smaller alleys just behind that offer different kinds of delights, and it's a cozy walk dwon the road just to enjoy ginza

must visit. gotta stop by this district in tokyo.fun. exciting.great place for people watching as well. u get a sense of the current fashion in jp.safe. not dangerous.there are crowds but u don't feel cramped.lots of shopping.something for everyone.just gotta stop by to check it out for yourself to understand why ginza attracts so many locals and tourists.

Feel rich like old money. This is all the rich and famous Japanese shop. Those prestige well known brands in the world presented themselves. worth to visit to get a glimpse of how the old money Japan shop.

Luxury shopping area. If you are planning to buy some luxury items from Japan this is a place you shall never miss. Whole streets is full with shopping malls and you will see LV, Prada over here. The ladies and man's outfits are totally different compare with others place. My friend purposely went there just to buy the Black label and Blue Label from Burberry as this 2 brands only available in Japan.
Excellent shopping area.. Ginza is an excellent area to go shopping. Pricey, but you will have a great time. The close the main street on the weekends for pedestrian use only

If you've got money to burn.... All the designer shops you could imagine- including a Gucci cafe and Armani restaurant. I did notice that the same items of clothing were more expensive than they were in Harajuku.

Sunday Shopping. The main drag in Ginza's shopping district is closed off on Sundays and National Holidays. Don't forget your credit card because this area is not the discount shopping district by any means. All the brand names and major department store names are here and it is a place to go to see that Japan really is in the top three richest economies in the world.

take time to sightseing, there are so many stores to see, if you have enough money, go shopping. I believe they are too formal and serious, do not speake aloud, do not kiss, do not laugh. Be polite, you must put your money in a litle tray, do not count the change.

High end shopping and few lights in the evening. Pretty touristic and high shopping area. Good restaurants although. Don't go too late because closing pretty early. If you want to see the most famous lighting of Tokyo go to see Shibuya.

Outstanding customer service. We were blown away when we arrived at one of the major department stores a few minutes before it opened. When they unlocked and opened the doors, no one rushed in. A female employee read something in Japanese and we waited for the Seiko clock to ding ten times. Then the lady bowed and we slowly entered the store. As we passed other staff members on the way to the food floor, everyone bowed as we passed. We weren't in Kansas.

Architecture and Shpping. Indeed the best area of Tokyo, the most prestigious and famous. All the brands are there, fashion, electronics, shoes, bags. etc. Three big department stores, Mitsukoshi, Matsuya and Matsuzakaya, Lots, really lots of restaurants around, mainly in the side streets, and not as expensive as you would imagine. A must see in Tokyo.

So much variaty in Ginza. The two to visit are Takashimaya Nihonbashi and Prnitemps for price and excellent service. Bic Camera for all electronic.Don't fall sick there are no pharmacies or doctors and the main hospital closes at 8pm

Modern architecture and ID are aplenty. Modern and great details to streetscape. Ginza is still the '5th Ave' of Tokyo. Awesome is the 12 storeys UNICLO headquarters. Modern architecture and ID are plenty to tease and please your eyes.

Ginza, Parks. Arrived before the shops opened so wandered around and ended up by the Imperial Palace moat and then onto the Hibiya Park. It had a Green Festival on, all to do with gardens and living spaces outside which was quite interesting.
Over Priced. You will find every Brand name store you have ever heard of. We found items we bought back in North America and they were all marked up between 20%-40%

High end shopping. Nice strolling along the massive department stores, and it is a must see. But - unless you're looking for throwing thousands of dollars on designer cloths, shopping won't be your activity.
The enormous number of Japanese dressed in the latest fashion is an attraction by itself.

Worth a visit. This is a great place to see brand names and people watch. You name the upmarket brand and you will be able to find it in Ginza. The Apple store was great - I found accessories there that I hadn't seen in any other Apple store around the world.
Ginbura still works. Ginza still has some very solid and high quality places for eating and drinking whch are excellent value for money

Elite Shopping. Be wowed by the designer bags, jewelry and shoe brand stores and ateliers, Hermes LV (and its customizing shop) Gucci Prada Chanel Cartier D&G Harry Winston Bulgari ... name it...they have it. Want the designer second hand shops, Daikokuya can be found near the Hakuhinkan Toy Store :)

The more upclass area.. This is where many famous international brand boutiques are located. The Ginza shopping area will satisfy the brand conscious crowd. There are many nice cafes and restaurants in the area too.

You get what you expect. A seemingly unlimited supply of high end department stores/massive brand stores. All extremely expensive. Not really my thing, but if that is what you like, only other place I could compare is Marina Bay Sands in Singapore for the amount of insanely priced brands you can get.

Get Ready to Burn a Hole in Your Pocket. No visit to Ginza is complete without stopping by Muji's flagship store, the largest in Tokyo, Apple's Japanese flagship store and the Sony showroom. Muji in Ginza is so large that in addition to the usual apparel, food items, furniture and other household products, it features an optical shop (with great spectacle designs) and a mobile house department (yes, you heard right, fancy buying a Muji home anyone?). The Apple and Sony stores are just as impressive, if you're a technophile. Fashionistas will also get to shop till they drop with the endless streets of branded shops and department stores housed in interesting buildings in Ginza. All in, Ginza makes for a fun half day out. Head there after sunset to see the impressive buildings all lighted up.

A shoppers paradise with too many choices. I cannot get over the choice of anything you want to buy. There are so many shops and department stores in Ginza - just make sure you have comfortable flat shoes on as there is so much to see. On Sundays they close the main street to traffic and place table and chairs to sit down and enjoy the scenery - people watching is fabulous in Tokyo. There are expensive stores but also some affordable ones as well - like Uniqlo, H&M, Zara. Check out the restaurants in the side streets where you get a set lunch for yen 1000 or AU$12. It is also worth visiting at nightime with all of the stores lit up and all the bright lights.

amazing shopping experience. Ginza is considered to be the 5th avenue of Tokyo. Japanese people are crazy about fashion and they love burberry and louis vitton. they have more than 4 stores of both on the same street. i highly recommend going to Shiseido bulding and have an amazing dessert on the 3rd of 4th floor if i remember well. make sure to visit Sony building as well and take a tour at all the gadgets they sell exclusively in Tokyo. there are a lot of restaurants to choose from in Ginza and i recommend Mizutani, Dunhill Cafe or Sony resaurant in the building. they have international dishes for the ones who dont want to challenge themselves in trying authentic japanese.

Go here on Saturday for a great experience !. Presently I live in Tokyo. The Ginza is a great place to visit, but it can be a bit crowded. However, if you go on the weekend, it is a totally different experience. All day Saturday the main streets of the Ginza are closed to traffic and it becomes for pedestrians only. It really makes it a much easier experience. Try to be in front of Mitshukoshi department store (Ginza line stop 9) just before 10:00 am. They come out, and do a little "store opening ceremony" every day at 10:00 am. My favorite stores are Mitshukoshi (check out the housewares department for some good things to take home). Also go upstairs where you will find several restaurants that are great. If you enjoy the French cafe, Laduree, and their wonderful macaroons, there is one right in Mitshukoshi, over-looking the most famous intersection in the Ginza. Matsuya is another favorite department store. Check out the basement floors of each of these stores. They are food floors with amazing Japanese food to take to the park, or hotel to try. It is like walking through the food halls in Harrods in London ! Matsuya is just down the street from Mitshukoshi. Further down the street is an amazing stationary store, unlike any in the States, called Itoya. Across the street from Matsuya, is the Apple Store, which is a great place to visit if you need to check your email. After the Apple store, go 1 block further, and turn left. Cross 2 or 3 small blocks and on your left will another favorite department store. It is called Printemps and is from Paris. The Japanese love all things French. And as you can see from my notes, I do too. This store is great for up to date fashions and good prices. In the summer they even have the "summer sale" in July, just like the Paris store. I am actually not much of a shopper. But when friends come to town, this is where I take them. Enjoy !

The perfect place to stay in Tokyo. We stayed in this area and it was great! Walking distance to shopping and lots of restaurants and also to the Fish market! Very easy to catch the metro to other parts of Tokyo and walking distance to Tokyo station.
Pedestrian walk Paradise! . During my visit (weekend) Ganza Street is open entirety and act as Pedestrian Walk, simply perfect for shoppers!

Japanese 5th Av.. Indeed, all the brands and designers are here. The cars on the streets are classy, and you'll see a lot of money walking the streets, but you'll never feel out of place. Don't forget to check SANRIO Ginza out, one of the many exclusive Hello Kitty stores in Japan.

Nothing special. We had great expectations from this area but effectively it is the same as Londen or New York only much, much more cleaner. Other than that, the usual line up of brand stores with some Japanese department stores thrown in, that sadly were also mainly offering westeren style fashion and brands. As most items are much more expensive than at home you might as well skip the area. If you like to see and walk trough major crowds you should definitely go there.

Better than 5th Avenue. Very clean, large streets with all your "name" stores on show. Extremely clean and great for people watching. A coffee is about $6.00 or a beer $10.00. But well worth the investment. Definitely a must see!
Great restaurants and shops. Lots of tiny hole in the wall restaurants and everything from tiny specialty who's to all the designer labels. Easy to get around.

Good for high end shopping. Good selection of shops. I like Barney's New York, Mitsukoshi mens wear floor. Down the back streets there are also some good Japanese menswear retailers such as Beams. Only problem is lack of cafes in the area.

Shopaholic Haven. Went there earlier in February this year.In a nutshell,it is a shopping haven - especially for those into high-end luxury goods. Many brands (e.g. Hermes, Dior and Chanel to name a few) have their Japanese flaghship stores here, so be sure to visit Ginza if you're into this sort of thing. Otherwise, if you're looking for culture/nature in your trip, it's ok to give this place a miss.Duration-wise, plan at around 2 hours if you only intend to walk around and visit only a handful of boutiques. If you intend to visit every other shop, Ginza can easily take you up to an entire day.Good Points:- Central place for luxury shoppers- Easily accessible via multiple metro linesBad Points:- Not much to see other than luxury good stores, so don't bother if you're not into luxury shopping- Might burn a big hole in your pocket ;)
A must for Tokyo visitors. Great place for shopping, dinning, drinking or just walking around during the day or at night. Highly recommended. Just walk around and be amazed at what you'll find

Tokyo's Magnificent Mile. Ginza is Tokyo's premier shopping district for signature brands and high end items. It is the equivalent of Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, Michigan Ave in Chicago, Fifth Avenue in New York, Santana Row in San Jose California to name a few. On a weekend, this place is closed to vehicles and transformed into a pedestrian alley. If you like shopping for branded stuff, this is the place for you but be ready to pay the price. If you fancy window shopping, this place is also for you. You could spend a day by just looking around and marvelling at the window displays. At night, this place is festive with its bright colored lights and attractive neon signs. In my recent visit to Tokyo, I visited this place twice. I simply fell in love with the place.

Stroll around. Nice place to stroll around in the weekend when the traffic is forbidden. All major shops are here and famous buildings as well. A must is to walk over the famous crossing in rush-hour. There are many bars here, but in general the prices are high. In the night time you can find many exclusive clubs, but prepare to open the wallet once inside.

Expensive but pretty. Ginza is the most expensive neighbourhood in Tokyo. Here you can find shops of Armani, Louis Vuitton, Dolce & Gabanna, etc. But there is also an H&M of course. The buildings are very nice and modern, there's great architecture here.

Nice to Window Shop. As others have stated, Ginza is very clean. However, this is an upscale area and the stores are high end shopping. Great if you like window shopping or have money. Otherwise, it's good to say you've been there I suppose.
Great area for walking/shopping. Though the stores tend to be expensive in this area, it is a very nice area to walk around and shop.

Nice upmarket shopping and dining area. Spent a week based in Ginza in early July and really enjoyed the area. It is clean, felt safe and has some amazing up-market brand stores (Chanel, Tiffany & Co, Prada etc). It also has some really interesting department stores, and we really enjoyed exploring their food halls, which had an intriguing array of food and drinks.On the weekend they close the streets to traffic which makes strolling around Ginza even more enjoyable. It's also well worth a visit at night too, as the neon signs light up and provide a bright and colorful backdrop. There is no shortage of restaurant choices in Ginza, with plenty of places along the side streets. Just remember to look at the signs advertising the restaurants to see which floor they are on as many are up a few floors or in the basements.

Bring Lots of Yen!. This is the place to shop and get rid of all that bothersome money you have laying around.This is a high end shopper's paradise. All the big names are here and they have some very flashy store fronts to announce their presence.I really enjoyed exploring the absolutely massive Matsuya Ginza department store. The selection of products is like nothing I've ever experienced before ... and the food department in the basement must be seen to be believed. There are quite a few restaurants and coffee bars to along the street to enjoy. My partner and I found a nice spot out on the patio of one place to have a coffee, relax and watch people go by..... and I came home with a souvenir watch!Go!

Great shopping area. You get everything at the Ginza. Upscale malls and fashion houses, little shops serving in side alleys interesting japanese local specialities, rice rice cakes, exotic pastries, sake, pickles,etc..Wide avenues crammed with lots of people. You have to be in the mood to go cruising...

A lot of flagship store brand names are located here. It's a very nice street to go for a walk. Not so much for shopping as the price are pretty high here. Go on a Sunday, and the roads are closed for people to walk. Very nice environment, but not much to do, then again plenty to see.

Nice, but go on a Sunday - there's no traffic. The much touted Ginza is really just another up market shopping street like anywhere else in the world, except the road is very wide and on Sunday is closed to traffic. I suspect within the space of a couple of kilometres there are more up market stores than anywhere else I have been to, plus a few Japanese ones that you would not find elsewhere. Being a larger framed person, the clothing was all too small for me, but there is a lot of fun to be had just people watching and seeing some of the promotions that are happening. A delightful area to visit and great for window shopping or spending large ammounts of money if you have the resourses to do so. Some interesting buildings to look at as well. A visit to Tokyo would not be complete without at least a quick stroll on the Ginza.

Bring Your Money. You'll need it in this area of Tokyo. Ginza is a high-end shopping district that's great for walking through at any time of day. If you go at night, of course, you'll get to experience all of the bright lights. And if you're a Starbucks fan, you can get your fix (and a little history) at Japan's first-ever Starbucks store here.

Great fun on a summer evening. We loved walking through Ginza and drinking in all the lights and the store windows and fortune tellers and fancy treats. Very spacious with nice wide sidewalks and so much to see!

Sony and Armani. Don't miss the Sony Building with a four floor showroom with all the latest from the company. Also, the Armani building is impressive with several floors of high quality products. We liked.

New York's Fifth Avenue in Tokyo!. This is the place where you are going to stroll for hours, (windows) shopping its elegant and expensive stores, and clubbing at dark. In the months of June or July, just make sure you have an umbrella handy as it rains a lot, and once it starts raining, just like in Seattle or in Vancouver during rainy seasons, it seems like it doesn't want to stop, although it's not heavy rain!Along Harumi-dori and Showa-dori or Chuo-dori, you will run into all of the big names, from Hermes, Cartier, Chanel, LV to other smaller brand names inside department stores, or little boutiques and specialty stores on the smaller crossing streets. Sony flagship store is one block away from Apple. Restaurants are plenty as well. Two convenient subway stations are within a few blocks of each others, the Ginza station and the Higashi-Ginza station. It is also within walking distance of Tsukiji Fish Market and Sumida River. The Courtyard Marriott hotel is also located in the heart of Ginza as well.Just as with New York's Fifth Avenue in New York, Ginza is a must visit neighborhood in Tokyo. We loved it.
Wow factor. Is the "5th Avenue" of Tokyo-lots of glitz and high end shopping. Especially enjoyed Swarovski crystal store- entire stair case is covered in their crystals.

Need a Plan in Japan. Coming off a 13 hour flight from DC, I should´ve stayed at my hotel upon check-in. I decided not to sleep off my jet-lag, but rather explore the Ginza district at night. There was certainly some interesting sights, from an old steam locomotive which is now a monument to tall and narrow buildings that housed a different nightclub/bar on each floor. The lighting was good on the streets and I felt pretty safe, but I´d recommend to anyone else not to go out without a plan or knowing the lay of the land when overly exhausted. I feel like I mainly wandered around with no real goal of where I wanted to end up, which can normally be a cool travel experience but not when you are jet-lagged. I guess my main message here is that I found nothing wrong with the district, but nothing that blew me away either, and I´d advise the next travelers to at least know what they want to get out of Ginza

High-End Brand Shopping (Commercial Japan). Ginza is well-known for its expensive department stores and brand storefronts, but there's more to the neighborhood than over-priced shopping. When Japan opened up to the West, Ginza was designed to look like a Western boulevard, and so the main street through the neighborhood was substantially wider than normal Tokyo streets back when it was constructed. If you visit on a Sunday when the main drag is open to only foot traffic, you can appreciate how huge this would have felt back in the days before everyone drove cars.Today, you can find restaurants (both expensive and cheap) as well as some prefectural goods stores -- these are run by each of Japan's prefectures and sell famous foods and handicrafts from each region. Even if your trip doesn't take you out of Tokyo, prefectural stores are one way to get a flavor of Japan's other regions.There are also some Japanese brand showrooms, including Sony's multi-level electronic tower. If you find Shibuya and Shinjuku daunting (or find the crowds claustrophobic), Ginza is a more sedate area of downtown Tokyo. It doesn't have as much energy, perhaps, as the areas where more young people hang out... But you're also less likely to get squashed or trampled.
i forgot. i visited ginza when i was very littlethe only thing i remembered was the yakitolivery good
Expensive shopping, nothing very different. I will give this place a miss as a tourist unless you like expensive shopping :)

Ginza with a wheelchair. On our recent trip to Tokyo, sightseeing for my 87 year old mother became a breeze with the use of a wheelchair. We bought ours from Australia, but I understand most hotels can hire one at a moderate cost. Traversing the Ginza area was easy. Gutters, uneven footpaths and holes were virtually non existent making for a pleasant exploration of this famous area. The department stores had lifts and we even ventured down into the nearby subway to go to Harajuku. Station staff could not have been more helpful and even arranged assistance off the train at our stop.

Lovely Ginza. The area was perfectly managed, clean and beautiful. Come on Sunday and enjoy the car free day on the main street of Ginza. There were some big beach umbrellas with chairs to sit and enjoying to see and be seen.

shopping haven. Alongside the high-end boutiques, you can also find stores like Uni Qlo and H&M which sells more mid-range clothes for those on a tighter budget. We liked them best for the smaller sizes they stock for more petite Asian frames.
streets of gold. Ginza and neighbours yurakucho and marunouchi are it for me - true urban centres with way more than business, offices and shopping

Shopper's Paradise. The largest Uniqlo is here... occupying 12 storeys. Got ourselves Uniqlo Ginza specials. We visited the designer shops and the latest designs were found here. When visiting the Sony or Apple store, the latest gadgets were also found. Is truly a shopper's paradise!
Commercial Tokyo as you expect. Basically a very high end shopping area with the same brands ht are found in the best part of other major cites. Worth a look.
Just a bunch of high class shopping. This is where you'll find the signatured brands. I didn't find this area very interesting because I wasn't really after the shopping district.
Ginza. High end shopping. Go to Mitzukoshi`s food basement. Get there at 10 to see the opening. The staff bow to the customers as the doors open.

Very upmarket shopping and dining area. There's no doubt that this is one of the most expensive real estates in Japan. You can find branded goods everywhere.Unfortunately, at the time when we were there, Yen was extremely high for us. I was looking for branded Japanese skincare products. One particular 30lm serum and another 30ml essence cost an additional 2000 yen compared to my home country.There's a huge toy shop at the junction near Burberry and there's some interesting toys for kids. The Blue Label and Black Label is available in this Burberry outlet.

More than just high end shopping. Great place to shop and eat. Check out the lunch deals at the major department stores. Ginza does have a reputation for high end shopping - it does have a great selection of high end brands. However, Uniglo has its flagship store there - 12 stories of clothes where you can shop till you drop. Prices are reasonable and quality is ok. Another Japanese brand, GU also has a store in Ginza. Prices are cheap but as I discovered later - quality is poor.

See Tokyo the way it is advertise. After seeing the cherry blossoms , the imperial palace , numerous shrines and temples , tall buidings and markets , we felt we had missed something of Tokyo so we went to Ginza after dark .  Boy , is this a different Tokyo ! We have been in Times Square , the Champs-Élysées , the Magnificent Mile in Chicago , and we think that Ginza is the best for window-shopping , neon publicity and advertising ! It is really worth spending 3 to 4 hours wandering around , getting the pulse of the crowds and stop by for a drink or food at one or more of the numerous restaurants available ! A different and still surprising Tokyo altogether !

Lots of good shopping. Ginza is not as expensive as it appears to be. There are lots of brand name stores but if you look close enough there are bargains to be found as well. Recommend going on a Sunday as that is when they would block off the main road and make it a pedestrian area.

The main upscale shopping district of Tokyo. The Edo Shogunate opened a mint office here in 1612, hence the name "gin-" (silver) "za" (locus). The main streets remain intact from the Edo era. After the Meiji Restoration, the Western-style buildings made of bricks and stones were constructed in 1873-1877, but they were destroyed by the Great Kanto Earthquake in 1923. Many of the buildings are from the late 1920s and 1930s, when the "MoBos" and "MoGas" enjoyed shopping and frequented coffee shops and bars in the area. After WW2, Ginza retained the status of being the most prestigious district of consumerism, although new shopping districts in Shinjuku and Shibuya developed. The Japanese take much pride in having a store in Ginza, and you'll see why after your visit.Ginza is generally an upscale shopping/dining district, but it can be a family friendly place, with chains like Uniqlo and Tokyu Hands that co-exist with Prada and Louis Vuitton. The competition among department stores (Mitsukoshi, Matsuya, Matsuzakaya, etc) are fierce. Their basement floors begin sales after 19:00 to sell off all the food imaginable in this world. Very worth visiting if you like window-shopping in a neat and relaxing area.  .

Magic at Christmas. Arriving into Tokyo on Christmas morning, with no real idea of what the city would be like at this time of year and no plan of what to do. I got the train to Tokyo station, figuring if any action was happening it would be in the heart of the city. Coming out of the station there were Christmas trees and lights everywhere, a magical place. It was freezing cold with icy winds gusting down the streets, but there were forever little pockets of warmth inside shops, each of which had their own Christmas tree decorated to perfection.This stretches all the way from Tokyo station into Ginza. Such a beautiful neighbourhood with lights and excitement wherever you look. Best place to be on Christmas night - just don't forget your winter woolies!
Love it. I love going to Ginza on weekends. The streets are closed to traffic and the neon lights at night is what Tokyo is all about
Pricey Cosmopolitan Shopping District. Pricey but always something to see. Where I'd go for a nice gift for my wife, but not for a souvenir.
Super clean. Boring. The streets are spotless. The stores are all high end designer houses. But the neighborhood is boring. Harajuku is way more interesting
Want Branded Items???. Channel, Prada, LVT, what else? you can find it there. Expensive place shops are there. Restaurants are excellent.
noble shopping. Ginza is better by day then by night, a lot of glamour. Nice for window shopping.
Piccadilly Circus on drugs. Somewhere you have to go to see Tokyo night-life. Several large high end department stores with all the designer goods you could want.
Shopping. Amazing district, so diverse bit expensive but you can walk around for hours just window shopping

Shopping and nothing.. Since I am not shopping enthusiast I found this avenue rather boring. Yes it has perhaps all major and minor brands in its shopping windows but other than this, nothing interesting.
Fancy. This is the fancy part of Tokyo. I enjoyed the little time I spent here.

Shopping Heaven of Tokyo. Crowded and sparkling, Ginza is regarded as the hub of Tokyo youngsters for its favorably commercial location. Hip coffeehouses and appetizing bistros may keep you occupied for a spell but brand stores shall dominate your impression unto this sleepless locale. From mid-range to upscale boutiques are sitting along the eye-bursting light streets and ready to serve fashionistas the latest trends, of course, at hard price-tags.You will not want to miss out Ginza in your Tokyo excursion as you gotta visit Manhattan once strolling to Big Apple.
Good if you like to shop. As the title sugggests, good if you like shopping. Lots of high end brands there. Otherwise pretty boring.
6 storeys uniqlo!!. Apple store is so cool too! The whole street is bright with lights, it's so new york!

A nice walk. You dont have to spend money if all you want is a walk on the street which houses the biggest brands in the world! not much to see but another box checked!! I did buy some origami products and postcards from a shop on the street, it also has a shop that sells old maps of Japan, though i wonder how they can afford the rent!!

Great area to explore. Ginza is cool if you are into high-end shopping. Mitsukoshi Department store has a huge food area on the basement level and you can find all kinds of edible souvenirs there. There are also many great cafes on all of the streets around the main the shopping street that runs through Ginza.
the heart of Tokyo for me. love walking around Ginza all the wonderful shops stocking all the luxuries and more to buy, bring your credit card! also plenty of food around
Mass Brand Shopping Mecca. Place to go for mass brand shopping; walk the small side streets and visit Japanese designer shops.

Ginza Shopping Paradise. We love walking along Ginza street with many shops and department stores. Uniqlo just open it GINZA store last 16 Mar.
We didn't queue up to enter the store this time but definitely visit for our next Tokyo trip.
High End Shops Galore!. A must visit place while you are in Tokyo! Designer and Local Brands abound.

Looking area. For 1st time visitors to Tokyo, Ginza is a must visit to see all of the high end shops - especially ladies. It is an interesting area to walk around particularly on Sunday when the streets are closed to cars. Most places very, very expensive.
Your usual financial / commercial district in a major city. Loads of high end stores, high end restaurants - worth a walk if you have time.
Where to spend lots on nothing. Just another overpriced ,brand shopping place with most of the character lost.

Great Place to see the "Other Half" in Japan. Yes, the home to $1000/hour hostess bars and the top designer shops in Japan. Recently the area has been morphing into the jewelry store center of the capital. As far as shopping goes, forget it. Prices are at least 100% higher than elsewhere in the world. People go here to spend money, not save it. Eating can be expensive, but there are bargains to be had at any of the "Ginza Lion" beer halls which are foreigner friendly. So why go here? Well because all the beautiful people do. On Sundays they close down the street and tens of thousands walk up and down the street dressed in their best window shopping and having $10 cups of coffee. The back streets are interesting to take a look at. Lots of oddball shops and 1000's of bars and clubs. I actually go here often. It's more of the "adult" place to go, and not really for the kids. They go to Harajuku.

Great shopping, reminiscent of 5th Avenue. Long boulevards of designer shops, a Bulgari on every street corner with Louis Vuitton and Cartier thrown in for good measure. The streets are somewhat reminiscent of Manhatten. Well reocmmened for an explore / window shop for most.

Shopping capital. We enjoy just looking around Ginza & strolling the wide streets. We always fine good small restuarants in buildings, so look out for these. Plenty of shopping with all your famous brands within a couple of blocks of each other. Train & subway line available, although Tokyo main station is only a 10min walk.
Shopping area. My favorite shopping place where a luxury brand name shops are.
A nice walk.... Nice ares to walk around with high grade shops. Very safe

High Rise, High Class. While Ginza is interesting to look at, it is certainly a high-rent district. It isn't enough to just have a store in Ginza, companies must have entire buildings, such as the Gucci building. The Sony Showroom was fascinating and fun. I also recommend a small tea shop, where you can experience a modern version of the traditional tea ceremony. It is called Cha Ginza, I highly recommend it.

This is where Gucci bag-toting ladies with upturned noses go to buy more Gucci bags. It has also become a drop-off point for busloads of Chinese tourists.And a few years ago, it became Japan's fast-fashion capital: Gap, Zara, UniQlo, Forever 21, H&M. All the cut-rate casual clothing chains seem to dominate the neighborhood now. Abercrombie & Fitch has also arrived. The store wafts its cologne scent through the entire neighborhood. So if you're wondering what that smell is, now you know.But the once-posh shopping district also retains most of its luxury retailers. Hence the little old ladies with the big ol' bags.These days, Ginza has all the sterility of an airport departure lounge.

High-Class Shops and Restaurant. There are many rich shops and restaurants. But you can find some inxpensive and good shops and restaurants. The Kabuki Theater and Hibiya Park are also worth visiting.

Shopaholics Paradise!. Incredible shopping experience. Especially at weekends when they close the road for pedestrians. Try the Lion beerhall for the weekend king crab special lunch - you won't be disappointed
Regular shopping street. This is a regular shopping street with some highend brands. Not special.
Shopping!. Brilliant if you like shopping with brand items. Usually, I don't like shopping much, so I don't go there quite often. Different taste from Shinjuku or Shibuya.

Large shopping district. I'm not a huge 'shopper' myself, which would have hugely added to the appeal. I'm glad I saw it because they neighborhood is so well known, but basically just a large stretch of fancy stores.

The Expensive Side of Tokyo!. Very pricey and similar to every big city's shopping district - premium that is! Had some difficulty looking for a fairly priced restaurant but on Ginza Strip near the JR Station, you will find wonders which I will write about in my next post.

Shopper's Experience. Altho we were there when the yen was terribly high at 75 to $1, it's still a place to go and walk Ginza dori and see all the high end specialty stores all in one area! Unbelievable the extravagance and overwhelming. The buildings are all modern and futuristic so maybe their overhead costs are being tricked down to the buyers?? As far as we could see from the storefronts, not many shoppers inside....perhaps due to economy and to the recent tragedy in Fukushima has many holding on to their money for more realistic things. Lots of great restaurants and bars. Pretty much anything you want to eat or drink at the time. Have fun!

The epitome of shopping. Ginza is a fast paced clean pleasant area of tokyo. Plenty of high end shops and department stores. A must see is the asementvlevel of these department stores they are shining stars for food displays and sharpness

Ginza - Madison Avenue of the East. Never had I seen a city so well laid out, so clean , so organized, and yet so cool and hip as Ginza. The entire area is like Madison Avenue in Manhattan - gorgeous shops, great restaurants, and clubs. The streets are immaculate, and while bustling very safe. I would highly recommend staying a few days in Ginza.
Nice Place to Shop if You're Rich. and see the night lights. A big party scene at night, workaday during daylight.
Buzzing. A slice of modern Tokyo - has some pretty buildings and the lights of Shibuya... with half the crowd!
