High priced European fashion designers all present and reporting for duty!. This is an interesting place for a few hours of window shopping unless you have a lot of spare cash. Very pricey, high fashion and trendy department stores and designer stores. If you are planning an outing that requires a picnic or simply want to eat casually in your room at the end of the day, pick up the makings of a wonderful gourmet meal in the food stores that the department stores have on their basement level. Matsuya and Mitsukoshi are especially grand, with all kinds of breads, pastries, cheeses, gourmet deli, and imported wines and beers along with bentos and saki. The fruit is the highest quality. Everything is packed with precision and care.

My favorite place in Tokyo. It sounds interesting to note that Ginza, though expensive in many ways, attract many visitors because all flag-ship stores located in walking distance. Wide roads, unusual in Japan, take you to various places without difficulty. Also, located in Ginza is traditional KABUKICHO that dates back into centuries. There are affordable places where you can buy things, watch movies, dine in multi-cuisine restaurants, relax in free, comfortable walking!

Fantastic cakes in Ginza. There are some great cake shops in Ginza, the guide books talk about the up market fashion stores, but the cake shops were fantastic. I have't tasted cakes as good since I was in Switzerland!
city of fashion. you can find the most fashionable cloth and highest building or its say a good spot for people......

Bring your credit card!!. there are 3-4 things you should know about GINZA:1. it's expensive. bring your credit card that has no foreign transaction fees (aka continental)i bought my aunt some Shiseido lotion...and the bill was that of a cheap plane ticket!!2. do NOT eat any of the foods here. they are ALL tourist traps....go to shibuya or asukasa3. HOWEVER, the bottoms of the department stores are an exception.4. it's a great place to walk during the morning and night. at least during december, they cordoned the streets for pedestrian use and during the day, all the neon lights come on! =)

SHOPPING!!. A great range of shops for all tastes. From the Sony Center where you can play with all the latest gadgets that might not reach your home country through the traditional style Japanese department store to the small specialist shops. Especially good on Sundays when some roads are closed.

Nice Shopping District, especially Weekend. Popular High fashion area, especially enjoyable on weekends, for it's car free! Mitsukoshi Department Store is completely renewed and has many to see, not to mention LUMINE fashion department (near Yurakucho Station) which was just open !
Big city bright lights. Lots and lots of shops, restaurants and bright lights all arranged in a very orderly manner.

CHEAP SHOPS DESTORY THE IMAGE OF GINZA.. Ginza is supposed to be the cream of the cream for shopping but my last visit there changed my mind. Now u have whoever it is there selling mass production clothes from China and 3rd world countries.The ginza now is a good example of what cause
the economy collapsed. Volume and cheap unneeded things produced not in the country itself.

nothing much. seemed pretty much like the 34th street area @ nyc... it's an old part of town with just stores. we were excited to be staying in a hotel in the area - but there isn't all that much to do here unless you are in Tokyo to shop in international stores (armani...etc.)

worth a look. its got a lot of good eateries,designer shops,very lively , trains are great ,japanese theateres, lots of edwarden and victorian buildings,top department stores,great mix of overseas and japanese people.
not so good -quite expensive shopping but thats all.

One of my favorite areas on the planet.. Ginze looked better than ever, even though the lights were dimmed slightly due to the Tsunami energy aftermath. Clean as a pin, great variety of stores and eating places, totally unique atmosphere on Sunday when the road is closed to vehicles.
Tokyo's answer to Regent's street or Les Champs-Elysées. Ginza is a classy but somewhat boring area of Tokyo. There's nothing unique here - the usual high-end retail outlets.
Clean, safe, shopping and restaurant area. Great area to walk around at night, lots of shopping opportunities and very good restaurants.

Beautiful stores, beautiful food, beautiful people, beautiful cars... you get the point. One reviewer said his is 5th Avenue on steroids- an apt description. More luxury stores per square mile than most anywhere in the world. On the other hand, the prices are higher than most anywhere in the world, especially for US travelers with the current yen dollar exchange rate.Great selection of restaurants also.I love to just walk around this area and take in the sights- window shopping, stopping to eat, watching the beautiful people (including some women wearing kimonos on weekends) walking down the street, seeing the beautiful cars driving by.... Other than eating, I tend to keep my wallet in my pocket though. Most of the luxury goods are available in US cities at lower prices.

GREAT FOR WESTERN CLOTHING AND BRAND NAMES. If you want technology this is where you get it. You don't have to be a nerd or a geek to love the area. There are many other things such as department stores which appeal to the everyday person. PROS************************************************************** A good place for western brands (if you fit)* Friendliest staff I encountered in Tokyo* Toy Park is a great place for gifts for all ages* Many department stores* Great for walking* Sapporo beer brewery* Window displays are a work of art themselves*Great train line which is close to everythingCONS************************************************************** Expensive* Many department stores* It is easy to get lost - Japanese people have no sense of direction and the rule of thumb is usually * Hard to find a map unless you get one from department stores* English speaking of some staff is so-so - you need to know basic Japanese if you want something specific like I did.

Treasure trove of delightful finds. Ten-ichi for tempura. Angelina's (2F, Printemps), Bunmeido or Lindt Chocolatier for high-tea or coffee. Shiseido Gallery for inspiring art. Ippudo for tonkutsu ramen. Koruson for Sushi. Nearby Hamarikyu Garden for an afternoon walk. Mitsukoshi basement for snacks and souvenirs. Wine selection at the basement of Ginza Printemps.

Bring lots of money. Fantastic shops but very very expensive. We definately did lots of window shopping but not much buying. The large department stores stock all the international designer brands plus locally made products of exceptional quality, with an exceptional price!

Great shopping. All the modern brand names in huge specialist stores, or in departmental stores. The food halls in each of the stores are also worth a visit. Drink coffee, or even have a light lunch in the Dunhill shop across the road from Tiffanys

luxury shopping. The department stores cater to globalized tastes but are still dazzling, from their food courts to their jewels. And if you like stationery, don't miss Ito-ya, nine floors of paper, pens, art supplies, calendars and more.
Shopping, Shopping, More Shopping and then Shopping. The high-end shops in Tokyo; a great area for restaurants, night clubs, theater, and ....uh, shopping.

GInza - Heart of Tokyo Spirit. Ginza is THE Shopping Street of Japan. Some calls it the Fift Avenue of Asia. You would find any day, both Japanese Traditional Riches and Asian New Rich are strolling to the 'Extravagant ' Shops. However, Ginza also home for younger people with more of heart than riches, to offer from its back road mazes with resturants, shops from around the world. What I personally recomend to spend an afternoon of Saturday or Sunday (or any holiday) of Autumn/winter or Spirnt to stroll at the main roads of Ginza. The main road is closed for vehicles and reserved for Lazy Padestrians. I often de-stress with my camera, and discover Japan each time a new way.Do try it, either with your family, friends or just alone, you are sure to hit some treasure..

Fifth Ave on steroids. If you like to shop, all of the name stores are within a short walk. Salvatore Ferragamo, Tiffany, Prada, more, and many department stores. I hate to shop, but I can see why many would like the Ginza.

Heaven for shoppers.. I love to shop, especially window-shop. Ginza has the flagship Apple store and flagship Coach store, along with numerous restaurants sprinkled throughout.The prices in most of the stores in Ginza are NOT cheap, but that's why window shopping can be so fun.While many of the stores in Ginza are also in the States, it's still a nice place to visit while in Tokyo.

Don’t bother. I didn’t find Ginza very interesting – it had designer outlets, department stores and restaurants, but less character than a lot of other districts in Tokyo. There are designer outlets in my home city too.

Beautiful area, both old and new Tokyo. I visited Ginza a number of times with my boyfriend and sister on a recent trip to Tokyo. Although I was not there to shop, this is perfect for anyone looking to do some serious shopping, with the Apple store, Tiffany, Bulgari and many more designer shops lining the streets.We really enjoyed seeing this side of Ginza during the day, and still managed to find a small, trendy cafe/bar to eat ramen for lunch at a low price.If you want to escape the bustle of the city, it is easy to visit the Imperial Palace Gardens, just a short walk from the train station.By night, we often sat at the street cafes under the railway arches (with the occasional Shinkansen passing by), amazing Japanases food - Yaketori, Sashimi, Gyozas - at a good price perfect if you are looking to enjoy the "street" side of Tokyo.From here you can go on to enjoy cocktail bars or traditional sake bars.Ginza is easy to get to from Tokyo station and you will love it whether you want to shop, sightsee, enjoy cocktails in one of the many high rises or have a beer or sake with the locals in a traditional bar, all under the amazing lights.

Ginza - Old Tokyo. I love Ginza, one of the old time of Japan. And, it's not so crowded compare with Shinjuku. Some of the shopping complex in Shinjuku are also available here. Would recommend to shop here if you hate the crowd.

dissappointed. We went on a Saturday afternoon. The whole place is huge and there is a real difficulty finding the upmarket western shops. Very busy but in a crammed, western way and not the exciting, tokyo way like the Shinjuku. Actually, if you want to do some shopping and have fun, I recommend going to Shinjuku instead. One thing to do if you are in Ginza - go to Mikimoto. No Harrods, Selfridges, Saks can ever come close to the way they treat you in Mikimoto. And if you have some cash to spare, those pearls are close to the best thing money can buy. I recommend this attraction only if you have loads of time and patience and definitely not after a long day.

Great for wandering around between business meetings. I tend to visit Tokyo for business, and stay at the Dai Ichi hotel or Dai Ichi Annex, so for me Ginza is a great place to wander around between meetings or in the evenings.Yes, the designer goods are expensive, but there are a few other places worth going...- Uniqlo for good value basics, sometimes with a quirky Japanese edge.- Muji for Japanese household goods and snacks.- Bic Camera by Yurakucho station for travel adapters if you forget yours.- Apple Mac store (top floor) for free internet access if, like me, your work laptop won't let you get to hotmail and facebook.- Printemps or Matsuya department stores for little designer hankies and flannels. (And for the loos...)- Rag Tag for second hand designer clothes - Hermes scarves for £40 or so.- Cafe Doutour at the Ginza crossing to sit on the first floor and watch the world go by.So not really a destination in its own right (unless you're very rich), but a nice place to kill some time if you're travelling on business and don't want to go too far from your hotel.

Not the best stop for a one-day Tokyo Visit. Who is the researcher for this trip that stuck us at an airport hotel? Ahhhh...Lynn! I was a bit nervous about jumping right into lodging in Tokyo, a place neither of us have been to and where everything would have been an unknown and so took what I thought would be a more familiar introduction to Asia...An airport hotel, the Holiday Inn for our layover nights.This decision results in our having to take the hotel bus back to the Airport, then catch the express train to Tokyo, an expensive $100 round trip. Another weak research moment...what to do when we get to Tokyo? We fumble trying to figure out the subway, got off at Ginza station and walked around and around, each of us in hurting shoes. Neither of us are shoppers, so this may not have been the best section to explore, but we did have some interesting views, enjoyed a park, found that almost no one spoke English (at least where we were) there is no such thing as an internet cafe and we had a fantastic lunch.In our rambling about Ginza we came across a little alley way that we returned to for lunch. The restaurant had about 24 seats at 6 tables and you were sat with other folks. We watched one group of three come in and they were sat at 3 different tables. WOW!This was a locals restaurant, mostly business men. I was the only woman there. The nice thing about menus here is that almost all of them have pictures so it doesn't matter if you can't read it...just point and cross your fingers that you didn't just order something too wacky! We both chose what would have been a Binto styled meal here, but it didn't come in a box. Miso soup, rice, pork & vegetables, potstickers, and a beer for less than $20 very reasonable!We found a wine shop and picked up a good bottle and headed back to Narita. Our summary is that Tokyo was not too easy for those who don't know the language. At least the Ginza area was not trying very hard with most street signs sans-subtitles. We wish we had done more research on Tokyo to maximize our time here. A tour might have been the way to go.So on our first day we figured we had a $120 lunch. Sort of like pilots and the $100 hamburger.

Don't waste your time... Just the same old upscale stores on the Ginza that you have in any upscale mall in the USA, just at double or even triple the price. Louis Vuitton, Burberry, Coach, etc. Yawn. If you want Japanese shopping, even for fashion, then there's other better areas in Tokyo to do it (Shibuya for example).
